PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Mr O'Keefe:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to the government, I am sure, that the coalition will not be opposing the Australian Land Transport Development Amendment Bill, just as I am sure it will come as no surprise to the government that the opposition will be using the opportunity that this bill affords us through the debate to press home some of the concerns that people who happen to use our road and transport systems have about the government's policies on road funding, which has been seriously reduced in the last budget and will be reduced further in the next budget.

PARA.TAB: We will also be expressing the concerns that those people who use our roads have about the government's decision to increase fuel excise by 5c a litre for unleaded fuel and 7c a litre for leaded fuel. Indeed, the announcement in the budget speech of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 17 August was for an increase of 10c a litre. Those people who use our roads are very concerned about the high level of taxation this government is now imposing on them. Likewise, as the bill directly relates to the issue of road funding, people in the community are thoroughly sick and tired of discovering reductions in road funding by the government, and we will express those concerns.

The purpose of the bill is to extend the life of the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988. Those of us who were here in 1988 will recall that the government instituted a new mechanism whereby roads for which the Commonwealth had responsibility would be funded. That was due to expire at the end of the current financial year—by the middle of next year. The trust fund through which the moneys would be expended expires at the end of this calendar year.

As a result of a decision made at the heads of government meetings and also at the ATAC meetings—the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which is made up of Commonwealth, state and territory ministers for transport—there has been agreement to establish new legislation outlining the Commonwealth's responsibilities for roads and to provide a mechanism to fund those responsibilities. However, because of the way in which those agreements have been arrived at, there are delays in the drawing up of the new legislation which will carry the Commonwealth's road funding commitments. As a result, and in order to overcome the consequence of that, the government has decided to extend the life of the current Australian land transport development trust fund.In light of the opposition's strong support for the Commonwealth's role in road funding, we will be agreeing with the government on this bill to ensure that there is no obstacle in the way of the Commonwealth providing funds to maintain our roads in some semblance of order.

Having said that, it is worth now moving to the point which I think concerns so many motorists and users of our road transport system in Australia today—that is, the deteriorating amount of funds that the Commonwealth is applying to roads for which it has responsibility. In the last financial year, about $1,630 million was expended by the Commonwealth to meet its road commitments. This year, in the budget brought down by the Treasurer on 17 August—the budget which was described by virtually all fair and reasonable observers as the worst budget brought down in living memory, by a Treasurer who has been severely mauled in the press, in the minds of the public and by his own party's caucus and his own ministerial colleagues—there is a road funding commitment of $1,020 million. So we have gone from $1,630 million in road funding allocations to $1,020 million. If we look at the budget papers provided on the night on which the budget was brought down, we will see that the forward estimate for the next financial year is that the Commonwealth will outlay $813 million towards its road funding commitments.

One needs to have only a basic knowledge of arithmetic to work out that, if the government spent $1,630 million in the last financial year and in the next financial year it is proposing to spend $813 million, in effect the government has cut its road funding allocations in half in the course of two years. That, of course, would cause concern to any reasonable and fair observer, particularly people who use our roads.

I note as I speak this morning that the former land transport minister, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), is in the chamber. I know that he shares, along with all those other people, concerns about the inadequate amounts of funding that the Commonwealth is allocating for roads. It was he who brought into this House a few years ago a very innovative and effective program to overcome some of our worst road accident sites: the black spots program. It was one of the most effective programs that any government has introduced to overcome accidents, injuries and deaths on our roads.

The amount of money spent through the black spots program saved more lives per dollar spent than would ordinarily have been expected to be achieved out of ordinary road funding. Yet, as I am sure the honourable member for Charlton despairs, that program has now expired. Despite the original concept of its expiry in the last few months, I think the evidence has been more than sufficient to prove to anybody that we should have continued with the black spots road funding program and continued to provide funding to it so that we could overcome those road sites that we all know in our local areas are the cause of so many accidents.

It is worth making the point—and I think the black spots program proved it beyond any doubt, as will all the research done through the very authoritative sources that we have in Australia and overseas—that good roads are safe roads. If we do not have good roads and if we do not have the funding to achieve good roads, deaths and injuries will occur on our roads in a needless fashion. The motorists of Australia, the people who use our roads and who pay their taxes at the petrol bowser, are very concerned at the way in which this government has wiped out the black spots program, ending something that had proved its worth, and at the same time has halved road funding over a period of two years.

Motorists know that the change has occurred. They also know that today they are paying more taxes at the petrol bowser than they have ever paid in the history of this country. When Labor came to power 10 1/2 years ago fuel taxes at the petrol pump were 6c a litre. Under the Labor government's administration today, we now have a mechanism in place which will see petrol taxes go to 31c a litre for diesel and unleaded fuel and 33c a litre for leaded fuel. That is a direct result of this government's decision to use fuel as a means of raising revenue rather than raising revenue through the traditional means of the ordinary PAYE tax mechanism or other indirect tax measures.

Whilst the government will say about fuel taxes, `Well, we have to fund our commitments to education, to defence, to social security, to child care, to nursing homes and all the other things; therefore we can justify increasing taxes on fuel', no government and no fair or reasonable person could credibly argue that putting up taxes on fuel will assist our ability to create jobs. The government is reducing Australia's ability to create jobs. By lifting fuel taxes from 6c a litre to up to 33c a litre, the government is increasing the cost of doing business in Australia. It is reducing Australia's ability to compete and to export in the international marketplace and, by doing that, is reducing our ability to create jobs. The evidence is there for all to see: unemployment is hovering at around 10 1/2 per cent to 11 1/4 per cent, and seemingly we are not able to get out of that rut.

The reason for that is that governments are treating the people who use our roads as a vehicle through which to raise revenue for the purposes of operating their activities. That is not the right thing to do. It is hurting people very badly. The government's decision to reduce its road funding commitment is also hurting people unfairly. The opposition is determined to make these points.

As I look at my notes, I am reminded of the speech of the honourable member for Charlton when he first introduced the black spots road funding program. On that occasion he said that the black spots program would save 220 lives per annum. Road accidents cost this country in excess of $6 billion a year. Of course, any attempts to reduce the number of people killed or injured on our roads will have a very beneficial impact on the nation's income. As well, there is the fact that we would have less misery and suffering in the community.

When we talk about road funding we need to recognise that every dollar we take away from road funding, whether away from the normal allocations to roads or away from special programs like the black spots program, will cause both social and economic harm to this country. We need to recognise that. The honourable member for Charlton highlighted that when he introduced the black spots road funding program. In his speech then he said that for every $4 million spent on the normal road funding allocation a life could be saved, but under the black spots program for every $500,000 spent a life could be saved. In other words, the black spots program gave eight times more value for money in saving lives than does normal road funding, yet this government cut out that program in the last budget.

I know that in their hearts people like the honourable member for Charlton, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and many others on the government side of the House who are interested in transport matters know that the decision to do away with the black spots campaign is a very bad one. Whilst supporting the government's bill before the House today, the opposition makes an appeal to the government to reintroduce the black spots road funding program because it should never have been cut out and it has tremendous advantage for the people of Australia.

Putting aside the black spots program, we also make a plea to the government to allocate more funds to the road budget overall. We think the government can afford to do this because, over the next couple of years, it will reap billions and billions of dollars from the pockets of motorists in excess of what it used to get. By this time next year only 8.7c in every dollar collected in fuel excise will go towards roads. That means that in every dollar taken from the motorist at the petrol bowser there are 91.3c in the form of this government's taxes that do not go towards roads. That translates into about $8 billion or $9 billion per annum.

We say that we should go back to the days before this government came into power, pre-1983, when the then coalition government used to allocate towards roads 4c of the 6c collected in fuel excise. Two-thirds of all fuel excises collected by the previous coalition government was allocated towards improving our roads. Obviously a jump of that magnitude would be inconceivable in one budget, or even in two or three budgets. But let me make a plea to the government from this side of the House: the government ought to start working towards achieving a goal of returning to roads more of the moneys that are collected through fuel excise.

Not only do better roads saves lives and injuries; they also reduce the cost of transport. In the process of constructing and maintaining those roads we create many much needed jobs. I know that on previous occasions the honourable member for Charlton has spoken very highly of the job creation opportunities arising from road funding. Of course, the more the government increases road funding the more the opportunities are increased to create jobs, the more the likelihood is increased that people will have their lives saved or injuries reduced, and the more the likelihood is increased that the cost of transport in Australia will go down.

There are many good reasons to sustain the argument of members of the opposition. We are correct in pushing the issue of increased road funding, in pushing the issue of reintroducing the black spots program and in pushing the issue of trying to reduce the cost of transport by not treating fuel as a milch cow, in some sort of cargo cult mentality, to ensure that we can reduce the cost of transport in Australia so that it does not affect our ability to compete in the international marketplace and therefore reduce our ability to create jobs. From this side of the House we make that plea.

I know that my views and the views of members of the opposition are well and truly supported by ordinary road users, particularly by the commercial end of the road use business—that is, the transport industry. I spoke at the Australian Livestock Transport Association annual conference in Sydney on Friday afternoon following the address of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins. I can only say that Senator Collins's reception on that occasion was, to put it mildly, frosty because members of the Australian Livestock Transport Association well recognise the huge cost impost that has been imposed on them by this government with the 5c a litre increase in the cost of fuel brought down in the budget of 17 August.

To give an example of that, prior to the meeting, the livestock transport people who were present at the conference on Friday highlighted to me the cost of transporting, say, live cattle out of the port of Darwin. In fact, Jim Cooper from Gulf Transport gave me this example. He said that the cost of transporting live cattle, which is a rapidly growing industry for the Northern Territory and for Australia, out of Darwin will go up by $1.80 a head because of the 5c a litre increase in the cost of diesel. He cited the example of a six-decker road train, of which he has many, sourcing cattle from Queensland and trucking those cattle through Queensland, up into the territory and out through the port of Darwin.

The net consequence of jacking up the fuel tax by 5c a litre for one small aspect of the transport industry is to increase the cost of exporting our live cattle by up to $1.80 a head. That means that Australia is less competitive when competing for live cattle sales in the international marketplace. That is something that should concern every Australian, because from the income that we earn from those live cattle sales we can create jobs, and we so desperately need those jobs.

From those sorts of examples given at the conference of the Australian Livestock Transport Association last Friday, it is clear that these people are well justified in criticising this government for its budget measures of reducing road funding and increasing the taxes that road users have to pay for the privilege of driving on our roads. We make these points, secure in the knowledge that we are supported by the great bulk of Australian society and, indeed, by everyone involved in the Australian road transport industry because they have to wear the costs of these increased taxes and live with the consequences of there being less funds to spend on our roads to improve and maintain them. If we add to all of that the increased sales tax of two per cent that will be imposed on road users, which adds about another $2,400 to the cost of buying, say, a truck, these people are justified in expressing their concerns, as is the opposition.

Whether they be truck operators who are going to have to pay on average around $6,000 a year extra for their fuel bills, $2,400 a year extra for the purchase of a truck because of sales tax increases, and about $400 a year extra in operating expenses because of sales tax increases, or people who drive ordinary cars on the road to visit or do business, they are justified in their criticisms of this government. We who represent all those people in this House should be concerned on their behalf. That is why the government should heed the comments and the pleas of the opposition today to increase road funding, reintroduce the black spots program, stop treating the road users of Australia as a milch cow and do something to save lives, to save injuries, to reduce the cost of transport in Australia and to make Australia a more competitive economy.

In saying that, the opposition will support this bill, recognising that to do otherwise would simply provide an obstacle to the normal flow of Commonwealth funds to the states for the purpose of maintaining our road infrastructure. We support the bill, express those concerns and ask the government to act upon the pleas from this side of the House and from members of the road transport industry, because those pleas are well based and are meant sincerely.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), indicated, the purpose of the Australian Land Transport Development Amendment Bill is to provide interim arrangements before more detailed and specific legislation is introduced later on. Before the shadow minister goes, I would like to say that I appreciate the genuine level of balance that he brings to his responsibilities. While we differ in some considerations, I agree with a lot of what he said and I appreciate the generous comments that he made about the development of road transport policy and programs—some, to which he was kind enough to refer, having been developed while I was the minister. I have always appreciated my association with him and, as I say, the genuine way in which he has approached his responsibilities on behalf of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I make just one point of criticism in connection with the points that the shadow minister made. One of my good friends, and a very close colleague of mine, recently expressed it in these terms: how is it that the tories all support reducing the deficit but always want to see more money spent on roads and the cost of petrol reduced in the process of government cutting taxes? There is a very serious anomaly there that is difficult to reconcile. Along with the shadow minister, I would like to see a very substantial increase in the level of funding for those areas for which I maintain a very special interest. Of course, I have been in a position of being able to assess the significance of those changes.

The government has come through a period of very significant reform across the whole area of land transport. Over the last few years—and some of these were mentioned by the shadow minister—quite significant changes have been introduced. Many of those changes were made in the context of an Industry Commission report which indicated that, if Australia was able to achieve world standard efficiency in land transport, there would be a saving in the national cost of operating land transport to the extent of about $6,000 million—$4,000 million in the area of rail transport and $2,000 million in the area of road transport. It would have represented an overall benefit to our gross domestic product of something like three per cent, and that would represent an increase in GDP of something in excess of $10,000 million. Very substantial benefits would have accrued to the national economy, the national community, Australian families, income earners and producers as a result of those types of improvements.

Some additional considerations directed our attention to the types of reforms that were necessary. It was indicated—the shadow minister referred to this as well—that the national cost of road trauma is in excess of $6,000 million every year. We also had a continuing annual loss on the national rail system of $4,000 million every year. It was indicated that about $2.1 billion of that involved the types of losses which could be identified from the accounts for our rail systems. The remainder, the difference between the $2.1 billion and the $4 billion, lay in in-built costs which were not necessarily apparent from the accounts, such as hidden subsidies, concessions, reserve freight arrangements and so on. There was also about $400 million that was being lost on interstate freight movement for the Australian rail system. In the context of that and other considerations, the government embarked on a series of initiatives which, taken together, would represent the most significant group of initiatives in land transport ever considered. First of all, there was a record level of road funding.

There are about 30 new members in this chamber since the last election and many of them have heard conflicting arguments about what happened in connection with road funding. I want to emphasise to them that, say, for the first seven years after the Labor government was elected in 1983, there was an increase of 20 per cent in real terms in the total level of funds being applied to the road system compared with the seven years of the Fraser government. That represented an average increase of something like $250 million every year for each of those seven years—a very major increase in the level of funding.

Everyone knows of claims to the contrary that have been made by opposition spokesmen and women. Their claims cannot be substantiated, and the figures indicate that very clearly. In 1992-93, the financial year that we have just come through, the total level of funding for roads was $2.1 billion. That represented an increase in real terms of 25 per cent on the 1991-92 level of funding. These increases have been very substantial. People cannot drive around Australia either in their private motor cars or in their rigs and not realise that over the last 13 or 15 years there has been a very substantial increase in the quality of that network, as there needs to be, of course.

The national highway system will stand as a permanent monument to Labor initiatives. It was introduced in the first place by a Labor government and it was extended by another 2,500 kilometres when I was minister, making a total of 18,500 kilometres of national highway around Australia for which this federal government has accepted full responsibility. People should take the opportunity to read the brochure recently prepared by the Department of Transport and Communications entitled The length of the land: Australia's national highway, which indicates the importance and significance of the national highway.

We also established the National Road Transport Commission. The purpose of that was to achieve for the first time a level of uniformity for both technical and operational standards in road transport. Prior to that, there were about 200 separate regulations between the various states and state authorities. They were often conflicting, ambiguous and stupid regulations which needed to be torn out and made consistent, non-ambiguous and non-confusing. The National Road Transport Commission that we set up—an independent body reporting to the Australian council of transport ministers—was the means by which we attempted to overcome that problem.

We also introduced uniform charging for heavy vehicles on the roads. The Inter-State Commission originally made recommendations that mass distance charges should be about $22,000 for a six-axle articulated vehicle, $42,000 for a B-double and $70,000 for a triple-decker road train. In the system that we finally adopted, we incorporated a pay at the bowser element which had been requested by the road transport industry. That meant that the introduction of uniform charging was going to be much more sensible and the transport industry would be able to adapt itself to it much more easily.

As I said earlier, we also extended the national highway system. We had adopted, initially in the 1970s, 16,000 kilometres of national highway around Australia essentially linking together the capital cities. But it was apparent to me and to others that, in linking together the capital cities, there was no direct link between Brisbane and Melbourne and between Adelaide and Sydney. The Melbourne-Brisbane link was based essentially on the Newell Highway and the Adelaide-Sydney link was based essentially on the Sturt Highway. This added to the original 16,000 kilometres of national highway a distance of 2,500 kilometres. To put that into context, I suppose it would go from Canberra to London or perhaps even into Scotland. There are 18,500 kilometres of national highway and this federal government has accepted the responsibility for every cent which is spent on either developing or maintaining that system.

We also had significant improvements as far as programs in urban public transport were concerned. Prior to that, states could voluntarily take about 25 per cent of their state arterial funds and apply that to urban public transport projects. I thought that funds should be required to be put into urban public transport because every improvement there means that pressure is taken off the road system. It means the road system does the job better.

The electorate of the honourable member for Prospect, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Mrs Crosio), who is at the table at the present time, benefited substantially from that because of her vigilance in making sure that she identified where those improvements could be brought about. She brought them to my attention, we supplied the funds and her constituents have now benefited substantially from that program, as they did from the black spots program. All of those honourable members who were vigilant in taking advantage of those programs made sure that they brought some of the benefits that accrued from those programs into their electorates.

We increased the volume of funds going to urban public transport from what would have been about $115 million over those three years to $200 million. We said to the states, `Use it for public transport projects. Indicate to us what they are and we will work out with you the types of projects that should be implemented'. And we introduced some very remarkable and important ones. As part of the federal government's social equity approach, we particularly wanted to make sure that a lot of that funding went into the outer suburbs of the major metropolitan and provincial cities. That is where it went—into the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne. I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that your electorate benefited substantially because you, like so many of our members and colleagues, were vigilant about the way in which advantage could be taken of those good programs.

When we first introduced the black spots program, it was going to represent about $110 million over a three-year period. It was so popular because it was so successful and because it eliminated in excess of 4,000 of the worst death spots over the whole of Australia. Because it was saving lives and stopping crashes and injuries, that $110 million program finished up being a $270 million program. We cannot identify the people in the community whose lives have been saved as a result of that program, but we know they are there in their hundreds.

We also established the National Road Trauma Advisory Council. It was originally chaired by Sir Nicholas Shehadie and was suggested to us by Sir Dennis Paterson from South Australia. We brought together people with expertise in various areas to advise us about road trauma. The new chairman, Collin Freeland, a former senior bureaucrat within the federal bureaucracy, is helping to continue the solid leadership that was provided by Nick Shehadie.

If we put that black spots program together with the National Road Trauma Advisory Council; the Federal Office of Road Safety—which had the responsibility, on behalf of the federal government, of managing our approach to road safety—cooperative state authorities and voluntary community organisations concerned with road safety; all of the road improvements that came about, whether they were improvements in the road pavement and network itself or in the elimination of black spots; and education programs, we can see that there has been a remarkable reduction in the number of people killed on the roads. However, we should never be tolerant of a situation where those figures are substantial, as they continue to be.

In 1970 the number of people who died on the road network peaked at about 3,800. That figure was brought down as a result of all of those elements to which I referred, until, in 1988, 2,800 people died. Last year—1992—was the first year since records have been kept that the number of people killed on the road network dropped below 2,000. It has almost halved in those 20 years. Serious injuries were reduced from about 50,000 to 30,000.

All of those elements amount to substantial benefits in the area of road transport and the road network. We encourage the establishment of a peak national transport body. The National Transport Forum consists of representatives of all of the peak national transport bodies and acts as an umbrella organisation to give one voice to transport interests. Bruce McIver is now the chairman of that forum. He was the founder of the Livestock Transport Association, and is a former state and national president of that association and chairman of the National Transport Forum. This is a development of enormous significance which brings people together to give them one voice so that we can speak to them in the development of policy. They introduced a self-accreditation scheme, with federal government funding, cooperation and encouragement, to make it possible for higher standards of professionalism to be encouraged in an industry where professionalism had already reached a very high level.

We introduced vehicle safety regulations. The national control of vehicle standards is now under the jurisdiction of the federal government because of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act which I had the privilege of introducing into the parliament. We now control the quality of vehicles that come onto our road network. Whether they are buses, motorbikes, motor cars or trucks, we control that at the national level and we have consistent standards right across Australia. We have taken it away from the absurd situation that existed before, when we had some ridiculous contrasts in what one state expected in comparison with the state across that imaginary line we call a state border.

There have been substantial improvements in areas of bus safety as well. The rollover provisions, non-lock brakes, seat mountings and padding and seat belts have all been introduced in the last few years as a result of initiatives by a federal Labor government. We introduced a bicycle strategy to encourage people to use bicycles—a very conservative, conservationist type system of travel—to encourage people not to take their motor cars out, to encourage healthy lifestyles and to encourage improvements in the environment and a reduction in atmospheric pollution from motor cars. We cooperated with national bicycle groups in developing that strategy. They applauded it. They said that it was the first time—as it was—that an approach had been made at a national level to achieve any type of strategy. We got that strategy adopted by all of the states. They undertook that, in future when they were planning and developing their own road networks and transport systems, they would take into account the need to provide for bike riders and bicycles as well.

All of those elements that I referred to have been responsible for putting Australia right at the front of development around the world not only in the quality of road construction and the nature of design but also in the way in which the whole of the transport industry has been brought together, coordinated and integrated, to make sure that we achieve the sorts of benefits that those reports, such as the Industry Commission report, indicated would be available. So we have been able to coordinate a total land transport strategy. That is in place.

One of the concerns that I had was a proposal, which the federal government agreed to, as a result of an approach made by the states in the context of the Special Premiers Conference process, to develop what was being referred to as new federalism. The states said to us, `Move out of our areas'. One of those areas is state arterial roads. They said to us, `You give us the money; do not tie it. We will look after our roads. You move out and just look after the national highway system'.

I did not support that approach. I did not support, and I do not support, the decision that this government made in acceding to it. I said then, and I have had it confirmed, that we could not trust the states. I asserted then, and have had it confirmed since, that they would not use that money for roads. They are in the process of tucking away the $300 million that we untied and handed back to them. They are putting it into all different sorts of programs but away from roads. New South Wales has announced and disclosed recently that, out of the total of the untied money that went to New South Wales, $50 million was taken straight out of the roads budget. We know, and everyone else knows, what will now happen. Pressure will come back on the national government. Because of the national importance of a road network, it will be necessary to provide funds to overcome the dereliction of responsibility of the states. When the roads start to fall apart, those people who are concerned about them—transport operators and ordinary motorists—will want to know why. One of the chief reasons is that we have given the states the money to fix up, maintain, extend and improve the roads, but they are using those funds for purposes other than those for which we provided them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other members have indicated, the Australian Land Transport Development Amendment Bill primarily extends the time available for the operation of the funding provisions that the government now has through the Australian land transport development trust fund. The bill is necessary to ensure that the funds that the Commonwealth has allocated in the budget are available for road expenditure. Nevertheless, that is done in the context of substantial reductions in road funding. I take the point of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) that about $350 million of funds previously identified for roads has now been put into the states' general purpose funding arrangements. They are expected to continue to spend this on roads which are their particular responsibility outside of the national highway system.

PARA.TAB: I am disturbed by the remarks of the honourable member for Charlton that certain state governments are not taking that responsibility seriously. I think they should be subject to criticism at home and abroad. I do not oppose the concept of states being responsible for funding for their roads. If a particular level of government has a responsibility which is identified clearly, it should meet that responsibility and suffer the consequences electorally if it fails to do so. I would join with any other federal member in criticising a state government that backed away from that responsibility and attempted to use that money for another purpose. I trust that that matter will be attended to in due course.

Nevertheless, it does not alter the fact that, after a big splash of spending on roads, the budget figures indicate quite clearly a cutback in the amount of money that will be made available to the fund this year for the purpose of road construction. We have $350 million put away through general purpose funding. Looking at the figures, I see that, whereas about $1.6 billion in total was allocated last year, that is to come down to an average of $800 million a year. According to the explanatory memorandum provided, funding will be $2.46 billion over three years. I do not know why we keep being told how much will be spent over three years. We have annual budgets. I believe that the amounts should be identified year by year. It gets even worse on an annual basis when, from the figures I am able to establish, about a billion dollars is to be allocated this year plus the $350 million that has been transferred away. If I add up the $1 billion-plus and the $350 million, I find that the total is only about $1.4 billion, which is a couple of hundred million dollars down on last year. So that in itself must be the subject of criticism.

A lot has been said here this morning about the need for an adequate road system. I join with others in saying that special allocations should be targeted to black spots—in other words, areas of the roads where there is adequate evidence of frequent crashes or deaths. In raising the black spot program today in a slightly broader context, I highlight something that was raised here just yesterday by the opposition on the use of federal government funding to the states as a process of blackmail. The minister responsible for roads made the granting of black spot funding in Western Australia conditional on Western Australia altering its laws as to the level of blood alcohol. For driving purposes in Western Australia the blood alcohol level is 0.08—a figure that seemed to be achieving very similar results to that of other states which had a 0.05 blood alcohol level. There is no statistical evidence to suggest that more people were being killed in Western Australia. After some public opposition, particularly from me, when random breath testing was introduced there was a massive growth in deaths. When I raised that matter in the press and asked, `Where are the promises that the police gave us about random breath testing saving lives?', people came back and said, `We never promised to save lives; we just said that we would get the drunks off the roads'. I said, `If you have the drunks off the roads, what has been killing people all these years?'.

All sorts of statistics can be produced showing the number of people with high blood alcohol levels who are involved in crashes. I do not disagree that they are a contributing factor, but I think the statistics tend to overstate the situation. The reason for the accident might have been totally unrelated to blood alcohol. If anybody is found dead or injured in a vehicle, police take a blood sample. That particular crash is then designated an alcohol related crash. I think that is very silly. We should be looking at some of the other problems such as road standards and black spots, which are a major contributing factor. As a representative of rural areas, I use these roads all the time and I know that to be the case. Whilst there was some doubt as to whether a 0.08 blood alcohol level was more significant than 0.05, there was no doubt statistically as to these dangerous spots on the roads. The government said, `You don't get the black spot money unless you line up on the 0.05 issue'. In other words, it said, `We will continue to allow people to get killed on these very identifiable and dangerous parts of the road while we argue with you over another issue of less consequence'.

The other day in this place the government gave us another example. Notwithstanding the fact that a state government had power in this area, the federal government said to the people, `If we are elected, we will cease the practice of making guild fees in tertiary institutions compulsory'. That seemed to be pretty fair and above board. The government was elected, but then it introduced legislation to take money away from education and give it to political activists. It said, `We, the federal government, do not agree with you, the state government, on a matter of policy duly debated during an election campaign'.

Firstly, I cannot understand the benefit to students of taking away money from their education and giving it to another area—which it had the right to do. It is just another example of the sort of blackmail that the black spot issue identified. The irony of the black spot issue is that, having bullied the Western Australia government into passing legislation on the 0.05 limit, it has now cancelled the black spots program. It is a great lesson for state governments which comply on such issues; they gain nothing in the end.

Yesterday we raised the issue of landcare funding. One of the fundamentals of any environmental program is being made conditional on the state knuckling its forehead to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his proposals to solve the problem of Aboriginal native title. I could not believe those two issues could be linked in that fashion—but we had it confirmed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). Western Australia—the state that I represent—is a huge area with massive resources contributing 25 per cent of national exports. It has to be linked by roads.

We had no say as a nation—and the Prime Minister was not able to control it—on where the iron ore or gold came up through the surface. Whoever made those decisions made sure those deposits were about as far from our population centres as they possibly could be and as far as possible from the coast where they might be processed or from where they might be exported. Western Australia has had to provide the infrastructure of roads, in particular, to service those very remote developments. We can take the product away by rail, but the very small number of people associated with developments of that nature in this modern day require the services of roads.

Past conservative governments recognised that to the extent that just 25 years ago, when all these great developments were occurring, Western Australia was paid some 18 per cent of total national road funding, as provided by the Commonwealth. We have seen that sink to eight per cent. Whilst I could not argue in the modern context for 18 per cent, I genuinely believe that eight per cent is far too little. But it is eight per cent in real terms of such a substantially reduced amount of money. This is where the real problem arises. The states—and the system—are no longer receiving anywhere near the same proportion of moneys in terms of road funding, as was once provided. A graph entitled `Relationship Between Road Funding and Fuel Tax Collections 1980/81 to 1993/94' compares the relationship between road expenditure and excise collected. I understand that, under the rules, only the graph can be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to have the graph—which I cannot explain by holding it up in this place—incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point the graph makes is that there has been a massive increase in taxes collected and, relatively, an ever declining proportion spent on roads. As with many other taxes, it was introduced for no other purpose than road construction and maintenance—the old user pays concept. Whilst I do not object to the user paying, traditionally—as with all such taxes—once people grab hold of them, the taxes get worse.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian government has put forward a proposal to be given the approximately 6c per litre that the federal government now raises from road taxes. The Western Australian government wants to administer the lot. The honourable member for Charlton says that that might not be wise. Basically, it would give Western Australia substantially more money than it is getting at the moment for road maintenance and development. This huge state, delivering 25 per cent of national exports, should have the support of the nation in providing infrastructure.

We provide about 40 per cent of grain production—another part of the export system that requires a substantial road infrastructure. It is just not practical to go on cutting back. In fact, Western Australians consume, per capita, 1.5 times the amount of automotive fuel consumed by the people of New South Wales. They also consume a higher proportion of fuel which is subject to the diesel excise rebate. But when we allow for that, we find that Western Australians are paying about $50 per capita—a couple of hundred dollars per family—more in fuel tax than people who reside in New South Wales.

It is not very difficult to establish why, when we look at the size of the state, the remoteness of so many of our resources and the simple fact that that makes the provision of public transport, such as electric trains, so much more difficult. I frequently remind people in my electorate that, notwithstanding the approval certain people give to public transport, there is no chance of my walking out the door of the Wyalkatchem hall and catching the next electric train back to Perth. The train is not there; nor is a regular taxi or bus service. People have to drive their cars. This is a real problem in Western Australia; the road infrastructure has to be maintained and it is not being maintained when there is an ever declining allocation of aggregate moneys and an ever declining proportion of it going to Western Australia.

For many years the states of Victoria and New South Wales have argued that they built our roads. Statistically, technically at least, they could sustain that argument. The reverse is now the truth. Under the present distribution arrangements, if Western Australia could be given the 6c per litre contributed through fuel taxes paid, it would have more money to spend on roads. It is a matter of great importance to us. I commend the state minister, Mr Charlton, for his efforts in trying to make this understood. He had the Commissioner for Main Roads put some figures together. It was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If 6c per litre . . . of the Federal. . . excise collections from Western Australia were returned to the State, this would raise $132M pa, an increase of $33.6M pa over the 1993/94 indicative allocation of $98.4M . . .

The point he is making is pretty simple. Under the current arrangements, even on the basis of this roughly 6c per litre which we are confirming today, if the money continues to go to the Australian land transport fund, Western Australia is subsidising roads in more developed and smaller states to the tune of about $33 million a year. He said:

PARA.TAB: Assuming that this additional revenue is pro-rated across National Roads and State Roads in accordance with the needs identified in Table 2 of the Roads 2000 Report (p 15), the following increase in revenue would result:

SPEECH.PARA: National roads would have an increase of $7.2 million, state roads an increase of $26.4 million for a total, as I have already mentioned, of $33.6 million. They are the official figures. I believe a state should receive no less than that, particularly when it is in Western Australia's situation.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Charlton also made a lot of the fact that the government has achieved certain arrangements in relation to uniformity of standards applicable to vehicles. I am a supporter of the concept that people should be able to drive from one side of Australia to the other and not have to stop at borders to unload a couple of tonnes, have the height of their load checked, or have to get a special permit for a load. I have seen people delayed for a week at a border waiting for the right permit to take such things as agricultural machinery across the border. Whether we like it not, that machinery cannot be compressed to take it from one state to another. It is made in foreign countries to certain height and width specifications. It is downright silly that certain governments should try to prevent traffic carrying these loads on their roads when that is the only way for the loads to be transported. Even if these loads are transported by rail, there will always be a road component.

My great fear, stemming from some of these arrangements, is that the debate is still concentrating on the lowest common denominator. Western Australia—along with Queensland from time to time—has led Australia in exciting new road transport configurations. Shortly after I went to the north-west in 1958, the situation was that, north of Carnarvon, people could drive a single prime mover and tow three trailers behind it, while north of Geraldton, a person could drive a single prime mover and tow two trailers behind it. I became active in the road transport industry and convinced the then Liberal government that that distinction was silly and that we ought to be able to drive multiple trailers out from the perimeter of Perth. We conducted a trial, which ran for six months, and it was so successful that within a month the government opened that section up.

But the debate still rages. We were then allowed to transport these trailers as far as 30 miles out of Perth, but it cost a third of the gross turnover of a single trailer to get someone else to come out, pick up that second trailer, and cart it in the last 30 miles. Little by little we have crept closer and closer—the distance is now eight miles out—but the cost has not changed. We still have to get someone else to pick up that particular trailer or else do a double trip. The honourable member for Charlton has said that these double road trains carrying stock, or other things, ought to be able to go straight into the suburbs of Perth, but people are going crazy over that.

One person was foolish enough to say that it would double the amount of transport going past the front door when, in fact, it would halve it. At the present time, the trailers passing that person's place are passing one at a time. When two go together there is only one lot of noise. There is a lot of evidence to prove that this reduces road damage because there is not the extra weight of a second prime mover on the road. In fact, all the efficiencies go up. People have to stop using road safety measures as a means of protecting inefficient rail systems. Governments either have to make the rail systems efficient or they have to let the road transport system deliver the services. It is a service to the people and we have to put an end to the non-tariff barriers within our own country, such as we have today. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to contribute to the discussion on roads in Australia, and road funding in particular, in this debate on the Australian Land Transport Development Amendment Bill. I do so with a great degree of disappointment and sadness at the fact that, despite the national pressure that is continually applied to governments, both state and federal, to increase allocations for roads and to do something about upgrading our national road system, we have just seen a budget which slashes road funding to about the lowest level in real terms that our country has known. That kind of behaviour is inconsistent with a government that is dedicated to the development of our nation.

PARA.TAB: If we really believe in regionalisation and in providing opportunities to all Australians, it is essential that we have a top class infrastructure system. A vital element of that infrastructure is clearly roads. So it is not good enough for the government to come into this place and suggest to the Australian people that the task is somehow completed and therefore less money should be allocated to roads. I know it is fashionable to talk about very fast trains and tilt trains, the Alice Springs to Darwin railway, and all sorts of other rail enhancement projects. No doubt many of these schemes have merit and a real place in Australia's transport system of the future. But, in reality, the number of rail lines in Australia is decreasing, and the share of our transport task undertaken on the roads is increasing.

Just recently we witnessed the Queensland Premier, who received an increase in funding from the federal government, returning home from the Premiers Conference in Canberra and saying that 29 rail lines would be closed because he was out of money. He made that decision instantly upon returning from Canberra, so clearly the closures had been thought out well and truly in advance: 29 rural lines, about a third of the Queensland system, were to go. That is the kind of commitment that Labor in Queensland has towards our infrastructure system. Naturally there was an outcry when so much of the rail system was to go. A committee of inquiry was established and it is taking evidence all over the place. Every community is anxious to protect its rail line. The interesting thing that has come out of that inquiry is why people are not using the rail system. It is not because they do not like it or because they do not want it, but because the rail system has failed to provide a service. The inefficiencies, the lack of a professional marketing outlook, and the seeming lack of attention to customer needs, have led people to desert the rail systems of Australia in droves. It is not good enough and it needs to be fixed. There needs to be a much more professional approach to management of our rail systems.

But whatever happens to improve railway lines and the rail system across our country, there is still going to be an increasing demand for road transport services. There will be an increasing need for Australians to travel by road, using their motor vehicles, to get to their destinations, and for road transport to take an important role in our national freight task. We need better roads. It is a national disgrace that they have been allowed to decline as they have over recent times. Instead of our road system improving, it is degenerating. It is a disaster for our country that there are to be further reductions in road funding by this federal government. Those opposite should hold their heads in shame. I certainly feel sorry for the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who spoke earlier. He must feel deeply embarrassed that much of the work he did to build up the importance of roads on the national agenda has been so quickly whittled away since his departure from the ministry. The black spots program was axed absolutely, despite all the rhetoric that we have heard from government members over the years about the lives that would be saved and how critically important it was to our nation. In one swoop that program has gone in this budget—

TALK.START.PARA: —A black day for black spots.

—A black day for black spots, and a black day for Australian motorists. Sadly, the ALP continues to give a low priority to roads. In his opening remarks the honourable member for Charlton criticised this side of the House because we advocate lower fuel tax but higher expenditure on roads. He said that that was inconsistent. It is not the slightest bit inconsistent because only a very small percentage of what is collected in fuel tax is actually spent on roads. There is infinite scope, just from the amount collected in fuel tax, to boost enormously the amount of funding available for roads. The days when all of the fuel excise was spent on roads are well and truly behind us, and that is disappointing. Today, perhaps less than a quarter of the fuel excise collected actually ends up being spent on roads. The money is diverted from the motorists of Australia to other projects. No doubt some of the projects are worthwhile government activities, but some of them, including projects to improve the swimming pool for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), or to provide a new carport, or barbecues for public servants, are not considered by motorists to be a wise use of their petrol dollars.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that Labor has been using the fuel pumps of Australia as branch offices of the Australian Taxation Office. Fuel excise has become an integral part, a critical part, an increasing part—there has been something like a 700 per cent increase in fuel excise over the life of this government—of general revenue now rather than something specifically allocated to roads. Fuel tax is a particularly iniquitous tax in a vast country such as Australia. It is a tax on distance. The further people travel the more fuel tax they pay. If ever there were a country that ought not to tax distance it is a vast continent such as Australia.

We talk about decentralisation. The government sets up task forces and committees of inquiry to promote regionalisation and the like. Its new task force under the leadership of that great bastion of industry, Bill Kelty, is now travelling around Australia to look at ways of improving the lot of industry in country and provincial areas. That task force was set up in the same month as the government decided to increase fuel tax. So that shows how sincere the government is about really helping the rural and provincial areas.

Fuel tax is a tax on everyone who does business outside of the capital cities. It adds to the price of every item on every shelf in every store for people who live outside of the capital cities. So, if the government is serious about doing something for provincial industry, serious about redressing the income imbalance between country and city, the first thing it should do is abolish fuel excise—get rid of it altogether—to give country industries an opportunity to compete fair and square with those located in city regions.

One wonders about the sincerity of this particular task force that is now travelling around the countryside. Nearly all of the members of the task force have capital city addresses and yet they are supposed to be giving advice on what to do to assist provincial industry. There is only one Queenslander on the committee and he is a trade union activist. So the most decentralised state in Australia, the one with the most amount of provincial industry, has been worthy of only one place on this particular committee. The interstate members of the committee did not even think it was necessary to come to Queensland to attend any of the public hearings of the committee in that state. So this government is really demonstrating its lack of real interest in provincial regions.

That lack of real interest in provincial regions was heavily reinforced as the fuel tax was increased in this last budget—another 5c a litre, which was not announced, I might add during the lead-up to the election. At that time the government was critical of our proposals to abolish fuel excise altogether. But, when it got back into government, at the first available opportunity it put another heavy slug on Australian motorists through fuel excise.

The second part of that excise increase was the new tax that is to be imposed, a super tax on leaded petrol. The government claims that this has been introduced because of its desire to do something about lead levels in the atmosphere.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just want more money.

—But, in reality, as the honourable member says, the government just wants more money. The government says it has imposed a super tax on leaded petrol to encourage conversion to unleaded fuel, but the Australian Institute of Petroleum reports that sales of leaded petrol are already falling by 5.7 million litres per month while unleaded sales increase by more than that amount. So the conversion is occurring without this new tax. The government says it wants the lead in air figure reduced below 1.5 micrograms per cubic metre—that is the National Health and Medical Research Council's level of concern.

PARA.TAB: However, the seasonally adjusted average across all testing sites in Brisbane has not exceeded 0.5 micrograms per cubic meter—a third of the safety level—since 1988. The Queensland department of the environment said in its 1991-92 annual report that `lead levels continued to decline to such an extent that lead levels in Brisbane are never expected to exceed national health standards'.

Sydney is supposed to be the main trouble spot, but even there the level of concern has not been exceeded since 1988, and the Environment Protection Authority now reports the lowest airborne lead levels on record. It seems to me that the problem has solved itself without the government's tax increase.The latest edition of The Road Ahead of October 1993 deals with this question of lead in the blood of children. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The most recent blood-lead level tests (being carried out in Victoria) appear to show that, far from the 33 per cent of children the Government claims would be above the national goal in 1996, less than four per cent are above the level today.

So it is quite clear that this increase in tax on leaded fuel is there for only one reason, to raise additional money for the government. This new tax also demonstrates the hypocrisy of the government in the way in which it deals with these issues. A press release issued jointly by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the former Minister for Land Transport, the honourable member for Charlton, as recently as 30 December 1992 states:

Mrs Kelly said: "Despite clear statements and reassurances since 1990 by myself, Bob Brown, and even, in April this year, by the Prime Minister, we have continued to receive many hundreds of form letters based on the false belief that the Government has been planning to penalise owners of older cars by selectively higher petrol prices. . .
"These are merely ideas that have been put to the Government and they have not been accepted. . . .
Mr Brown said that the main consequence of forcing older cars off the road would be to disadvantage many low income families.
"Such a move would deprive many ordinary citizens of their independent mobility and access to work, health care, education, and cultural and recreational activities.
Later on the honourable member for Charlton went on to debunk the idea that it was old cars that were causing road accidents. He evoked the name of the Prime Minister and then went on to say:

We state categorically that the Commonwealth Government has no intention of discriminating against owners of earlier model motor cars. We have not been considering and are not considering any action to force these cars from the nation's roads.

What happened between December 1992, when the environment minister and the then land transport minister both categorically denied that there was any consideration being given to a tax on leaded fuel, and the budget in August 1993? The simple answer is that there was an election, and the government forgot all of its promises to the motorists of Australia and imposed yet another tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mrs Kelly said there would be no tax increase on leaded petrol.

—I do not know on which page the environment minister actually signed this particular document, but she clearly identified herself with that commitment, and now she has turned around and done precisely the opposite. These tax increases hurt country people particularly harshly. But they hurt also those who are actually trying to construct roads, because these new taxes will have to be paid by Australia's road builders. Not only has this government reduced its own allocations to road funding to appallingly low levels but also it is taxing to an increasing degree all of those authorities involved in road construction. It will particularly hurt local authorities who build a lot of country roads and, indeed, city roads.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to read some comments about the effect on country local authorities in Queensland of this increase in fuel excise. The Barcoo shire in the west, which has only 189 ratepayers, will have to pay $14,013 extra in fuel excise as a result of this government increase. That will mean an extra bill of $74 for every ratepayer in the shire. The alternative is that the Barcoo shire build about half a kilometre less of bitumen road each year. Boulia shire, with 176 ratepayers, will have a rate rise of $73.86 for every ratepayer as a result of just this fuel excise increase.

What about the Brisbane City Council where the Lord Mayor, Alderman Sorley, was so critical of the coalition during the days leading up to the previous election? He was so concerned about potential cost increases on local government. But his city council will be up for another $982,061 just as a result of the government's fuel excise increases in this budget. I have not heard Alderman Sorley and his Labor mates complaining about that million dollar increase. That apparently is acceptable.

However, it again means that scores of additional streets in Brisbane will not be constructed and roads will not be repaired because this federal government has decided to take the money from Australian councils, from Australian road builders and put it in its own pocket. That really is a disgraceful way in which to deal with an important national infrastructure such as our road system.

So the tax on fuel—over 30c a litre—is now close to half the cost per litre of fuel in a state like Queensland. But that fuel excise is not the only tax the government collects from fuel. Like everyone else, fuel companies pay income tax and, like all other people involved in business, they will pay the increased sales taxes. The people selling and distributing fuel will pay the fuel excise on their own delivery costs, as well as all the other taxes that the government imposes on their day-to-day operations. So the government certainly has a very strong vested interest in people travelling as far as they can because it collects extra dollars on every mile.

Indeed, fuel tax is a particularly iniquitous tax because of the way it penalises country industry and those who want to be productive in our community. The fuel tax falls particularly heavily on exporters who need to move their product to ports to go to other parts of the world. It is a tax, of course, that is not borne by most of our competitors around the world. It is an additional burden that Australian industry is required to wear as a result of this government's absolute determination to increase its revenue from Australian motorists.

Another concerning aspect of road construction in Australia is the wasteful use of funds. I heard the honourable member for Charlton talk about the way in which the states siphon off road funding. Undoubtedly, a considerable proportion of the money provided by the federal government to the states for roads is not used on bitumen, gravel and concrete but to fund bureaucracies. The money is used to pay for the states' public servants—the ever increasing army of engineers, quality control officers, planning report providers, safety officers and the like, which these days produce enormous overheads on every road project.

When a council gets a release for a road construction project, it can expect something like one-quarter to one-third of the money to never actually be delivered because it has been used by the state government bureaucracy in measuring every pothole before it is filled and calculating economic assessments—all of which does nothing to extend our national road system. I might add—and this is of critical importance—there is no evidence that it has produced better quality roads. Indeed, there are many embarrassing examples of our state road construction authorities having to go back to repair a big new road project weeks after it has been opened. So, in fact, we have built a bureaucracy around our road system. So much of the money that is collected these days, which is allegedly allocated to road expenditure, does not go on producing better roads. It is time that kind of expenditure is brought to account.

Also, there seems to be a lack of priority on important projects. So often we widen roads around poor alignments rather than fix the job in the first place. Clearly, there is a need to give priority to some of those projects that are causing present delays and problems. I briefly mention one in my own electorate: the Gunalda Range is a classic case.(Time expired)
