TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Land Transport Development Amendment Bill amends the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988, the ALTD Act, to extend the operation of the Australian land transport development trust fund. This amendment will allow the $2.46 billion that the Commonwealth has allocated to fund roadworks on national highways over the next three calendar years to be funded from the current ALTD Act, until new legislation is in force governing the new roads program.

PARA.TAB: This amendment will not alter the government's commitment to develop a new national highway act during 1994 to replace the ALTD Act of 1988. The national highway act will create a more efficient road management system, with potentially great benefits not just to the taxpayer and road users, but also to the economic growth of the nation as a whole. As part of this government's commitment to creating an appropriate roads administration program, a full consultative process is under way, involving state governments and major industry bodies.

The national highway bill for the post-1993 roads program is well on track, with consideration and passage likely in 1994. This is why it is necessary to amend the ALTD Act to extend its operation and ensure that the federal roads program can continue to be delivered until the new national highway bill is in place.

The introduction of this amendment will not alter the government's intention to fund the national highway system only from 1 January 1994. This commitment arose from the July 1991 Premiers Conference where it was agreed that road funding responsibility for each level of government should be more clearly defined and that each tier of government should concentrate on funding, planning and building roads that were clearly within their responsibility.

It is important that state and local governments take on more responsibility for funding and operating the road systems that are their own responsibility. This should ensure a more efficient allocation of road funding, rather than simply looking to the federal government every year. It is also important to note that it was the states that wanted this role and agreed to it at the 1991 Special Premiers Conference.

I share the concerns raised earlier by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) about how this will operate. The question of the actions of the states on this and a number of other issues relating to funding provided by the federal government raises real concerns about the use of untied grants to states.

To provide the government with the ability to extend the current ALTD Act, three sunset clauses within the act require amendment: subsection 12(1) provides that road user revenue payments into the trust fund may only be made before 1 January 1994; subsection 12(2) provides that a proportion of refunds applicable to road user charges payable before 1 January 1994 be offset against road user charges payable into the trust fund; and section 25 provides that the trust fund shall be closed at the end of 30 June 1994. The provisions of this amendment remove each of these final dates and give effect to a continuation of current ALTD trust fund arrangements. The proposed new national highway act would contain provisions for the closure of the ALTD trust fund.

Turning to details of the bill, clauses 1 and 2 contain the usual citation and commencement provisions. Clause 3(a) of the bill provides for the continuation of road user charge revenue payments into the trust fund beyond the date of 1 January 1994, which would otherwise apply. Clause 3(b) of the bill likewise provides for the continuation of the provision contained in subsection 12(2) of the act such that the proportion of refunds applicable to road user charges payable after 31 December 1993 be offset against road user charges payable into the trust fund. Clause 4 of the bill provides for the continuation of the ALTD trust fund for an indefinite period or until it is repealed by the inclusion of an appropriate clause in a new act for administration of the federal roads program. The trust fund would otherwise close at the end of 30 June 1994.

Land transport and the public capital expenditure associated with it are usually spoken of in terms of micro-economic reform. However, the macro-economic effects of road expenditure must not be underestimated. The federal government has shown, especially since the One Nation statement, its commitment to providing the necessary investment in public infrastructure and, through the development of the national highway act, an increased efficiency in the application of that investment. I quote from an article in the September 1992 edition of The Economist, entitled `The Case for Central Planning':

SPEECH.PARA: Liberal (i.e. conservative) thinking has ruled economic policy for the past decade. It is no coincidence that the 1980's were also a time of diminishing public investment in infrastructure. Governments rallied against public spending of most sorts—and, by and large, rightly so. But they sometimes failed to distinguish between useful spending programs and wasteful ones.
This was speaking in an international context but there are also some relevant considerations to the Australian experience. I quote further from the same source:

Adequate infrastructure well used, undoubtedly promotes economic growth. To get these benefits in full, government must take charge—always making as much use of market forces and private enterprise as possible, but never seeking to shirk their responsibility as chief executive.

A key element of the new arrangements under the national highway act is that the allocation of funds to the national highway will be determined on the basis of national priorities. It is therefore entirely possible that states may not have consistent proportions of NHS funding over time. National priorities require a national approach; they cannot be left to eight state and territory governments and countless local governments. That would cause inefficiencies due to disparity of approach, parochialism and a lack of proper consideration of the needs of the nation. Clel Harrall from the World Bank explains the relationship between investment in highway stocks and private sector output as follows:
Roads like any transport investment, operate fundamentality by reducing economic distance between spatially separated markets.

. . . .By reducing the costs of commercial or social interaction between diverse regions their different resource bases can be exploited to the mutual benefit of each according to the laws of comparative advantage. The more different the resource endowments of the various regions, the greater will be the benefits of specialisation permitted by improved transport—as is most obviously illustrated by the differences between cities and agricultural areas.

He could have been talking about Australia, especially about our national system. Agricultural industries in Australia will be boosted by better roads and access to ports, et cetera. We have to work on that in a continuing way as a national priority. Manufacturing zones will also benefit through better linkages.

PARA.TAB: The US has led the world in macro-economic road investment models. While both the government and the opposition in Australia have used, for example, the Murphy modelling processes to examine, for instance, Fightback, the use of similar modelling processes to examine the macro-effects of road spending has perhaps not received the attention that it should. One US study of this type showed an extremely high correlation between per capita income growth and highway capacity and pavement quality, because highway facilities raise the level of transportation services that are available to producers, which in turn stimulates investment to utilise these facilities. The OECD has conducted similar studies and, overall, these have shown a similar correlation between productivity and infrastructure investment. The correlation exists especially in countries with similar conditions to Australia in geographic size and population dispersion—for example, Canada.

The federal government has led the way with programs such as black spots, the urban public transport program and the rural highways and provincial cities program. Those programs have provided jobs and economic growth in the areas they affected and have reduced accident levels, resulting in government savings in a wide range of areas. The results of these programs, particularly the economic and social benefits, should now be clear to the other levels of government. They wanted responsibility for roads. They should pick up the ball and run with it. It is also important to note that even after the expiry of these programs road funding levels will still be above the historic average level of funding by federal governments.

A growing number of economic theorists are acknowledging the role of road infrastructure in macro-economic terms, and not just overseas. For example, researchers at Monash University have calculated that the net present benefits to the community for carrying out safety improvements to 82 intersections in Melbourne, for an investment of around $7.5 million, would be $66.2 million. That resultant saving basically relates to a reduction in accidents and the enormous costs that they bring to the community. Phil Raskall estimated the cost to the community of one suicide at $0.5 million. The cost of road deaths must be of the same order of magnitude.

States must realise the benefits of this spending and act. In my electorate, black spot funding has been a very important part of local infrastructure development in the last 12 months. I think over $1 million was spent in Corinella, providing improvements to the highway to Phillip Island, to a number of railway crossings in the Cranbourne and Dandenong South parts of the electorate and also to traffic lights in the Cranbourne area. The states also have to take up this responsibility and run with it.

In terms of the federal government's commitment to the black spots program, I was very disappointed to see in this budget that we did not fund black spots. I will be urging the government to reinstigate that program in the coming year and to work towards continuing it as an important part of the government's approach to roads. But, again, as a result of the Premiers Conference the role of the states in those areas and the points raised by the honourable member for Charlton earlier about states siphoning off money that has been delegated to road funding have to be taken into account.

In terms of the federal government's strategic approach to road funding and transport planning in the future, it was recently announced that a national transport planning task force would be formed. It was announced, as I understand it, through the policy statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) prior to the federal election, and has since been acted upon. Three people have been appointed to that committee: Mr Ian Webber, chairman of Mayne Nickless Ltd; Mr Lance Hockridge, group general manager of BHP Transport; and Dr Derek Scrafton, director general of transport from South Australia. They are all people with real, lasting experience in the industry and great knowledge of the transport needs of this country. I think they will perform a crucial role in making sure that the government gets its transport priorities right.

The NTPT is to focus principally on the interstate movement of freight and will have two primary functions. Firstly, it is to perform a strategic role in assessing the future pattern of transport demand, planned infrastructure investment to meet those demands, including alternative sources, and the broader economic costs and benefits of increased transport infrastructure investment. Secondly, the NTPT will look at all aspects of intermodal issues, especially the efficiency and cost effectiveness of the interface between land transport and sea and air transport infrastructure. However, broader international freight issues will be considered in other forms.

The task force is to have regard in its work for the social and environmental impact of the transport system and the maintenance and enhancement of safety standards. This strategic approach, involving experience from within the industry, should put us in a position whereby the priorities that we set nationally for the national highway system and national transport plans are the right ones and take into account the needs of the community and of industry.

In conclusion, the bill we have before us today is to maintain the current commitment to a national strategy agreed to by the Premiers Conference. The new national highway act is being developed and will be implemented in a consultative manner. We have, through the national transport planning task force, an approach for the future which will put us in good stead. As I said earlier, I am concerned about the role of the states in the funding of roads. Untied grants, in my experience in Victoria in recent times, have not been a satisfactory way of approaching national priorities, although I understand that many of the priorities we are setting are state priorities. I am concerned about the way the states will actually implement those initiatives. The federal government has a continuing commitment to the future of the national priorities for national transport initiatives. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CSL Sale Bill will give effect to the long awaited privatisation of the CSL by public float. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories have played a very important role in the health of Australia and in Australia's defences against disease for over 75 years. Obviously the health of the nation is a matter of the very highest national interest, and consequently the outcome of the sale of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, in view of its long historic and effective involvement in the health of Australians, is a matter of great concern to many people.

PARA.TAB: The CSL was established in 1916 as an arm of the quarantine service so that Australia could be self-sufficient in pharmaceuticals at a time of isolation, especially during periods of war. Since then CSL has woven itself into Australian medical history on numerous occasions.

In 1918, as Australian soldiers were returning from World War I, CSL produced Australia's first vaccine against influenza, and consequently the Australian population, during the early 1920s, suffered less from that scourge that went around the world than many other countries. CSL made three million doses to protect Australians against the most virulent form of the virus which has emerged this century.

In 1923 CSL was one of the four laboratories worldwide to produce insulin. CSL vaccines protected Australian soldiers against smallpox and tetanus during World War II. It is worth noting that, as a result of this, not one Australian soldier contracted tetanus during the entire period of the war years.

In 1944, CSL enabled Australia to be the first country to supply penicillin to its civilian population. In 1952, CSL commenced the fractionation of serum into lifesaving blood products, a task it continues to this day. CSL's vaccines were used in Australian schools in the mass vaccination programs against polio, measles, diphtheria and whooping cough in the 1950s and onwards. In fact, Australia set a world standard in maintaining the health of our younger children during those difficult years because of the effectiveness of the mass vaccination programs.

CSL also developed various antisera and antivenoms, including the funnel-web spider antivenom in the 1980s. For a long time CSL has been the only producer of human vaccines used in Australia and one of only two producers of biological veterinary products in the country.

It is worth noting historically, therefore, in the context of the legislation that in 1961 it was the Menzies government that made CSL a statutory authority. When I was chairman of the public accounts committee we conducted some investigations into the affairs of the organisation, and the sad fact was that lack of capital was always a fundamental problem holding back the development of what was otherwise a well worthwhile organisation.

Whilst CSL's focus was the manufacture and supply of pharmaceutical products, provision was also made at this time for limited commercial use of any excess manufacturing capability. CSL has since evolved into a primarily commercial operation. Changes to the CSL Act between 1980 and 1985 placed the organisation on a commercial profit-making basis. These changes also allowed the establishment of subsidiaries, joint ventures and partnerships.

CSL now manufactures and markets a wide range of pharmaceutical and veterinary products both in Australia and overseas and has a wide range of connections of a research and development nature with various foreign companies which are assisting them in this objective. In 1990, CSL was made a corporation with its own board of directors. Since then it has operated largely on a commercial footing.

By any measure CSL has been an Australian success story. The coalition's longstanding policy even prior to 1990 has been to privatise CSL so that it would have the advantages of being off-budget in the true sense of the term and have the capacity of attracting greater capital, which has always been one of its major shortcomings.

The company is now export oriented and has a research development division. It is based at Parkville in Victoria, it employs 1,200 people and has branches in each mainland state. It is awaiting the completion and accreditation of a major advanced blood fractionation plant at Broadmeadows which will make it amongst the world's most up-to-date facilities. CSL has assets of $240 million and sales in 1992-93 exceeded $170 million, an increase of $10 million on the previous financial year. In 1992-93 net profit rose by 42 per cent to $13.8 million, up from $9.7 million in 1991-92.

In the 1992-93 budget the government announced its intention to fully privatise CSL Ltd subject to CSL remaining under independent Australian control. As far as the coalition is concerned, this decision is long overdue.

The CSL Sale Bill which we are debating is therefore very important to see the interaction between the capacity to float off this organisation and ensuring the national interest. Preparations for CSL's public float involve the due diligence process, a public awareness campaign and, ultimately, the launch of the float. The due diligence process involves examining CSL's operations to provide potential investors with a complete picture of the company's financial position and future prospects. This also allows investment bankers to form a view about an appropriate price for the sale of shares as the basis for a prospectus inviting the community at large to invest in CSL.

In this connection I am concerned that the government clarifies CSL's contingent liability post-sale in relation to certain claims which may arise against the company. CSL's own insurance company, Coselco, with reserves of $30 million, carries CSL's product liability risk, which it reinsures wherever possible. In relation to new products and some existing products, Commonwealth liability will cease on sale of the company. However, CSL is still negotiating with the government on some outstanding indemnification issues relating to some vaccines and products distributed pre-sale. These negotiations are expected to be completed prior to CSL's sale. In fact, they must be completed prior to sale.

I believe that as part of the due diligence process there should be a thorough audit of all conceivable claims against CSL. There is the question as to who will bear long-term liability for an unknown number of claims which may arise in relation to numerous drugs and vaccines. It is essential that this issue is clarified prior to sale and that the prospectus gives as accurate a picture as possible of CSL's contingent liability in respect of such claims.

Currently, liability rests with the Commonwealth in relation to claims against CSL arising from a number of its products, including Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a fatal brain disease linked to the use of a drug manufactured by the company; AIDS contracted from infected blood products manufactured by CSL some years ago; the side effects of pertussis vaccine, a component of triple antigen injections, which vaccinates against whooping cough; and hepatitis infection.

At present, risks relating to these drugs cannot be insured or completely covered on the open market. Therefore, the issue is real in terms of the actual value of CSL. I am advised that it is intended that the Commonwealth indemnity in relation to these diseases will continue after the sale of the company, although this matter has still to be settled.

The Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a rare brain disorder which has affected some participants in the Australian human pituitary hormone program. The fertility drug human pituitary gonadotrophin, or HPG, was manufactured by CSL. Between 1967 and 1985 about 2,100 Australians were supplied with cadaver derived pituitary hormones. One-thousand five-hundred women were treated for infertility and 600 children were treated for short stature, or dwarfism. HPG was recalled in 1985 when authorities decided it was too dangerous.

CJD is a disease of the central nervous system which causes dementia and muscle wastage and can exist in someone's system for up to 30 years before becoming active. Regrettably, there is no diagnostic test, nor at this stage any known cure.

As of yesterday, there were 21 writs lodged in the Victorian Supreme Court, of which three were by husbands of deceased participants in this program and 18 were by recipients of both HPG and HGH. Many writs relate to stress associated with fear of contracting CJD following the taking of growth hormone or follicle stimulating drugs. As I said, this fear could exist for 30 years.

As of May, four Australian women treated with HPG while being treated for infertility have died. At least one person in my electorate was treated with HPG, as a consequence of which she and her family have suffered considerable anguish. She does not know whether or not she is infected, and nobody can tell her.

In March this year I made representations to the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, on the matter. My colleague the shadow finance minister, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) has also drawn attention to the link between CJD and the administering of HPG. As a result of our efforts, the government belatedly announced an inquiry in May this year into CJD and the use of pituitary derived hormones in Australia.

The government has also accepted that its present indemnity with respect to CJD claims will continue after the public float and will be reflected in an agreement between the CSL and the Commonwealth. As I stated earlier, this agreement has not yet been completed and it should be tabled in the parliament. I believe Senator Richardson has given an undertaking to this effect and that this indemnity will be referred to in the prospectus for the CSL sale.

It must be understood, however, that it is likely that more CJD claims, particularly for trauma, will come forward, possibly for as long as 50 years. If successful, such claims could obviously reduce the long-term benefits of the sale of CSL.

I am also advised it is intended that the Commonwealth retain post-sale liability for claims against CSL for the contraction of AIDS as a result of treatment with contaminated blood products. In the mid-1980s, CSL was sued for compensation by haemophiliacs who contracted AIDS following treatment with blood products such as clotting agents used to treat their condition. CSL was also sued by a number of women who contracted AIDS following sexual intercourse with such men. However, I am informed that the risk of further claims against CSL for AIDS is not high due to improved screening processes. I am also advised that CSL has asked the Commonwealth to continue indemnity post-sale. I am informed that it is intended the Commonwealth indemnity also be extended to cover post-sale claims against CSL for hepatitis infection. Again, this needs to be clarified and codified.

The situation with respect to liability for pertussis vaccine is more complex. Pertussis vaccine is a component of the triple antigen injection or DPT—diphtheria-pertussis-tetanus injection—which vaccinates against whooping cough. In the mid-1970s it was suggested that the pertussis vaccine may be associated with permanent brain damage. Since then the side-effects of pertussis vaccine have remained a subject of controversy in medical circles.

Pertussis vaccine has been accused of causing cases of sudden infant death syndrome, leukemia, multiple sclerosis and other disorders. It is not for me to judge whether pertussis vaccine has such side effects. But I think it makes the point, however, that the issue is very much open and no final determination has been made.

What I am concerned about, however, is the liability of the government and CSL post-sale, with respect to liability, should any such claims against CSL succeed. Currently, proceedings have been initiated in the Supreme Court of New South Wales against a doctor who administered pertussis vaccine. The case, which alleges that brain damage resulted from administration of the vaccine, will be heard later this year or early next year. There are two other claims against doctors who administered the vaccine in New South Wales and one in Victoria which are likely to come forward in the near future. There are also three cases running in Queensland.

CSL was and is the distributor of pertussis vaccine. It is quite possible that the doctors involved in these claims will join action against the supplier. All claims are in relation to brain damage and are for amounts of between $3 million and $4 million each. There are an unknown number of such cases Australia-wide. Once the cases currently before the courts receive publicity, one can reasonably presume that undoubtedly others will come forward. There could be hundreds of people involved, as Australia endeavoured to vaccinate every child.

I am advised the proposal is that the government will retain its current liability post-sale for pertussis vaccine distributed pre-sale, and that CSL will accept liability for product distributed following the sale. I am also advised that, in relation to pertussis vaccine, the Commonwealth currently indemnifies claims up to an amount of $1 million and above $25 million per claim. The extent to which any successful claim exceeds $1 million is covered by the insurance policy—$1 million being the excess payable on the insurance cover. The limit of this cover is $25 million per claim, after which the Commonwealth again becomes liable. This issue must be given proper consideration, codified and presented clearly in the CSL prospectus, as it could well be a significant area of future litigation.

CSL has also distributed pluserix MMR, a vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella. Last year the government was asked to establish an inquiry into the possible links between pluserix MMR, which has now been banned,

SPEECH.PARA: and cases of brain damage and meningitis in children. Pluserix MMR was withdrawn by Australian health authorities in May 1991 because of links with meningitis. I am advised that there is no plan for the government to indemnify CSL for claims in relation to pluserix MMR because this is currently reinsurable. CSL will therefore cover itself against such claims.

PARA.TAB: There is another group called the HIB vaccines. The haemophilus influenza type B, or HIB, is a leading cause of meningitis and epiglotitis in children. HIB vaccines are relatively new vaccines administered to babies over two months old and I am advised that CSL has distributed HIB vaccines.

Last year the company entered into a joint venture with Merck, Sharpe and Dohme and Merck & Co., USA, to develop a new range of vaccine combinations. One of these combinations will involve combining CSL's triple antigens with Merck, Sharpe and Dohme supplied hepatitis B and HIB vaccine components. HIB vaccines have been accused of side effects such as increased susceptibility to infectious disease. I understand that CSL currently has insurance cover for HIB and has not asked the government to indemnify it against any claims arising from HIB vaccines.

There are, of course, two sides to this debate about the benefits of vaccines. In relation to pertussis vaccine, CSL has stated that both the medical and legal evidence shows there is no increased risk of children who receive the pertussis vaccine developing either acute or chronic neurological diseases.

CSL has an outstanding reputation. It is constantly monitoring and refining the quality of its products, and this certainly should be kept in mind. Against this, CSL has conceded that there are as yet no perfect vaccines and that every vaccine has some small incidence of side effects. The point in relation to liability surely is this: vaccination is continuing; any side effects of vaccines may not become apparent for up to 20 or 30 years; and litigation in relation to alleged side effects is an expanding field, particularly in the United States, but seemingly here in Australia as well. My sole concern in this debate is that the government take all such cases into account when it determines outstanding indemnification issues prior to the sale of CSL.

I am advised that the health minister is yet to approve Commonwealth indemnification for post-sale judgments against CSL arising from the above vaccines and products, although he has given certain assurances in relation to CJD. I would enjoin both Senator Richardson and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) to do their utmost to ensure that all outstanding issues of liability are addressed properly prior to the float.

The government's indemnification with respect to certain CSL products such as CJD is currently a full indemnification, whereas its indemnification, say, in relation to pertussis vaccine, is clearly different. I am advised that the government will be asked to indemnify CSL post-sale along the lines I have indicated for various products.

The opposition believes government has a clear duty to spell out the limits of its liabilities with respect to all products as this could amount to a continuing open chequebook indemnification of CSL in the event of a series of adverse judgments against the company. The government must also ensure that potential share purchasers are informed of the situation regarding liability in the sale prospectus. In short, the government must spell out exactly what it and CSL will and will not be liable for.
The opposition will be moving an amendment dealing with this issue, as well as with the issue of employee shareholding. I therefore move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House calls on the Government to ensure that all issues of contingent liability are properly assessed, addressed and declared prior to the float of CSL Ltd and that the Board and management of CSL Ltd encourage broad employee shareholding in CSL Ltd".

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to the method of sale. The government's decision to sell 100 per cent of its shares in CSL, announced in the 1992-93 budget, stipulated a five per cent limit on individual foreign shareholding. This was confirmed in the last budget. Legislation before the House addresses the issue of CSL remaining under Australian control by means of certain national interest provisions.

PARA.TAB: The bill limits the voting rights of significant foreign shareholders with regard to appointment, replacement and removal of company directors. It requires that CSL remain incorporated in Australia, and that the company's chairman and two-thirds of its board are Australian citizens. These provisions will ensure that CSL remains under the direction of an Australian controlled board. The bill also requires that CSL's head office and principal fractionation activities be located in Australia so that we remain independent of overseas suppliers.

Under the heading `National Interest Provisions', the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) also outlined arrangements for the sale of CSL shares. At the point of sale there will be a limit of five per cent on individual shareholdings, domestic or foreign; an aggregate limit of 15 to 20 per cent on foreign shareholdings; and preference for individuals and institutions over corporate shareholders.

This represents a substantial watering down of the government's position on foreign ownership as stated in the last two budgets. In fact, as soon as CSL shares are traded on the stock exchange, foreigners will be able to acquire more than five per cent individually and more than 15 to 20 per cent in aggregate. In reality, the limitations on foreign shareholdings as such will apply only to the initial float.

Australian control of CSL will be preserved only by the restrictions on the composition of the CSL board and the general provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act. The opposition believes this dilution of government policy on foreign ownership in this case is perhaps sensible. However, I wonder why the government is placing conditions on the method of float which will be superseded immediately the initial sale is over.

Theoretically, this temporary limitation on foreign ownership could result in the Commonwealth losing potential revenue from the sale of CSL. This would seem to be a face-saving exercise, allowing the government to represent itself as keeping its word to limit individual foreign shareholdings to five per cent. In reality, however, I believe most of the interest in the float of CSL will be domestic in any case.

I believe it would be better, if the method by which shares in CSL are allocated is to be prescribed, to provide for some employee shareholding. The opposition believes the ownership of shares involving corporate ownership, in the sense of shareholdings owned by employees, is a matter of fundamental importance which regrettably has not been adequately covered publicly by the government in documentation to date. Provision for employee share purchases in government asset sales has been addressed on a case by case basis, taking into account union and employee concerns.

I note that the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer on this legislation makes no mention of employee shareholding in relation to CSL. I also note an answer given by Senator McMullan, representing the Minister for Finance, to a question on notice in the Senate. He stated that, as at 30 August 1993, the government had taken no decisions with regard to an employee share scheme or other arrangements. That is why I mentioned this question of employee shareholding as part of our amendment.

I believe that in the lead-up to this float CSL management should fully exploit the opportunity to allow CSL employees to obtain a stake in their own company. I am advised that the CSL board has taken an in-principle decision in favour of an employee share scheme and has referred the issue to CSL management. In this connection, I note with approval that CSL's most recent staff newsletter states that at the appropriate time—whenever that may be—staff will be advised about special arrangements being made for their acquisition of shares. I am also advised that as yet there has been no decision on allocation policy, although DIR guidelines require an equitable allocation of shares among employees. Unlike the government, the opposition believes passionately that employees should be encouraged to take a stake in their company. Accordingly, I have moved an amendment to that effect.

I now wish to make some comments in regard to CSL's research capability. Last year the company made a 35 per cent increased investment in research and development, from $14 million to $19 million. However, I believe that CSL should have an even greater research capability if it wants to be more than merely a bit player in the megabucks international pharmaceutical industry. Presently CSL would have a net value of approximately $200 million to $300 million. As I said, it is a very small player in terms of its international competitors. As CSL's managing director, Dr Brian McNamee, said in the Bulletin earlier this month:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not in the discovery end of the business. We're strong in development and strong in collaboration with companies and academic institutes.

It is worth noting that Victoria has three private research companies doing state-of-the-art research, including AMRAD, which will be floated in the next two years.I believe there could be a potential advantage in linking CSL's production capability with a research based company such as AMRAD. I believe that the two have already discussed the possibility of collaborative projects. However, this is a practical issue and its future will be determined by market forces.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the opposition, I wish CSL the very best of luck with this privatisation. There is no doubt that it is an outstanding organisation and it is worth noting that Dr McNamee has established an excellent standard of administration of the company. In 1991 CSL received the Australian Business magazine's best government business enterprise award for being the best performer among all government business enterprises in the country.

As I said, in recent years CSL has opened a new penicillin dispensing and packaging facility and a new animal vaccine plant. This new $200 million blood fractionation plant at Broadmeadows, towards which the Commonwealth contributed $150 million, is highly capital intensive and is a world leader in its class. The plasma products produced will represent half of CSL's revenues.

CSL has developed strategic alliances involving more than 70 licences, agreements and deals with drug companies and local research centres, including SmithKline Beecham, Merck Sharp & Dohme, Cutter Laboratories, Biotech Australia and Hoechst. CSL's transition to privatisation has been arguably the smoothest yet for a government enterprise, especially when we are looking at a field where its record so far has been less than outstanding. It has been consistently profitable in recent years, and this is in large part due to the efforts of the management and staff of the company. I congratulate them all on this achievement.

CSL now has a new outlook for the future, and with that it must have a new culture. This legislation will remove CSL from administrative and legislative requirements of GBEs, to enable sale and to protect certain employee entitlements. The actual timing of the float is expected to be around March or April 1994, depending on the timing of other major stock market floats.

The coalition has consistently initiated and led the debate on the need for the privatisation of government assets, including the CSL. There is no reason for the government to own a pharmaceutical company. However, it is clearly the responsibility of government to ensure that the facilities remain in Australia to provide a range of drugs so that the health of this nation and its people can be both strengthened and protected well into the future.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been made clear in not only the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) but also in the speech of the shadow minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), during the second reading debate that the purpose of this bill is to facilitate the sale of CSL Ltd—formerly Commonwealth Serum Laboratories—and to facilitate the change in ownership from government to private ownership. It puts in place measures that are designed to safeguard the national interest and also to protect some of the entitlements that staff have accrued whilst they have been in the employ of CSL.

PARA.TAB: It is with mixed feelings that I enter this debate because, in past debates in this place, I have placed on record my opposition to the sale of CSL. I remember that in 1990, when CSL was converted to a public company, I spoke of the fear that I and some of my colleagues had that conversion to a public company was a precursor to CSL's eventual sale. That has now been proved right on the basis of the decision made in the budget of 1992.

Having said that, when I look around I do not seem to see too many fellow travellers, so I have to accept that the inevitable will happen later in this financial year. When I have entered into these debates the reaction of speakers on the other side of the House has been interesting. Back in 1990 they well and truly used the opportunity to push the privatisation barrow, with CSL being used as an example.

I have to say that I was impressed by the attitude of the honourable member for Bradfield to the debate today. I think he covered some important things that need to be looked at in the process that is being put in place for the sale of CSL. I think that they are things that the government will have to take on board. I do agree with him that it is very important to Australia, very important to the development of an Australian pharmaceutical industry, that we have CSL as a main player that builds on the strengths that it has developed since it came into being in 1916, that builds on the strengths that abound in a number of areas of research within Australia.

Towards the end of his speech the honourable member mentioned AMRAD. I think that from time to time we need to remind people in this place that not everything that occurred under the stewardship of the previous Victorian government turned sour. AMRAD was well and truly encouraged in the early years of the Cain government and is very much a success and recognised as such. It is very important that not only AMRAD but also CSL and others that are the players in developing a pharmaceutical industry use the strengths that abound as a result of that research effort. Those strengths abound in actually a very small sector of Melbourne, around the Parkville region, where there is a concentration of a number of research institutes that do work with pharmaceuticals and biotechnology.

Later in my speech I want to mention government policies that have been very important in developing and strengthening Australia's pharmaceutical industry. It is appropriate in the context of this debate, with CSL hopefully, whether it transfers from public to private ownership, remaining very much a successful entity in that development.

The honourable member for Bradfield also outlined some of the very important things in which CSL has been involved. Of course, it started for obvious reasons. Australia was isolated during the First World War. There was a need that we should not be at the mercy of other nations for our vaccines and sera. Therefore, right from the start serving the national interest was always very important for CSL.

CSL went on, as is well known, to develop and be involved in things that were specifically Australian—problems such as developing anti-venoms to a number of Australian pests. In 1923, CSL was only one of four laboratories in the world which produced insulin. In 1944, the work and efforts of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories meant that Australia became the first nation in the world to be able to supply its civilian population with penicillin.

This national interest objective was confirmed in 1961 when CSL became a statutory authority. The charter specifically mentioned that it should deal with issues that were in the national interest. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, as I have said earlier, mentioned a number of positive things about CSL in his second reading speech. He made one comment that I have a little difficulty in agreeing with. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The public float of CSL will enable it to achieve this potential and will release the Commonwealth from its incongruous position of being owner, as well as customer and regulator of the company.

I do not believe the Commonwealth's three roles should have impinged on what was occurring with CSL in its association with the wider pharmaceutical industry and the PBS. I think the things which had been done, such as making it a public company and the different arms-length ways of regulating, were sufficient.

PARA.TAB: As I said, one of the questions asked is: why does the Commonwealth need to own a pharmaceutical company? We can then answer: why should it not own a pharmaceutical company? Why should it not be involved in something that is very successful? The intriguing thing about most of those companies that are put forward for transfer from public to private ownership is that, in the main, they are fairly successful going concerns. We do not put up too many dud companies for that sort of sale. If we did that, we would not attract purchasers. So I think we should be in the business of working on the successes of a number of government concerns, recognising that those government business enterprises in their genesis operated in the national interest and developed in areas where the private sector, in those days, would not develop, such as telecommunications, postal services and airline services.

The other thing that should be said is that there is a return to budget. A number of figures have been quoted earlier in the debate as to the profits of the company and also the return to the Commonwealth by way of dividend. I recognise that, especially over the last few years, CSL has been very much involved in developing an international outlook. There has been more recognition of the potential for export sales. If we look now at CSL's revenue, we can see that over 10 per cent of it comes from export sales and there are plans for extending this in the future.

The international division of CSL is currently looking at establishing itself in Europe and North America, with a view to developing niche markets for biologically based products manufactured in Australia. During the past year, CSL has been responsible for investing over $18 million in new R&D. CSL has modern procedures in place to identify new products for development and manufacture. CSL is developing those processes to select opportunities which give it a strong market position without many competitors in the regions and markets that it is looking to be involved in.

In talking about those new processes for developing and identifying new product, CSL in the past had perhaps fallen into the habit of reacting to problems as they came along and reacting within what it thought was the limit of its capacity to tackle those problems. Now it is becoming much more outward looking—looking at the potential of what it is involved in and being very pro-active.

CSL is a major employer. It employs some 1,200 Australians. I have mentioned that its headquarters are based in Melbourne in Parkville. In the electorate of Calwell in the suburb of Broadmeadows—which is the neighbouring electorate to my electorate of Scullin—a plasma products facility is to open shortly. That is a very sophisticated and state-of-the-art facility. Before the sale of the company, the Commonwealth and CSL will have to come to an agreement about placing the ownership of that facility in the company's hands.

If one looks at CSL's performance, one sees the need within the pharmaceutical industry for a very interventionist industry policy by government. If one flicks through its statements, one can see that it takes advantage of the 150 per cent tax concession on research and development, and that is important. It is important that there be encouragement not only in this sector of industry, but also right across the board. Looking at the health of the industry overall, it has to be understood that I do not approach this on the basis that public ownership is the only type of intervention at which we should be looking.

Over the last decade there has been much debate which seems to be based on the notion that when we examine options for economic development one that we should perhaps shy away from is an interventionist type of government policy. Following the deregulation of the 1980s and the excesses that followed, more people are perhaps now realising that government policies which take an overtly interventionist approach are perhaps what we should be returning to.

If we look at the pharmaceutical industry, we see that one of the most successful of the industry policies at the moment is the factor F scheme. That scheme means that the government, with its pricing controls through the PBS, has been able to involve itself in encouraging Australian drug manufacturers to develop wider plans within the industry. However, one problem that should be recognised is that because of the success of the PBS pricing mechanisms, which mean that Australian drug prices are about 50 or 60 per cent of the world average, drug manufacturers in Australia have quite rightly said that that well and truly acts as a disincentive for them to be players within Australia.

The factor F scheme has meant that spending by pharmaceutical companies on research and development decisions to increase manufacturing in Australia are then taken into account when making pricing decisions for pharmaceutical products. The companies which agree to increase Australian operation in respect of value added exports, value added domestic sales, and research and development are given payments representing notional price increases in the pharmaceutical products they manufacture.

In the financial year 1991-92, the government was able to grant price increases in the order of $26 million to the nine pharmaceutical companies then participating in the scheme. This was in return for more investment in manufacturing, research and development by these firms. The results of this scheme have been quite astounding. The latest Auditor-General's report into the administration of the factor F scheme summarised the outcomes on page 5 of that document. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the first stage, factor F companies were expected to increase Australian pharmaceutical activity by $860 million, comprising $533 million export sales, $211 million in domestic sales and $117 million in research and development.

Most importantly, the analysis of these figures indicates that the scheme has probably led to the creation of 470 jobs within the industry and a retention of something like 390 jobs. I think that is the important thing. As the report of the audit office indicates, those figures are something like 10 per cent of the current work force within the industry.

PARA.TAB: We are now starting to see, as the factor F scheme well and truly has an effect, a turnaround in the balance of trade on pharmaceutical items. That will be important right through the 1990s as that becomes even more significant. Based on the present figures and estimates, there will be slight increases in imports over the next few years. But that will be well and truly offset by rapid increases in the amount of exports. Later in this decade, this will lead to not only that continuing rapid increase in exports but also a diminution of the necessity for imports on the basis of import replacement. I think that that is dramatic.

The only major competitors in our region are the Japanese companies. Therefore, at the moment within the region, purchasers have two locations that they can consider for their regional manufacturing operations—and of course factor F is putting in place a mechanism that ensures that Australia can get its fair share of that type of development. As these things continue, I think it is important that not only in pharmaceutical industries but in wider industry policy development we not be too coy about saying that government has a role and that government can set in place mechanisms that assist the orderly development of those industries.

If we look at the annual report of the CSL, we see another mechanism the government has put in place that I think really needs to be recognised. I refer to cooperative research centres. CSL has become involved again on the basis of its strengths within the biotechnology pharmaceutical community. CSL became a foundation member of the biopharmaceutical research centre, which is a CSL program focused on development of biopharmaceuticals. Again, when we look at those types of mechanisms, we have to recognise the importance of the totality of the government's involvement.

In conclusion, I recognise—as I did in 1990—Brian McNamee's role in the development of the CSL. I believe that we have seen, in what has happened since he has been there, a great development of what is truly a great company. I am sure that, even if it goes out of public ownership, it will continue to be a great company. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon, in discussing the privatisation proposal of the CSL in the CSL Sale Bill, I want to focus on the question that was raised by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), earlier in the debate, namely, the potential liability of CSL for an unfortunate tragedy which has caused considerable concern and hardship to a number of Australian women.

PARA.TAB: A near neighbour of mine, whilst living in Britain with her husband who had been transferred there with his job, developed suddenly and without warning a fatal brain disease which is known as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. She died in 1990. It appeared the reason that she had died was that she had been treated in Australia with a drug known as human pituitary derived gonadotrophin, otherwise known as HPG. The drug was manufactured by CSL. It was administered under a Commonwealth program which was run by a committee of experts.

The connection between the fertility drug treatment and the death of the woman with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease—CJD—was made because at the time she was living near Oxford where there was a world authority on this particular disease who knew the connection between the drug and the disease. The husband of the woman contacted me and informed me of her very untimely death, which had left him a widower and left his two daughters motherless. He asked whether, on his behalf, I could investigate what was known in Australia about this drug and its connection with the disease.

I wrote to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in July of 1991 and asked them for information: the number of cases of women who had been treated with this drug, the number of deaths, the known connections and whether there was any treatment. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories wrote back to me, confirmed the basic facts and provided me with an extract from the Australian and New Zealand Journal of Medicine detailing that in Australia there had been one fatality in 1988 of a woman in Adelaide who had been treated with this fertility drug. The second fatality was the woman whom I had known.

It was clear that in 1991 CSL and the Commonwealth health authorities were not aware of the second fatality, Jenny Halford. As a result, I alerted the health authorities and, indeed, raised in this parliament in November 1991 the matter of the second Australian fatality. The woman had been treated with a drug manufactured by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, administered under a Commonwealth health program, and had died because the drug had been contaminated.

This drug was being produced from pituitary glands of dead bodies. Apparently, for some time there had been what was called the harvesting of pituitary glands from dead bodies in Australia. From those pituitary glands, the human fertility drug HPG was manufactured and also another drug used to treat dwarfism in children called human growth hormone.

As a result of deaths overseas, the program was suspended in 1985 and there has been no treatment since then. In relation to Jenny Halford's death, the time between treatment with the fertility drug and death was about 15 years. It occurred to me that, if women were still being treated with that drug until 1985 and between the treatment and the onset of the disease and ultimate death—for this is an incurable disease, not treatable and always fatal—there could be other Australian women who were and still are at risk. I urged the Commonwealth department of health to take immediate steps to notify the women involved and to offer them counselling. I also urged the government to look at the question of compensation to that family who had suffered the loss of a mother and a wife as a result of this treatment.

As a result of the information that I have been able to glean from questions on notice and answers given, the department of health suspended the program in 1985 and informed doctors that there was a possible link between the drug HPG and CJD. The department took the view that doctors should notify their patients and that this would be an acceptable way of ensuring that patients were informed about the risk. Although the department wrote again to doctors in 1990, by June 1992 only 352 of the 1,500 or so women who were potentially at risk had actually been notified. What was clear was that, although the department had written to doctors, the information was not getting from the doctors to the patients concerned.

I repeatedly requested in this House, through the media, and to the people concerned, that the department directly notify the women because to get onto this program they needed the approval of the Commonwealth government health authority. The authority had all the details of those who had been treated. In answers to questions that were provided to me, I was told that the doctors were given information and asked to exercise their clinical judgment in relation to notification and counselling. In answers to questions on 7 July 1992, the health minister said that, in each case, medical practitioners provided counselling as appropriate according to their clinical judgment. It appeared to me that the clinical judgment of some of these doctors had been not to notify the women at all because only 352 women had been notified of this potential risk.

It was also important to notify the women because it was conceivable that there had been other Australian deaths. The department had found out about the second death only because I happened to know the woman. It was conceivable that other Australian women had died from CJD without it ever being diagnosed. That is why it was important to contact them directly.

It was also important to contact them directly because the balance of medical opinion is that a person with the CJD agent can pass it on through tissue or organ donations. There is also a suggestion that it can be passed on through blood donations. Potentially, Australian women who had been treated with this drug and were therefore at risk, could unknowingly donate blood or organs and pass the disease on. That is why it was very important that they knew that they should not take the risk of passing on the disease.

In answer to further questions on notice, which I received on 25 June 1992, I was informed that the batches that were supposed to be contaminated could not be isolated. The Commonwealth Department of Health regarded all batches as potentially infected, which meant that all the 1,500 women were potentially at risk. It also appeared that it was not until 1990 that the blood banks of Australia were told that they should not take blood donations from women who had been treated with HPG.

The program was cancelled in 1985 because it was known that there was a potential risk, but it took five full years before the blood banks were notified that people treated with HPG should be excluded, and HPG was printed as an exclusion for potential blood donors. We should bear in mind that the two fatalities had occurred after an interval of 15 years. So not only was there a large number of women at immediate risk, but for some time thereafter there was a risk of passing the disease on through organ or blood donations.

On 11 May 1993, Senator Richardson announced that there would be an inquiry. I welcome that inquiry. It is to run for about 12 months and we expect it to report next year. We hope that it gets to the bottom of this saga. The inquiry is to be undertaken by Professor Margaret Allars, the Associate Professor of Law at Sydney University.

In relation to further questions that I put on notice, and which were answered on 8 September 1993—I asked how many deaths there had been in Australia—the department was still maintaining that there had been only two deaths: Jane Allender in Adelaide in 1988, and Jenny Halford. We now know that there have been at least four deaths, including the death of Mrs Cummings in 1991. This was found out because her mother-in-law read an advertisement in a women's magazine and sought information from the Commonwealth Department of Health. It was years after Mrs Cummings' death that it was discovered that she had died from CJD as a result of fertility treatment. There is now known to be a fourth fatality, a woman in Perth in 1990.
