TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am tabling this report by the Schools Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training entitled Five to fifteen: reviewing the `compulsory' years of schooling at a turning point in Australia's development, much like the turning point the six Australian colonies faced a century ago. The federation debate was about nation building, and about creating a form of government which would generate wealth. It focused on how to minimise disputes over the crucial economic issues of the day such as railway gauges and tariff barriers. Australians are still debating the federation puzzle: how to achieve a system of government which ensures the administrative flexibility provided by regional diversity without losing the efficiencies which accompany a national approach.

PARA.TAB: Our system of government still militates against the most effective use of national resources. Nevertheless, Australia faces the 21st century as a more open, efficient and equitable society than it was at federation. Its economy is integrating effectively into the global economy. Its values are shaped by a diversity of cultures. Its political culture emphasises equality of opportunity. If Australia is to become an economic leader in the Asia-Pacific region these characteristics must be further developed.

The Australians who will lead the nation in the next century are in school today. The intellectual skills and the human qualities of tolerance, enthusiasm and vision they will need to ensure Australia's prosperity are what the schools must be encouraging now. The Five to fifteen report produced by the Schools Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training which I am tabling today is a significant contribution to the national debate on how we reach these necessary goals.

During the last two years, the Schools Council has focused on the study of the `compulsory' years of schooling—the preparatory, reception or kindergarten years to year 10. Five to fifteen is the council's formal advice on future directions for these vital years of schooling. In tabling the report, I shall take the opportunity to outline the government's view of the role which schools can play in educating young people for their lives as citizens of an Australia entering its second century of nationhood.

In considering the proposals in the report, the Commonwealth recognises that school education is primarily a state responsibility. But this does not preclude a national approach with the states and Commonwealth cooperating to pool their experience and resources. It makes no sense for young Australians to continue to be the victims of arbitrary lines on maps drawn by 19th century surveyors commissioned to set colonial boundaries. The interests of Australia's children do not change when they cross the Murray River or the Nullarbor Plain. There are issues in school education which cannot be undertaken by the states acting separately, issues which require the leadership of the Commonwealth.

Over the past 20 years, the Commonwealth has assumed responsibility for ensuring educational equity across the country and between different student groups. In other words, the Commonwealth's proper role is to see that access to quality schooling is assured for every Australian child.

This is why the Commonwealth is now committed to a national strategy for equity in schools. The national strategy will not only enable each state and territory to influence the setting of national priorities for the direction of funding to equity programs; it will also enable all school systems and the Commonwealth to set targets for raising the educational performance of particular groups of educationally disadvantaged students and for monitoring and reporting the outcomes for such groups in relation to those of the general student population.

The realities of Australia's federal system mean that there will always be overlaps and confusion in the provision of educational services. But with goodwill between the states and Commonwealth they can be overcome. Indeed, they must be overcome if Australia is to build on the advantages of our excellent school systems.

Australia's schools are well placed to meet the challenge of educating citizens for the 21st century. Certainly, I join with the Schools Council in encouraging all teachers to explore management philosophies aimed at the continuing incremental improvement of all aspects of their work. But it is important to emphasise that this change must be incremental, for Australia's teachers are already doing a good job. Indeed, the world at large recognises the quality of their work. The 1993 UNICEF report The progress of nations found that Australia—in company with Finland, Japan and Sweden—has the highest levels of primary school education in the world. Moreover, the doubling of retention rates during the last decade means that almost all children are remaining in education for at least 12 years.

Yet Australia's schools can be better. They can and will be better as our understanding of the intellectual disciplines of education improve. In fact, they must be better as there is no doubt that today's high standards will not be high enough for Australia in its second century of nationhood. This is why our industry is keen to see the general levels of school attainment rising and teachers becoming aware of the kinds of competencies and drive for life-long learning which will have to be demonstrated by their students when they become the work force of the future.

Of course, not everyone supports the emphasis being placed in today's schools on the preparation of young people for the work force. The opposition, for example, does not. Its spokesman in this place refers to such vocational preparation as `instrumentalisation'. He accepts the notion of a `large, permanently unemployed work force', and says that young people `are unlikely to get jobs'. In fact, he demands that these young people `be educated for rational leisure'.

These nostrums constitute nothing more than a litany of despair, a manifesto of defeat which this government absolutely rejects. The intellectual laziness that it represents has no place in the government's vision of schools education for the 21st century. We will not abandon the prospect of employment for our school graduates, and we will spare no effort in ensuring that their education equips them, as well as it possibly can, for all the dimensions of adult citizenship—including that of employment.

It is through the work of organisations such as the Schools Council that we can hope to reach these necessary goals. Five to fifteen does not cover all the elements of `compulsory' schooling which need to change to ensure that young people are comprehensively prepared for the 21st century. But the report does make some practical suggestions for improvement in a number of strategically important areas of school activity.

I support the report's emphasis on `explicit teaching' and its `outcomes based' approach to schooling. In a sense, the cooperative development within the Australian Education Council of the key competencies and the national curriculum profiles was a response to the demand for more explicit and transparent objectives being set for schooling.

Perhaps this is why one of the criticisms which have been levelled at the competencies and profiles is that they are merely monitoring tools designed to enable closer scrutiny of the schooling sector. Few have acknowledged the potential value to students themselves of having the explicit means by which they might monitor their own educational performance. Young people should know what is expected of them, and they should be encouraged to notice when they have learned something to realise that what has been learned is as important as what has yet to be learned.

Decisions as to whether or not the nationally cooperative trialling and further development of the curriculum statements and profiles will be re-established or not and, if they are, whether the key competencies will be taught and assessed within the context of the national curriculum framework will be taken at the forthcoming meeting of the Education Ministers Council in December. I hope that this meeting will see a resumption of the national collaborative process which has been so fruitful and resource effective in the gradual development of a national consensus on what Australian school children should know and be able to do.

The Schools Council makes the point that several of its recommendations—such as the continuation of the effort to eliminate unnecessary interstate differences in schooling arrangements—assume that national collaboration between the schools systems and between them and the Commonwealth will be maintained. I remain optimistic that this will be the case, if only because commonsense dictates that the nation's various education authorities cannot deny the fact that Australia is one nation, not a collection of squabbling principalities.

Certainly the Commonwealth acknowledges the concerns of groups as diverse as the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee that national collaboration not be abandoned. To answer their concerns the Commonwealth supports suggestions that the work being undertaken in various states and territories be reviewed at a national level by an independent and broadly representative body such as the Curriculum Corporation. The government also supports the Schools Council's view that it is desirable for schools to plan their curriculum and organise their teaching and learning in ways which ensure that the developmental needs of their students—in particular, those of young adolescents—are met.

In Five to fifteen, the Schools Council suggests that the traditional division of schooling into `primary' and `secondary' sectors can have the unintended consequences of muddying the focus on adolescents—who straddle both sides of that divide—and contributing to their transition problems. The council believes that additional effort needs to be made to ensure that there is more coherence, more continuity, between the curriculum at the different stages of schooling, and more integration across the different areas of the curriculum. The national curriculum profiles are an obvious means of achieving this kind of continuity.

While the `primary-secondary' divide remains, however, it is important that we ensure that these sectors are operating effectively. Following its election commitment, the government is undertaking a review of resource levels in government primary schools, with a particular focus on literacy. I am aware that my announcement of the review has been a matter for controversy amongst state administrations. However the Commonwealth's intention has been considerably strengthened by recent events in some states. The combined effects on public education of severe cost cutting and reductions in teacher numbers, of multiple school closures, of devolution, administrative downsizing and of the withdrawal of curriculum support services is as yet unknown.

However, the substitution by state systems of Commonwealth funding for their own expenditure is a cause for concern. There is no net value to schools when the Commonwealth provides supplementary funding to ensure equity and to improve quality in any state whose own cost cutting appears simultaneously to be weakening the very foundations of public education. The review of resource levels in government primary schools will enable us to address public concerns that the most fundamental and important stage of schooling—that of primary schooling—is being protected and adequately resourced.

The drastic reductions in funding that are occurring in some states make it difficult to assess the merit of other changes that are occurring simultaneously. The Commonwealth supports the continuing trend to devolve as much decision making as possible to the school—as long as the supports which schools need to undertake their additional management responsibilities are not simultaneously withdrawn. I believe that the Schools Council's recommendation for a study into the differing models of devolution and decentralisation which are being applied to schooling both in this country and overseas has considerable merit, and I shall consult relevant organisations and systems on the best way to pursue this matter.

The emphasis of Five to fifteen on the teaching of literacy is consistent with the government's educational priorities and the strengthening of literacy teaching in schools—especially those which have concentrations of disadvantaged students—remains a major objective for the implementation of the Australian language and literacy policy. Under this policy, the government has funded a large number of research and development projects. They include research into the successful literacy and learning practices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students at schools and at home; everyday literacy practices in and out of school in low socioeconomic communities; and the teaching, monitoring, assessment and reporting of literacy learning in the early years. In addition, the government has recently given the Australian Language and Literacy Council a reference on the education and professional development of teachers of literacy.

The status of our teachers and their professional development is at the heart of the Commonwealth's policies on school education. I therefore support the thrust of the recommendations in Five to fifteen on the initial education and professional development of teachers, and in particular I have already endorsed the Schools Council's suggestion that courses in primary school science be added to those which have been offered by the Commonwealth to enable teachers to renew their subject disciplines.

Teaching is a profession and must be recognised as such. This is why the Commonwealth has provided seed funding for the establishment of a peak professional body for teachers, the Australian Teaching Council. The council will ultimately enable the profession to take collective responsibility for raising teaching standards throughout the country.

The responsibility of the government to acknowledge and enhance the status of the teaching profession is also at the heart of the accord to advance the quality of teaching and learning which the Commonwealth concluded with the teaching profession earlier this week. The accord recognises the central role teachers play in schooling and sets out steps the signatories can play to further develop the skills and standing of the profession. It is a national initiative on an issue of national importance and demonstrates the Commonwealth's commitment to the entire spectrum of school education issues.

I commend the Schools Council for the work it has done during the past two years on the compulsory years of schooling, and on the preparation of Five to fifteen, the final report in the council's series on this stage of schooling. In this tabling statement, I have indicated some of the matters raised by the council which have the support of the government, and I shall be taking up with the council and others the details of specific recommendations.

Among its current references, the council has been asked to look at the ways in which children acquire knowledge and develop attitudes toward career and post-compulsory education and training options, Australia's economic system and its economic future. I expect a particularly stimulating report on these matters.

I wish to conclude with the government's vision of a school sector which adequately prepares young Australians for their lives as citizens and workers in the 21st century. It is one in which schools provide all their students with a high quality, broadly based education. It is one in which the business of the so-called `compulsory' years of schooling is to ensure that students acquire the necessary foundation knowledge and skills to equip them to take advantage of `post-compulsory' vocational and academic pathways. The most important of these are literacy and numeracy. The vision is also one in which, to quote the Schools Council:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the school has the wider task of developing in its students a range of social, ethical, cultural, physical and aesthetic skills and understandings appropriate to their stage of development and maturation.

This may seem like a tall order. But I am confident that the increasing professionalism of teachers and principals, and the unremitting quest of parents for the best education for their children, can make the vision a reality. The Commonwealth will continue to support their endeavours. I present the report of the Schools Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome this opportunity to say a few words this afternoon about the matters raised in the report Five to fifteen by the Schools Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. These remarks will necessarily be preliminary, given the fact that the report has only been available to me for a few hours today.

PARA.TAB: It is important when looking at the matters raised in the report to consider some of the issues surrounding education and schooling in Australia at present. There have in fact been a series of indications about the standards and performance of Australian students over the past decade to which this report directs itself in part. For example, in 1983-84 the International Association for Evaluation of Education Achievement conducted a study comparing the performance of students around the world.

This study, which, although 10 years old, is the most recent of its kind, revealed that the level of achievement of Australian 14-year-olds was far below that of students in Japan and significantly below that of students in a number of European countries, including some in eastern Europe. In 1988 the Australian Council for Educational Research found that only 77 per cent of year 9 students achieved the minimum reading competency required in adult society. The study also found that standards in spelling and certain mathematical skills had declined since 1980.

A recent report on literacy by a parliamentary committee documented the fact that up to 25 per cent of children leaving primary school were unable to read or write adequately. We also had an indication from the Australian Council for Adult Literacy in 1990 that an estimated one million Australian adults cannot read or write adequately. These are national concerns in relation to education.

TALK.START.PARA: —After 10 years of this government.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Goldstein points out, that is after 10 years of this government. On a recent occasion another speaker spoke about what he termed cultural literacy in Australia. He asked the question:

SPEECH.PARA: And how do Australian students compare when given similar questions about Australian heritage?
He said:
A survey conducted among 200 Melbourne undergraduates for Australia Week in February this year produced some alarming results.
Only a fifth of our University students could identify Patrick White as the author of the Australian novel Voss.
When asked to name just three famous Australian painters, from the great wealth of artistic talent this country has produced, only one in four was able to do so.
One quarter of students did not know that the Murray-Darling was the largest river system in the country.

Only eight percent of students could name an internationally acclaimed scientist—with students offering names such as, Barry Jones, Dick Smith and Professor Julius Sumner Miller instead of Florey, Burnet and Hargrave.

To be fair, as the first three owe their fame at least in part to television, and the second three are depicted on our currency, we can say that in the choice between the money or the box, the box won.
Under any circumstances these figures are unacceptable, but for a nation that has had 100 years of compulsory schooling they are alarming.

The speaker on that occasion was the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, the Hon. Bob Carr, and I think it points out, without drawing party political matters into this debate, that there is a concern across the spectrum for the standard of education in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In this latest report the government has published a collection of pious hopes and good intentions but the question remains: how much substance is there? For example, we are told that the teaching of science should be upgraded, yet the report also gives partial support to national curriculum profiles which, on all the evidence that has been provided by the scientific community in this country, would certainly lead to the demoralisation of science teaching. The report also recommends training teachers to deal with literacy problems, and in that regard these recommendations have come none too soon.

I cannot let pass some remarks which the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) made in his tabling statement in relation to the question of unemployment. He referred to remarks that I made in May about the prospect of there being a large, permanently unemployed work force in this country. I said that many young people—and the minister quoted me accurately—are unlikely to get jobs. I also mentioned the fact that education must take this into account. After I made those remarks in May there was a statement made by a minister in this government at no less important a place than the National Press Club on 30 June. This minister, not the minister at the table, the minister for schools—

TALK.START.PARA: —Another?
—but one of his colleagues, whom I will identify in a moment, in speaking on this issue, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is some downward movement in our unemployment rate, no matter how slow, no matter how high the absolute level, we can too easily be lulled into an uncritical belief that everything will come good eventually.
It's just a matter of time. After all we've been through recessions before and unemployment has always fallen back to its previous low level.
But that isn't true.
It hasn't.

This country, along with many others, has experienced a `ratchet' effect in economic cycles over the last twenty years. Since the early 1970s the unemployment rate has moved upward in a series of large steps.
Unemployment shoots up at the start of an economic downturn. Long-term unemployment shoots up a year later when the unemployed start crossing the definitional threshold of twelve months out of work.
Then, with economic recovery, starts a long, slow process of reducing the number of people out of work. But the numbers do not fall to the level which existed before the downturn.
This is especially the case for the long term unemployed who are the last to benefit from employment growth. The long term unemployed are hurt most by recession and helped least by recovery.
When the next downturn starts, the starting pool of unemployed is larger, and the whole process ratchets up another step.

The speaker on that occasion was none other than the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), a colleague of the minister at the table, who was admitting to the Australian people for the first time what others on this side of the House, including me, have been saying and what every Australian knows: that the prospect of long-term unemployment is something we will have to live with and work our way out of. We cannot simply snap our fingers and have jobs somehow materialise overnight.

PARA.TAB: In his statement at the press club, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training went on to say that he was not talking about the prospect of bringing unemployment down to under two per cent, or six per cent or even under 10 per cent—he was not going to put a figure on it—but that his proposals were something much less modest. If the minister at the table wishes to make what seem to me to be fairly petty debating points, he should at least get his story right with his senior minister.

I do not wish to take up the time of the House by debating all the matters raised in this report but I would like to mention the continuing fascination of some in education and in government, including the Schools Council, with the concept of competencies. The question is not so much whether we have this grand framework of competencies, but whether we have a school student population, and later a work force, which is competent. Nonetheless, as has been pointed out, there is a fixation in this country with some grand framework. Richard Sweet from the Dusseldorp forum said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: In continental Europe a long tradition of scholarly engagement in the study of learning at work has led to a strong concern for embedding process in the way in which vocational education policy and practice are developed.
He went on to say something about the obsession with structures. He said:
Here—
that is, in Australia—

we place little emphasis on process, but demonstrate almost an obsession with structures. The major focus of European interest in key qualifications, core competencies and the like is how these should be developed, not put into frameworks. There is far greater concern with how to ensure that apprentices and vocational education students actually learn in specific practical situations to plan, cooperate and solve problems than with putting these competencies into generalised multi-level frameworks that pose almost insurmountable problems in assessment.

Through his remarks on this report, the minister appears to be propagating the notion that we should have this centralised, top-down, bureaucratic structure in which a framework of competency is established for the entire nation and from which nobody in any part of the country can ever divert. If that is so, I would ask him how we will get the degree of flexibility in education and training in the secondary school levels, let alone in the vocational levels, that will lead to a skilled work force. The reality is that if we have that inflexibility, we will not achieve what we set out to achieve in providing adequate education and training in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are some other comments in this report to which I would like to refer. For example, the Schools Council recommends that there be some examination of the year 10 certificate in relation to a general statement about what schools have achieved. I note with some interest that earlier this year the board of studies of the minister for education in New South Wales, Virginia Chadwick, released a discussion paper on the future role of the school certificate which addressed the problem of reporting on skills at the year 10 level. Maybe that is an example which the Schools Council could look at in furthering this particular objective.

Interestingly, there were also some comments by the Schools Council in relation to assessment. In the debate about competencies, the national curriculum and assessment in Australia it seems that the aspect of that debate which has dropped out of consideration has tended to be assessment. If one goes to industry, one will hear the Business Council and similar groups say that they want some form of assessment whereby they can tell whether students have achieved levels of competence, skill, knowledge and learning so that they can guarantee, or say with some degree of accuracy, that when they take on students they will achieve a certain standard.

We could ask parents around this country what they want for their children. As the parent of primary school age children, I would answer this question myself. At least at that primary school level, I want to know that my children will leave school able to read fluently and able to write in a way which they understand and which someone else reading that writing can understand. I want to know that they have a knowledge of basic mathematical and numeracy concepts, such as addition, multiplication, the use of fractions and the like, and that they have some understanding of the history of Australia and the place in which they live.

That does not seem too modest an expectation to have of primary level schooling in Australia, let alone secondary level schooling. Yet when we look at the various studies which I quoted at the outset and a whole series of other studies in this country relating to this issue, we find that, sadly, that is not the case.

My final comment is in relation to the minister's remarks about teaching and the teaching accord. There is no doubt in my mind that, in order to continue to raise the level of expertise and skills and therefore the level of education in Australia, one must continue to work at giving every opportunity to teachers to raise their skills and competence. I do query, however, whether the accord—`accord' being a notion taken from industrial relations—is actually about achieving those educational outcomes or whether it is in fact something which has more to do with industrial relations.

I refer to the final chapter of Paul Kelly's book The End of Certainty, which many members of this House may have read—they may have read the index, at least, to see whether they cracked a mention. Kelly states that the five principles of the Australian settlement—of which he names the White Australia Policy, state paternalism and wage arbitration—were overtaken by the events of the 1980s and the early 1990s and that the future structure upon which society in Australia is to be judged will be according to principles different from those of the so-called Australian settlement.

The interesting fact in relation to education is that it seems to me that some of these aspects of the top-down bureaucratic structure still reflect state paternalism and not the degree of flexibility that we require. Some aspects of the language of the teaching accord—the minister can convince me otherwise—seem to be more about wage arbitration than education. There is a nice irony. If Kelly were correct in terms of those principles having been bypassed, the nice irony is that they may well still be part of the ruling notions which determine the future of education. As I said at the outset, I have had only a short time to look at this report. There are obviously other things which deserve careful consideration. I, along with the minister, commend the report to other members of this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to four bounty acts. In particular, the bill proposes amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 to continue bounty assistance on Australian book production until 31 December 1997 and to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 to introduce a new definition for `research and development' to limit eligibility of that factory cost, as well as to strengthen the ability of the Australian Customs Service to substantiate claims made under the scheme. It also proposes some minor technical amendments to the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 and the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985.

PARA.TAB: First, I will address the proposed amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986. Bounties have been paid on the production in Australia of certain books covered by the Florence agreement since 1969. As a signatory to the Florence agreement, Australia cannot impose tariffs or other charges on the importation of books of scientific, cultural or educational value. Bounty is paid on the local production of such books in order to assist the Australian printing industry to compete with overseas book printers.

The amendments proposed in this bill are the government's response to the Industry Commission's recommendations contained in its report No. 27 of 15 October 1992 on book production. In that report the Industry Commission commented that productivity improvements in book production appears to have more than offset the effects of the gradual reduction of assistance and that continued reduction of the bounty rate and other assistance is likely to maintain pressure to improve efficiency. The commission supported the continuation of the orderly reduction in assistance within the general program of tariff reductions announced by the government in March 1991.

In relation to bounty assistance, the commission's main recommendations were, first, that rates be reduced in four steps from the current 13.5 per cent to 4.5 per cent by 1997; secondly, that the present $500 minimum claim amount be replaced by a minimum publisher's production cost per production run of $3,700 per title with effect from 1 January 1994; and, thirdly, that the present arrangements, whereby either the publisher or a printer may claim bounty, remain unchanged.

The government has accepted all the commission's recommendations and this bill implements those recommendations in relation to bounty assistance by extending the life of the bounty to 31 December 1997 and annually phasing down bounty rates from the current 13.5 per cent to 4.5 per cent by January 1997. The bill also proposes to extend bounty eligibility to directories other than Australian telephone directories and timetables on the condition that they contain less than 30 per cent advertising and to specifically exclude company prospectuses from bounty eligibility as they are in a similar class of publications to annual reports and shareholders reports which are already excluded as they are unlikely to be printed offshore because of time restraints.

I will now address the amendments proposed to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984. The computer bounty is an important element of the government's policy for the computer industry, which for bounty purposes includes manufacturers of modems, multiplexers, microprocessors, computer subassemblies, electronic microcircuits and, since July 1991, printed circuit boards. The decision in 1990 to continue the computer bounty scheme, which resulted in the extension of the scheme until 31 December 1995, reflects a commitment by this government, and indeed this parliament, to encouraging increased development and use of computer equipment and microprocessor technology.

In 1992-93, the computer bounty program provided about $75 million of direct assistance to 927 registered manufacturing premises. The program is expected to provide $78 million to industry in 1993-94 and slightly lower levels in forward years with the adoption of the legislative changes proposed in this bill. On current trends, without either legislative or administrative changes, the budget outlays for this program are expected to be in the order of $88 million in 1993-94.

The amendments in particular introduce a definition of `research and development' to clarify and limit the eligible expenditure which might be included under this phrase. This proposed definition, together with the proposed amendment to the method of calculating value added by a manufacturer in section 6 of the act, expressly requires that, in order for expenditure on research and development to qualify for inclusion in a manufacturer's bountiable factory costs, the research and development must be likely to result in the manufacture of bountiable equipment within the bounty period; that is, by 31 December 1995.

There are two other substantive amendments to the Bounty (Computers) Act contained in this bill which are explained in greater detail in the explanatory memorandum to the bill. One is designed to strengthen the ability under the act to substantiate claims—clause 10 of the bill—by requiring bounty recipients to keep records and accounts which are relevant to claims for several years, in line with provisions in other bounty acts. The other introduces an administrative reform to allow interstate manufacturing operations to lodge consolidated claims across state and territory borders, thereby reducing administrative effort and costs for some claimants.

The measures contained in this bill which extend the operation of the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 until 31 December 1997 are expected to result in additional bounty payments as follows: $10.2 million in financial year 1993-94, commencing 1 January 1994; $19.2 million in financial year 1994-95;$17.2 million in financial year 1995-96; $13.2 million in financial year 1996-97; and $5.4 million in financial year 1997-98, finishing 31 December 1997.

The measures contained in this bill relating to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1986 which tighten the eligible bountiable costs definitions, and which strengthen the ability of the administrators of the scheme to substantiate claims made under it, are expected to result in budget savings in 1992-93 dollars as follows: $2.8 million in financial year 1993-94, commencing 1 November 1993; $13.8 million in financial year 1994-95; and $12.1 million in financial year 1995-96, ending 31 December 1995.

The measures contained in this bill relating to the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 and the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985 are all technical in nature and are expected to have no financial impact. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was putting before the debate was interrupted, it now appears that four Australian women have died from Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease as a result of treatment with the fertility drug HPG, manufactured by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. PARA.TAB: Indeed, it was only after this process of notification was stepped up that the Commonwealth became aware that two women had died and that they had not been accurately diagnosed as being sufferers of CJD. Even though they had died some years before, it was not until the process of notification was taken up that the Commonwealth became aware that they had been fatalities of this system. As a result—as may be expected—legal proceedings have been taken against CSL. The families of three of the women who have died have taken proceedings in the Supreme Court of Victoria. I ask honourable members

PARA.TAB: In relation to the Voyager debacle, for example, the Commonwealth spent a lot of time and money defending those claims in court. In the end it was forced to compensate the victims. In relation to this matter, the Commonwealth can either spend its money on lawyers or on the victims. It will not necessarily be any cheaper to spend the money on the lawyers; the Commonwealth will be paying whichever way it goes. As a matter of justice, it would be far more just and far more helpful to those who have suffered if the Commonwealth said that on this occasion its beneficence will be directed towards the victims, the families that have suffered the death and loss of a loved one, rather than the legal profession defending the claims.

I have taken up this matter with the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson). He wrote to me recently on the matter, telling me that, in relation to the proposed sale of CSL, the prospectus ought to refer explicitly to indemnity arrangements concerning the production of human pituitary hormones. He said that the Commonwealth currently indemnifies CSL against claims for damages arising from the use of products derived from human pituitary hormones. He stated that this indemnity will continue after the public float of the company and be reflected in an agreement between CSL and the Commonwealth. He said that he was advised that the sales prospectus, which is currently being drafted, will include specific references to this indemnity. The minister is saying that the Commonwealth will stand behind these claims. We would not want a situation where CSL was privatised and there was a prospect that these claims would be left defeated or barren in any judgment that might be awarded—if it comes to a judgment. The Commonwealth should be picking up the liability in this situation of privatisation.

I warmly commend the minister for taking that stand. I look forward to making sure that those arrangements are reflected in legal indemnity documents. They should be made clear, public and open before the privatisation goes ahead so that no-one is in any doubt about the situation. One may have expected CSL to be insured against incidents like this. I do not know what its insurance policy was, but I am concerned to ensure that, at the end of the day, those claims will not be defeated as a result of the privatisation. Those arrangements need to be put in place for the sake of justice and the concern of those 1,500 women who are at risk as a result of this terrible tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak on certain aspects of this matter not only as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health but also having had portfolio responsibility for the actual arrangements of the CSL. My colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) will speak on the actual sale arrangements and other such matters.

PARA.TAB: I begin firstly by saying that, while we have already effectively embraced the spirit of the comments made by the opposition in terms of its amendment, we do not see any reason for this amendment. We think that it could actually be misunderstood by some people. So rather than accepting the wording of this amendment we will reject that proposal and instead we will explain the situation as far as we can in relation to the matters raised by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) who moved the amendment. I want also to make some comments in relation to the matter raised by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) on the dreaded CJD and some of the issues that he has raised.

Firstly, on the general amendment, we do not think it is necessary and we consider that under the provisions contained in the Corporations Law the government is required to assess all costs and liabilities, existing and potential, of the CSL. This includes the extent of any product liabilities which have already been addressed by the task force on asset sales as part of the due diligence process.

The Commonwealth and the CSL are currently negotiating the terms of the indemnities to be provided by the Commonwealth post-sale. Those negotiations will focus on the indemnity sought by the company covering blood products, pertussis and products derived from human pituitary hormones. The government has the issue of contingent liabilities well in hand and it therefore regards this aspect of the amendment as unnecessary.

As to the reference in the amendment to an employee share scheme, the CSL board has already taken an in-principle decision, after recommendations from a number of members, including the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and me, to establish such a scheme of employee shares, and it is currently considering the nature and form of that scheme. I understand that a consultant has been appointed to work out the actual processes in relation to such a scheme. Therefore, we already have that matter in hand and we consider that the terms of the amendment are therefore unnecessary.

I will now go into more detail with respect to the issue of the indemnity concerning the products. Before I do that, it might be useful for me to explain what the government is doing in relation to CJD in broad terms and to fit into that what we intend to do with respect to the indemnity for the CSL.

On 11 May 1993 the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, announced an independent inquiry into the use of pituitary derived hormones in Australia and the rare disorder of CJD. This followed confirmation that four Australian women who were treated with human pituitary hormone while seeking treatment for infertility have since died from the disease.

The inquiry will be headed by Associate Professor Margaret Allars, who will be assisted by experts from the relevant scientific and medical areas and will have the full support of Commonwealth agencies. State governments are being asked to assist by ensuring access to relevant records held by public hospitals. The government believes that the people who were treated while on the program and who are at risk of contracting this disease have a right to know how and on what basis the decisions to start and continue the use of the product were taken.

It is also vital that there be an examination of related issues to see if procedures in place today are adequate in the light of this unfortunate experience. The inquiry will make recommendations on a number of areas, including further action which might be taken to identify and counsel people who used the treatment, and priorities for research into matters relating to CJD and its transmission.

Between 1967 and 1985, approximately 2,100 Australians were supplied with cadaver derived hormones as treatment for infertility and short stature. The program was stopped in 1985 after reports from overseas of deaths from CJD of people who had received similar hormones. The department of health has contacted at least 1,300 of the 2,100 people on the program and is continuing efforts to trace the remainder. A task force has been established within the department to concentrate efforts on tracing participants and providing advice and support. Comprehensive national counselling services are now available for people treated with human pituitary hormones.

On 1 October 1993, Marriage Guidance Australia will offer special counselling and support services for people who were treated with these products and who could now be at risk of contracting CJD. Marriage Guidance Australia will provide a professional, confidential service with qualified counsellors available in every state.

One of the greatest concerns expressed by people treated under the program is that they have not had the level of support and counselling services that they needed. As a result, there is wide support for community based rather than hospital based counselling services. The free service will help product recipients and their families with problems occurring as a result of uncertainty and anxiety, will offer psychological support and, if necessary, will refer people for further medical advice. That is the situation in relation to the question of the overall actions by the government in relation to this dreaded disease.

The question asked was about the actual arrangements with respect to indemnity. To clarify the position, I think the best thing I can do is to place on the record the contents of a letter from Mr Roche, the Deputy Secretary to the department, to Dr McNamee, the Managing Director of CSL. In the letter, Mr Roche sets out quite clearly what the situation is going to be with respect to indemnity, and I think it is important that we place this on the record. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to your letter of 30 August 1993 requesting that, in the context of the public float of the Company, the Commonwealth indemnify CSL Limited against claims arising from the use of a number of products manufactured and supplied by the Company; namely plasma products, blood bank diagnostic reagents, human pituitary gland-derived hormone products and pertussis vaccine products.

Officials from the Task Force on Asset Sales (TFAS), the Australian Government Solicitor's Office (AGS) and this Department have examined your request and generally support the provision by the Commonwealth of a range of Product indemnities.

In reaching our position, we took the view that the Commonwealth should not indemnify a privatised CSL for claims relating to the use of the Products where CSL is able or has been able to obtain product liability insurance. We also considered that no indemnity should be provided where the Company has made or will make commercial decisions independent of Government to enter arrangements for the manufacture and supply of any of the Products.

In this regard, I would expect that, in the case of foreign tolling of plasma, CSL will either seek indemnities from the countries concerned or reflect in its pricing policies the risks associated with the use of plasma products.
Subject to the above restrictions, the provision of Product indemnities to a privatised CSL has been limited to cases where:

.the Commonwealth has requested or permitted CSL over the years, and before the listing of the Company on the Stock Exchange, to manufacture Products the use of which could attract claims for damages;
.Product indemnities were provided by the Commonwealth to a Commonwealth-owned CSL; and
.the Commonwealth requests CSL to manufacture and supply post-sale, any of the Products.

Within this framework and for Products manufactured prior to the listing of the Company on the Australian Stock Exchange, and, in some cases, before the execution of the proposed plasma fractionation and diagnostic products agreements, we will recommend to the Minister that the Commonwealth provides an indemnity for any loss suffered by CSL arising from certain claims brought against the Company by any person as a result of the use of the following products:
(a)human pituitary growth hormones and human pituitary gonadotrophin (follicle stimulating hormone);

(b)plasma products supplied to New Zealand and Papua New Guinea (PNG), where the products are derived from plasma donated by individuals and collected in New Zealand and PNG and the claims are AIDS-related;
(c)plasma products derived from plasma donated by individuals and collected in Australia, where the claims are AIDS-related or arise from hepatitis;
(d)diagnostic products derived from blood donated by individuals and collected in Australia, where the claims are AIDS-related; and
(e)pertussis vaccine.

In the post-sale context, where the Commonwealth has requested CSL to undertake the manufacture of any of the Products for and on behalf of the Commonwealth, the related indemnity will be incorporated in an agreement between the parties. I note that the current draft of the proposed plasma fractionation agreement includes an indemnity clause for AIDS-related and hepatitis claims from users of plasma products sourced from plasma collected from individuals in Australia. I would expect that the proposed diagnostic reagent products agreement will contain a similar clause but only covering AIDS-related claims.

I have noted your request for an indemnity for claims relating to asbestos exposure by present and former employees, and can confirm your understanding that the Commonwealth is not prepared to indemnify CSL for claims made by present Company employees relating to asbestos exposure. The question of whether an indemnity will be provided by the Commonwealth to former employees for asbestos related claims is still under consideration.
I am sure that the Commonwealth will further consider that matter one way or another, but that is a separate question to the issue we are discussing at the moment. The letter continued:

I also note that your request for an indemnity for CSL directors in respect of the float process is being considered by the TFAS (in conjunction with the AGS) which will convey the Commonwealth's position to you.
I trust our position on product indemnities is acceptable to you.
I am sending a copy of this letter to Ross Smith of the Task Force.

In that letter, Mr Roche has broadly outlined the general approach of the government to this very complicated matter. In general, the concerns raised by the opposition have already been taken into account through the commitments made by the department and recommended to the minister.

PARA.TAB: As far as the government is concerned, obviously protection needs to be afforded for specific indemnities. However, the opposition's motion tends to suggest a much broader sweeping definition than the one suggested by the government. For example, the government can be responsible only for those situations in which it has been responsible for CSL up to the point of sale. It can only be responsible for those situations in which CSL has made determinations which, in a sense, meet its responsibilities to the government. The government cannot be responsible for commercial decisions made by CSL, especially post-sale, unless those decisions are consistent with the Commonwealth having specifically requested CSL to produce a particular product.

So, given all of those factors, the concerns the opposition tried to raise in its amendments have been met by the comments I have made here today. Some of the other issues raised by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Bradfield, will be dealt with by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer.

I congratulate CSL for the work it has done over the years for the Australian people. I am very pleased that CSL is setting up its new plant in my electorate at Broadmeadows. By the way, that happened before I gained responsibility for this area; nevertheless, I am very pleased that it is happening. The plant is one of the most modern in the world for these matters. This company, through its technology and development, shows what Australians are capable of in this area. It will be able to compete internationally and to retain a very significant section of the Australian market. I am sure that we will all be proud of its work in the future.

The Managing Director of CSL, Dr McNamee, particularly, needs to be congratulated for his efforts. CSL as a company has just handed down another very large profit, which shows not only that it has been working to deliver an excellent system to the Australian people but also that it is a very successful commercial operation. As the other parliamentary secretary will explain, the sale will proceed very satisfactorily and we can be certain that, into the future, Australia will have a significant supply of vaccine and plasma products from CSL.

TALK.START.PARA: —I close the debate on the CSL Sale Bill by thanking those honourable members who have been involved in the debate. I recently came back into this debate, having been involved previously as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health in the earlier stages of the preparation for sale of CSL Ltd, which was formerly the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. More recently, I introduced the bill on behalf of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis).

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) has explained a number of the issues dealing with any enduring liabilities that the Commonwealth might hold over products manufactured by CSL in the past or in the future where it cannot be insured. I will canvass some of the sale conditions because one honourable member asked in the debate why there were certain restrictions on the condition of sale. In deference to that honourable member, I should explain why.

It should be kept in mind that in this bill the government is preparing CSL, which essentially is a vaccine and blood plasma products manufacturer, for sale from the Commonwealth's holdings. It has been the case for a very long time that, whilst the Commonwealth probably felt comfortable that it had this in-house producer, CSL itself was keen, prepared, willing and able to go out and compete with the best in the rest of the world, but one of the things holding it back was that it had to come to the Commonwealth for capital, and capital is at a premium in the public sector.

CSL management, and to some extent the workers after some discussion, felt that it would be in the best interests of CSL as a producer, that it could do a better job as a manufacturer and a producer of these products, if it were to float free and be then free to draw on capital markets for its own purposes and its own growth. So we are preparing for this float, which should take place in the first quarter of 1994.

One of the important decisions we made at a very early stage, though, was that CSL should remain an Australian company and an independent company. We did not want it to be immediately gobbled up by a foreign chemical manufacturing company, but wanted it to remain Australian and be given a good chance, at least in the first instance, and hopefully from then on in, to remain Australian and independent. We want it to maintain those links with the Australian scientific community and the international producers at a scientific and production level so that it can take its place as one of the world's great producers of chemical products. I think we have successfully introduced a bill which will maintain the CSL, during and after its float, as an Australian and independent organisation.

I want to review some of the critical mechanisms by which we will achieve this. The first mechanism, which relates to the foreign control and influence of CSL after the sale, is that there will be a requirement that CSL's articles of association include provisions which limit the voting rights of significant foreign shareholders to the appointment, replacement and removal of company directors. Those foreign shareholders with holdings greater than five per cent will be able to exercise their votes only in relation to one-third of the directors. Further, we will require that CSL's head office and principal fractionation activities be located in Australia, that CSL remain incorporated in Australia, and that CSL's chairman and two-thirds of the board be Australian citizens.

At the point of sale, we also have some further rules. Those arrangements will be complemented by an allocation of shares in CSL at the point of sale. Those rules are that there will be a limit of five per cent on all individual shareholdings, domestic or foreign, an aggregate limit of 15 to 20 per cent on foreign shareholdings, and a preference for individuals and institutions over corporate shareholders. The third leg of those series of controls is that post-sale restrictions on foreign ownership of shares in CSL will be regulated through the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975. That satisfies a very firm decision of the government, which is a decision not so much to dispose of an asset but a decision which is a part of industry policy. The government had quite a good and strong debate on this issue: we see CSL as an Australian producer not simply being sold out of the Commonwealth's hands into private hands but enduring as an Australian manufacturer of vaccines and blood plasma products. Of course, it has some world-class blood fractionation facilities.

I think the bill will easily achieve the aims we set it. I appreciate the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), which talks about the notion of contingent liability—that has been addressed by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health—and that the board of management of CSL Ltd encourage broad employee shareholding in CSL. That, as we understand it, has been a subject of debate between the board and the workers of CSL. I think we have incorporated as well as we can both of the sentiments expressed by the opposition, and I appreciate the fact that it has raised those sentiments.

I thank those people involved through the assets sales task force attached to the Minister for Finance and those officers from the department of health who have also been engaged in this but I particularly want to thank CSL management and its work force, which have had to work through all of the work conditions—conditions which may or may not change as a consequence of this sale out of the Commonwealth's hands. We are confident, as is the work force itself, that the conditions workers have built up whilst CSL has been in the hands of the Commonwealth will be maintained. In fact, those negotiations have already taken place and, as far as I understand it, have been perfectly reasonably settled. I wish the Chief Executive Officer—Dr McNamee—his board and all the workers all the best in a company that will be for a long time to come a very significant player and a new Australian company.

DEBATE.TITLE: AVIATION FUEL REVENUES (SPECIAL APPROPRIATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Mr O'Keefe:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill amends the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act 1988. Currently the act provides for appropriation to the Civil Aviation Authority of duty on aviation gasoline. The purpose of the amendment is to enable duty on aviation turbine fuel to be appropriated to the CAA as part of the aviation safety regulation cost recovery regime. Honourable members will remember that in the 1992 budget it was announced the cost of aviation safety standard setting and surveillance would be jointly met by the government and the aviation industry. The government would meet 50 per cent of the costs up to a limit of $22.8 million in real terms. The government proposes to phase in cost recovery of the industry's portion of these costs over the two years, beginning with the 1993-94 financial year. Cost recovery arrangements for 1993-94 involve a slight increase in duty on both aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel. Because fuel used by Australian airlines on international services is exempt from duty, the CAA will introduce a fee for safety regulation to these international operations.

PARA.TAB: The industry's contribution to aviation and safety standards setting and surveillance for this financial year will reduce government outlays by $4.5 million. Users of aviation gasoline recently benefited, too, from a 3c per litre reduction in duty, and the CAA is currently exploring the prospect for a further reduction following the introduction of new airspace management arrangements. I must say that the proposed method of cost recovery with this particular situation is reasonably straightforward. But it is true that the industry would have preferred the government to adhere to the recommendations of the Bosch report that these costs not be recoverable. In 1985, under then minister Morris, the government and the aviation industry accepted the Bosch recommendations as a package, notwithstanding some industry misgivings at the time.

It frankly remains to be seen what the future holds in aviation cost recovery. There is no doubt that the government, if it is to meet its objectives, will need to increase its recovery from the industry to meet future cost recovery targets. The industry, particularly the airlines, are concerned that the necessary imposts being imposed have regard to the various sector contributions to the need of the safety regulations and standards function. I suppose this is understandable because the major airlines do not use many of the facilities that are provided, whereas general aviation, which could be high users of these particular facilities, would find it very difficult under the present circumstances to meet some of those costs. It will be a difficult outcome to achieve given, by its very nature, that the regulation function needs to be deployed, regardless of the sector funding of its costs, if the public interest is to be served. It is true that these matters are still to be subjected to discussion with the CAA, but the difficulties are such that the consideration of funding the entirety of the safety regulations and standards function on behalf of the community may well be appropriate. I say quite seriously that the opposition parties will certainly be monitoring the way the government proceeds with this particular matter. There is no doubt that there is a campaign that has built up into almost a frenzy amongst the general aviation operators of Australia as a result of the prospect of the safety levy being put on them.

General aviation in Australia has had a very difficult few years. Over the last few years we have seen a decline of 14 and 16 per cent per annum in general aviation activities. This has been brought about by a number of factors, not the least being the economic situation, the rural downturn and the drought. While many operators have already left the industry, the real scare is that more will go if the safety regulation charges are implemented by the government to cover these costs in their entirety. It is a very real challenge to the government, and one that we will be monitoring very closely.

There is no doubt that aviation safety, and the regulation of safety, is a most important matter. It is true that in Australia we have had the highest safety standards in the world. We certainly have had one of the finest aviation safety records. It is therefore of some concern when we see the front page of today's Canberra Times carrying the headline `Fatal flight after lapse by officials'. Whilst as yet we have not seen the full report into the crash of an aircraft at Young, the interim report indicates that this is a most serious situation. According to that report, the initial investigation by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation found that the aircraft involved had flown with a `significantly reduced' level of safety—a level that was below the minimum equipment list.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) made a statement a couple of weeks ago to an estimates committee that any aircraft that did not comply with the minimum equipment list is just `not supposed to fly'. I agree with that statement completely. Yet we find that this particular unfortunate aircraft had an unserviceable auto-pilot which was permitted to be used for something like 10 days. Admittedly, it was in accordance with the minimum equipment list, but permission was given to fly that aircraft twice, it would appear, when it did not have all its functions operating properly.

Whilst it is probably not completely proper to comment on what the interim findings might be, and we should really wait for the final CAA review, I think this particular case brings home the importance of monitoring aviation safety standards in Australia. Since this report appeared in the Canberra Times this morning it has been interesting to hear some of the press commentators already talking about the situation of deregulation and what that may or may not have done in the case of this particular incident.

I have no problems with deregulation of the airline industry at all. In fact, deregulation does not mean, and it should not mean, the lowering of safety standards. I hope we find that this was an isolated incident rather than one of laxity by the department in allowing some of those standards to slip. I am sure that the latter was not the case.

Even in a deregulated industry safety standards are set and all operators are required to maintain them. If the operators involved go below those particular safety standards, of course they must take the consequences. Therefore, I would hope that we would not be going into a frenzy regarding the reintroduction of a fully regulated airline industry when there are obviously so many savings that can be made in a deregulated environment. Perhaps I should not say any more than that until such time as the full report from the Civil Aviation Authority is released regarding this particular incident in Young. But it certainly does bring home the need for constant vigilance of our aviation safety programs in Australia.

In this respect, this bill is the beginning of a whole new regime. It is a whole new way of funding aviation safety, and it is one that we should be considering very carefully until we get the final program in place; firstly because of the cost that would be applied not only to the major airline operators, but to the general aviation industry; and secondly, how we can get a balance for a user pays principle on the monitoring of safety, vis-a-vis the cost to the general aviation sector which provides such an important role in the development of Australia and in the remote areas of Australia.

The opposition, therefore, will be watching the development of this program very closely and with very great interest. We hope that we will have an opportunity to be able to work out what will be fair and equitable, but still maintain the incredibly high safety standards that Australia has enjoyed over the past decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill. I advise the House that I am somewhat flying blind as I left my glasses in my office. I want to join the shadow minister for transport and communications, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), in some of his comments. I guess it is always dangerous for a backbench member to praise a shadow minister, but I know that he takes a great deal of interest in his portfolio area. On most occasions people on both sides of the House find it difficult to disagree with him. I certainly am in such a situation today.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the bill is to appropriate certain excise revenues to the Civil Aviation Authority. This is my first opportunity to say in this House how delighted I was that General Peter Gration was appointed chairman of the authority. As Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence it was my great pleasure to have some deal of contact with Peter and I am sure that he will do an outstanding job. I am sure that he will earn the respect, admiration and thanks of those in the aviation industry, in the same way as he did in the Department of Defence.

As the shadow minister has pointed out, we should be very proud of our safety record in Australia. The price of safety is eternal vigilance and avoiding complacency. Whilst both sides of the House have supported this approach of phased in full cost recovery, we want to avoid the situation that results in any lessening of standards. I am confident that it will not. I regret that I cannot comment on the accident that has been referred to.

This legislation increases the cost of aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene by 0.264c per litre. For those who do not know, gasoline is utilised by piston-powered aircraft and aviation kerosene is utilised by turbine-powered aircraft. The revenue will accrue from 1 September 1993. It is expected that in 1994-95 we will move from a situation of the government and the industry sharing the cost of safety regulations to a position where the industry will be fully funded.

I suppose my being in the electorate of Chifley puts me in an ironic situation when talking about aviation, aeroplanes and airports. On the one hand, my neighbour the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman) is very keen to see Schofields general aviation airport closed down, and thus avoid the imposts of this bill. Equally, we are both very keen to see Badgerys Creek start up and see the imposition of these increases being met by aircraft taking off and landing there.

All honourable members accept that we need to explore fully the opportunities for private enterprise involvement at Badgerys Creek airport. However, the FAC seems quite determined to ensure that it maximises its revenue from Sydney (Kingsford Smith) airport and minimises the opportunities for Badgerys Creek to provide competition. We must hope that the Minister for Transport and Communications will authorise a reputable organisation—one of the banks, such as Macquarie, CFS or First Boston, or whoever—to scope this proposition. If there is a positive result, we ought to delay no longer and proceed as quickly as possible with Badgerys Creek not only being a general airport, but, more importantly, being an interstate and international airport.

If the answer is in the negative, I think honourable members whose electorates encompass the western suburbs and who take an interest in it, as well as the shadow minister who has spoken on it, need to set aside our reservations for a few years and then look again at the problem. Until such time as it is properly studied in a report and in advice to the government, we have no alternative but to keep the pressure on. I sincerely hope that Minister Collins will accept this challenge and authorise such a study, even if his own department appears reluctant or provides advice to the contrary, because I think it is a logical proposition.

The FAC's own figures of projected traffic indicate that it sees Badgerys Creek getting up and running and taking international passengers much quicker than has hitherto been disclosed to the public, or even in its advice to the government. I find it rather incredible that an organisation like that can play it both ways—that is, have a public posture which suggests nothing before the year 2010 and then project that in the year 2002 we will be seeing up to 1,000 international aircraft movements a year. It is absolutely incredible. In fact, if I had not seen it, I would have argued that it was impossible. Perhaps General Gration will move on to become Chairman of the FAC. I am sure if that were the case we would see a consistency and honesty from the FAC that we have yet to witness from it. But perhaps he has got enough challenges in the civil aviation field.

I would like to wind up my remarks by saying that those on both sides of the House, as is the case with a lot of legislation, support this measure. I hope that the airport at Badgerys Creek will provide quite a lot of revenue to the Civil Aviation Authority for its standards and regulation. I live for the day when we will see an international airport there which provides an alternative to Sydney (Kingsford Smith) airport and which will actually be capable of providing some competition in terms of services and charges. This means it will not only play its part as Sydney's second airport but also fill the coffers of the Civil Aviation Authority in order that our exceptionally high aviation standards can be maintained and possibly improved.
