TALK.START.PARA: —The Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Departure Tax Act 1978 to increase the departure tax from $20 to $25. That new fee will commence on 1 January 1994. The decision was announced in the budget and will provide a boost to revenue of $11 million in this financial year and $28 million to $30 million in a full year. The tax, in terms of its amount, is similar to such taxes imposed in comparable countries, such as the USA, Japan, Canada, Hong Kong and Germany. The increase was seen by the industry as preferable to the imposition of an arrivals tax which was floated prior to the budget.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing about this tax is its history. If we look at what has occurred over the years we see that the amount collected from it is reasonably comparable to the growth in the number of international tourists in Australia and the amount of money allocated by governments of both political persuasions in terms of funding of the Australian Tourist Commission.

The tax, as I mentioned, was first introduced in 1978 as a result of a recommendation of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism which made 46 recommendations in its final report, including one to introduce a departure tax to fund the Australian Tourist Commission. I must say that the government of the day immediately took that on board and introduced it straight away. I also have a confession to make, in as much as I was chairman of the select committee which recommended the introduction of the departure tax.

In terms of overall funding, we have had a relationship between the amount collected through the departure tax and the amount spent by the Australian Tourist Commission. It is true, too, that the government has announced some further increases in tourism funding, especially for regional tourism, over the next few years. It would argue that the extra money will be taken from this particular allocation.

I am quite interested to see in the House today the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) because one of the things I was going to refer to was the growth in tourism and the potential for tourism to become a milch cow of governments of all political persuasions if we are not particularly careful. I say for the sake of the honourable member that the latest figures I have just received show incredible growth at Cairns international airport. Having had some connection in the early 1980s with the promotion of Cairns as an international destination overseas, it is quite amazing to think that, in the year ended May this year, there were 936,915 passengers processed through Cairns airport. Cairns airport is now the fifth busiest in Australia. It is an indication of the incredible strength that tourism has gained in Australia—an incredible strength that continues to grow, and will do so for many years to come.

We must be careful to make sure that tourism does not become a milch cow for all and sundry in government to start making money, because tourism by its very nature is a fickle industry. It is very cost sensitive. One of the things that scare me more than anything is that almost weekly in various newspapers we read about local government authorities, state government authorities or, indeed, this government talking about imposing additional taxes on tourists to make sure they can provide some of this infrastructure. We should never forget the enormous contribution that tourism makes through the general tax arrangements in Australia—through sales taxes, through excise taxes, through income taxes. I think I am right in saying that last year that in itself was worth about $7 billion to the Australian Treasury.

On top of that, there are taxes to visit the Great Barrier Reef; in some parts of Australia there is a bed tax. We now have this proposition—and I am delighted to see the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) at the table—for a fringe benefits tax, which was really going to cause some heartache and real problems for the industry. All the way down the line tourism is seen as a relatively easy means of making extra money to fund some of these government programs.

The warning should be that the industry must be very aware of some of these moves and must make sure that those moves do not price Australia out of the international market. One of the greatest things we have going for us at the moment has been the decline in the value of the Australian dollar. Australia at this stage, quite frankly, is one of the best value for money destinations in the world. In previous years we have seen some hiccups in the market when additional charges were introduced. Therefore, as I say, we have to be vigilant and we have to make sure that we do not get to a stage where we start pricing ourselves out of that international market.

The other thing that I would like to talk about briefly this afternoon is the method of collection of the departure tax. It has been of concern to me ever since the tax was introduced 15 years ago. There are various ways of collecting these taxes. A separate organisation has been established in Australia. There are cages at international airports where people line up to pay their money to leave the country. Early in the piece there were fights with the airlines. The airlines virtually refused to collect the departure tax on behalf of the government, although this method is used in many ports overseas. I note that the government keeps referring to the fact that this is an efficient and cost-effective way of picking up the departure tax. In actual fact, it does cost a great deal of money—hundreds of thousands of dollars every year—to sell those stamps in the cages at the airport.

While we may congratulate ourselves on the standard of promotion of Australian tourism, the best form of promotion is word of mouth advertising. When word gets around, often wrongly, that Australia is regarded as a somewhat expensive destination—through statements such as that when a person wants to leave the country he has to line up to pay $25 to get out of the place—I think we have to be careful. It is interesting to note that about 111 countries around the world impose some sort of departure tax and many more have taxes for the use of aviation infrastructure. I suppose one of the best examples of that is the United States. Most people do not know that when they go to the United States taxes in excess of $US30 are imposed on them. People very rarely pay those taxes directly; they are incorporated in the price of the ticket. It would seem to me that this is the most sensible way to go.

We have not really examined properly in Australia the prospect of including these prices and charges within the cost of the airline ticket. It would not require an army at the airports to line up to sell the tickets to departing tourists and residents. It would not require the airlines to issue and collect the stamps and account for the money that is being collected. It would require Australia joining some sort of bank settlement plan similar to that used by the airlines to take the collection. Obviously there would be a fee involved, but it would be an efficient way of collecting the tax. Most importantly, it would take away that feeling that some international visitors have that Australia is an expensive place because they have to line up to pay money to get out of the country.

When we look around the world, we see that a number of our charges are a great deal less than those imposed by overseas countries. For example, in the United Kingdom the cost to move in and out of an airport is the equivalent of about $60, but in that case nobody realises that he is paying those charges.

I think we already have an example in Australia of what can be done. Once again it centres around that magnificent airport in Cairns in the middle of the federal division of Leichhardt. A specific tax is imposed on visitors, both domestic and international passengers, in and out of Cairns. That tax, the airport handling charge, is incorporated in the price of the ticket. If one were to travel through Cairns, one would note that the charge is listed on the ticket coupon, but if 95 per cent of the passengers who travel through Cairns were to be asked whether there was a charge involved very few of them would have any realisation that this passenger handling charge is there. That system should be examined as soon as possible, partly because of the public relations image that the present system portrays of Australia and partly because I believe it would be a much more efficient system of collecting the departure tax.

The growth of international tourism to Australia has really been quite enormous over the last 15 years. It is 15 years since the international visitor numbers started to grow. A little earlier I mentioned the growth in the figures for Cairns airport. When we consider that in the year to the end of May 1993 something like 9.675 million passengers passed through Australia's international airports we are given an indication of just how big the tourism industry is.

When we look at the growth in the collection of the departure tax over the years, we see that only five years ago we collected $64 million and last year we collected $92 million. So there is some big revenue involved. I believe there is an opportunity to make sure that we continue the promotion of Australian tourism as best as we possibly can in overseas countries through this formula of roughly using the departure tax as a means of funding the Australian Tourist Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1993 provides for the increase in the departure tax from $20 to $25. This measure announced in the budget is to take effect from 1 January next year. The tax is expected to bring about a 90 per cent increase in the revenue raised, estimated to be $11 million in 1993-94. As the increase only takes effect from 1 January, the revenue raised in the next financial year is expected to increase by a larger amount, as the new rate will be collected for the full financial year. As has already been mentioned by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the expected increase is $28 million in 1994-95, $30 million in 1995-96 and $32 million in 1996-97.

PARA.TAB: At $25, Australia's departure tax will now be around the same level as the charges imposed on international travellers by authorities in the United States and Fiji and is actually below those levied in Japan, Hong Kong and Canada and a number of European countries such as Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Greece and Germany. As the honourable member for Fadden has already indicated in what I consider to have been a very bipartisan contribution to the debate, this increase will offset the additional cost of tourism promotion expenditure announced in the budget. An additional $80 million was allocated to boost the development of new tourism products and for tourism promotion over the next four years, including an extra $8 million in 1993-94 and $10 million per annum to 1996-97 for overseas market development.

The Far North Queensland tourism industry, centred on my electorate of Leichhardt, appreciates the value of promotion and the importance of having guaranteed sources of funding for these activities. This has been supported by recent comments by the Chairman of the Australian Tourism Industry Association, who described the increase as `a small additional cost to travellers'.

The honourable member for Fadden must have been reading my notes because I agree with him that no-one, least of all me and my tourism based constituency of Leichhardt, wants to see the tourism industry treated as some sort of milch cow. However, there is a general acceptance within the tourism industry and amongst other interested parties, including environmentalists and travellers themselves, that there is a degree of room in the industry for user pays principles.

It is acknowledged that Australia's tourism sector is in its adolescence. I describe it as such because it is youthful, growing fast and requires a lot of sustenance. Strong, vigorous and healthy adults are not created from diets of bread and water. This government is the first Australian government to recognise this and to really nourish our tourism industry to ensure its future viability and vitality. This was clearly evidenced in the tourism initiatives included in this government's budget—a tourism focused budget that has in the main been accepted, approved and applauded by peak tourism groups in my electorate, including the Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau.

TAB.TAB: The Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau, headed by a very capable and committed Geoff Donaghy, has commended the $80 million in tourist initiatives marked in this budget. Of particular interest to the bureau is the $23 million in funding available over the next four years to the regional tourism development program. The bureau is recognised throughout Australia as a leader in regional tourism strategy. Yesterday it unveiled a draft of the Cairns regional tourism strategy.

PARA.TAB: The four main aims of this strategy are to diversify tourism to support and sustain the economic growth of the region, to coordinate the delivery of infrastructure and services to support tourism, to ensure sustainable use of the region's natural and cultural assets, and to establish appropriate organisational structures to manage and develop the industry. Geoff Donaghy and the bureau ought to be congratulated on these far-sighted objectives. I look forward to working with him and the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) in the future in order to ensure that his far-sighted strategy is implemented.

Far North Queensland tourism operators and their organisations know of the importance of planning for the future. This program, and the programs that are set out in the budget, will provide funds for the development of strategic plans, the development of local tourism and infrastructure and the coordination of tourism information on a regional basis. My electorate includes some of Australia's most significant ecotourism destinations. The Daintree rainforest, the rest of the World Heritage Wet Tropics and the Great Barrier Reef all fall within the electorate of Leichhardt. So it is no wonder that considerable support has been expressed for the implementation of the $10 million national ecotourism strategy currently being formulated. Funding will be provided for a program to complement the work of the states, environmental groups and tourism organisations in promoting sustainable tourism.

In yesterday's Cairns Post Mr Donaghy of the Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau estimated that $1.6 billion was required for supporting public sector infrastructure in Far North Queensland over the next 10 years. As the honourable member for Fadden has mentioned, we already have a reef levy. In my region there is also a small levy for visitors to Kuranda. In the May 1993 report on the Cairns regional economy, produced by the Cairns Economic Research Unit, research fellow Tim Nevard noted:

SPEECH.PARA: These two examples—
he was referring to those two small levies—
indicate that at certain key areas within the Region, the environment has reached or passed its capacity to absorb further tourism development without significant additional funding.
He asked:
Is the increased cost of the visitor experience likely to have a disproportionate and economically damaging effect on the number of visitors?
He then said:
Given the small amounts involved, any effect is likely to be extremely marginal and unlikely to have any measurable impact on commercial revenues . . .

I believe the Far North Queensland experience forms a micro view of the situation nationally. We need a coordinated national approach to tourism promotion and development and it has to be paid for through a breadth of approaches. The small increase in the departure tax, as outlined in this bill, forms just one small part of this. I have to say, partly in response to the honourable member for Fadden, that it is stating the obvious that, if the $1.6 billion suggested by Mr Donaghy is in any way accurate, all levels of government face an enormous fiscal challenge.

PARA.TAB: Coming from Far North Queensland, I recognise the enormous contribution that the Queensland tourism industry makes to the Australian economy as a whole, as the honourable member for Fadden has referred to. Nevertheless, it is my hope that we can meet the challenge with the cooperation of the government and industry. I suspect, with some respect to the honourable member for Fadden, that the tourism industry may be a little ahead of him here.

Earlier in my speech I talked about milch cows, as did the honourable member for Fadden. I accept that the tourism industry cannot be a milch cow. Nevertheless, I detect in the tourism industry a recognition of the fact that there is a requirement for infrastructure and that it cannot be met by existing funding arrangements. Local government has great difficulty meeting it. It is something that challenges federal, state and local governments. I hope that it does not become a political issue and that we can all sit down and address the problem.

I would also like to commend the acknowledgment by this government of the important role played by the backpacker market in Australian tourism. Anyone who has visited Cairns, the reef or the Daintree region will know how important this market sector is to the economy of Far North Queensland and Australia more generally. But its genesis has been organic. The backpacker market needs some assistance to make sure it can continue to provide good value holiday experiences to young people from around the world for a long time to come. After all, they will be the five-star travellers of tomorrow. The Commonwealth is to provide support to develop this market with an aim to remove impediments to growth, encourage a strategic approach and ensure a positive return to the economy. Funding will encourage the promotion of standards in the backpacker accommodation sector, an initiative I believe is very urgent. The Australian Tourist Commission will identify marketing opportunities and increase the promotion of backpacker accommodation in consultation with youth hostels and backpacker associations. When I speak to the tourism operators of Far North Queensland, one message keeps coming through: we need information to help us plan. We already have a building lull as a result of the oversupply from the late 1980s. No-one wants to see that happen again.

I am sure the appointment of Frank Conroy as the chairman of the newly created Tourism Forecasting Council will be applauded. Mr Conroy is a former managing director of the Westpac Banking Corporation and the current chairman of the FAC. He will be joined on the council by representatives from a range of industries directly reliant on tourism, and he is well aware of the need for sound information on the future prospects for the industry.

The Tourism Forecasting Council will comprise a high profile reporting body, including the peak tourism industry, finance and building sector organisations. The group will be supported by a technically oriented advisory body. This is long overdue. The council will provide medium- and long-term forecasts for future tourism growth as well as the supply and demand for accommodation.

Some industry commentators argue that occupancy rates in key centres, including Cairns, suggest that new accommodation will need to be financed in the near future. I commend the council for determining this as an area of priority on which it will be able to focus its early efforts. The tourism industry has never before had access to such high quality forecasting. It is absolutely essential and has been welcomed as such by the industry.The report from the Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau and its draft plan again emphasise that the key to providing the appropriate infrastructure for Far North Queensland will be the establishment of a regional tourism information system.

In conclusion, I again refer to the comments made by the honourable member for Fadden, and I look forward to a future whereby, as with a lot of issues in this House, we can approach the issue of infrastructure for the tourism industry on a bipartisan basis. As I said earlier, it will require cooperation from the federal, state and local governments.

As much as I would wish it, all those governments are not always Labor governments. These issues have to be resolved with a degree of cooperation because they are urgent. Federal, state and local governments have other fiscal restraints. The honourable member for Fadden is quite right in saying that the tourism industry does supply a great deal of income to the Australian economy. Nevertheless, the fact is that, if the figures that I cited from Mr Donaghy are correct, then there is a need for some massive expenditure. As I said, that perhaps needs some innovative thought on behalf of the tourism industry and all levels of government. By `innovative', I mean that we might have to think about some form of taxation. We cannot avoid that.

I hope that the government of the day will sit down with the tourism industry and come up with a resolution that everyone agrees with. I hope that whoever is in opposition—I am confident that the honourable member for Fadden will remain in opposition in this House for a long time—cooperates with any future plan that is brought up in that area.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the remarks of the shadow minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull). No member in this chamber has a better understanding of the tourist industry, its background and the policies that might make Australia a better tourist destination for international travellers.

PARA.TAB: I preface my remarks by saying that the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is at the table, would be very happy about this particular measure because it is a money raising measure. As we all know, the Assistant Treasurer and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) need as much money as they can get to try to make up the budget deficit. Whilst both sides of the parliament might disagree with some aspects of the departure tax, fundamentally, it is a measure to get more money into the coffers of the Treasury.

The Departure Tax Amendment Bill seeks to raise the departure tax payable at Australian air and shipping ports from $20 to $25 effective from 1 January 1994. That in itself does not seem a very big rise, but each year it appears that governments put just a little bit more on the departure tax, which is a greater imposition on tourists. The departure tax was first introduced in 1978 at $10 a passenger. In 1981-82, it became $20. It has moved up and down to either $10 or $20 a passenger in various later budget decisions. So the poor old tourists and passengers continue to pay this tax, which I am aware is paid in other parts of the world. Governments are very keen to take their pound of flesh from tourists, but there is a price, as the honourable member for Fadden has pointed out and other honourable members will be pointing out. Inevitably, tourists resist paying too much by way of departure and entry taxes.

In a full year, the government says that the boost to revenue will be about $28 million to $30 million on top of the $92.2 million collected last year. The collection costs for this tax are quite high. This financial year, with 5.2 million transactions for the tax, the government will be paying a collection agent, Australia Post, about $4.2 million or 81c per transaction. That in itself is a problem and we should be very aware of the cost, and inconvenience in some cases, of collecting this tax from the passengers.

The number of transactions does not always equal the number of people who pay the departure tax. For instance, 300,000 children under 12 who leave Australia for overseas each year are exempt, but Australia Post still charges a processing fee for exemption stamps that are needed to identify these children. Australia Post's involvement with collections of this tax dates from 1986. At that time, the airlines were made responsible for collection and they appointed Australia Post as an agent. In 1986, all the revenue from this tax went back into aviation. I think this is a key point: the tax, as originally imposed, went back into aviation. But this has changed.

In 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority were formed. In 1989, tenders for collection of the departure tax were called. Australia Post won a three-year contract in 1990, which was subsequently extended in 1992 until 30 June 1994.

I note that since 1988 half of the revenue from the tax has been channelled back into general revenue, with the other 50 per cent being split equally between immigration and tourism promotion. So we see this fundamental problem that, whilst in the initial stages the departure tax was always promoted on the basis that it would help the tourism and immigration areas, a proportion of that tax moves back into general revenue. Initially, half of what was then a $10 departure tax was notionally given to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as a replacement for the previous immigration clearance fee.

Hypothecation is of course an old political argument both in this area and in road funding. It is unrealistic to expect governments to endorse widely the principle that moneys collected in one area should be spent in that area. It is a problem. The Assistant Treasurer agrees with me. From his point of view, hypothecation is always a difficulty, and I am inclined to accept that viewpoint.

I note in passing that the government's claims of an $80 million boost for tourism funding over four years should be read in light of the $30 million each year in extra taxes that will come from what seems an innocuous $5 hike in each person's departure tax. It is just as I said earlier: the $5 extra generates a fair bit of revenue.

The end of this collection contract on 30 June 1994 raises some dilemmas for the government. Since 20 per cent of the revenue comes from passengers leaving for New Zealand, any establishment of a common aviation market between Australia and our Kiwi cousins would mean the ending of that proportion of revenue overnight. We have an interesting dilemma on our own doorstep in that the tax might be reduced if we are to do the right thing by our close neighbour, New Zealand.

A common aviation market is highly desirable between our two countries. The shadow minister, who is at the table, agrees entirely with that. Both he and I have had discussions in New Zealand about those propositions and how there might be greater cooperation between the two nations in terms of aviation and agricultural products.

However, the timing could not be worse for any of the public servants in the Department of Transport and Communications who might be trying to decide whether to extend Australia Post's contract or call for new tenders. Part of the difficulty is that I understand Australia Post's contract can be extended only once more. So we have a difficulty with the administration of this tax which involves personal difficulties to passengers. Honourable members who have travelled overseas would know that if one is lucky enough to be at the airport and have the right amount of money one can pay the departure tax. If one does not have the right amount of money, it causes considerable administrative inconvenience.

The other problem is that, if tenders are called with a start-up date of July 1994, the bidders might face some uncertainty in the costs they will have to build into any of the proposals. Ansett, and probably Qantas, will begin operating international services from domestic terminals. We do not know exactly when, but this will require additional collection points for any tenderer—even at integrated international and domestic airports such as Melbourne. This will obviously reduce the government's revenue to some extent by pushing up the tender prices quoted to collect the departure tax, so the budget estimates might not even be met. The government should get its act together with respect to aviation policy. If tenders are to be called for a contract commencing in July next year, they would surely need to be advertised by January at the latest.

The other issue that speakers have alluded to is the government's oft repeated claim that tourism is going through boom times. We can be pleased that the average annual growth in international air arrivals and departures between 1986 and 1992 at Australia's six main international gateways varied from 5.3 per cent at Melbourne, 6.5 per cent at Sydney, 14.7 per cent at Brisbane—that is the airport of the honourable member for Fadden and I know he uses that airport a lot during his working life, so he is very familiar with the increased traffic at that airport—to a massive 42.3 per cent at Cairns.

I draw honourable members' attention to Cairns airport, which I have had the privilege of inspecting. I compliment the port authority on its foresight in developing an international airport at Cairns and seeing an opening in the international passenger market which it could service. It has done this in a cost-effective manner using local capital. It has certainly created a tourism market of its own, independent of other airports around Australia.

However, I caution the government that our performance at least in air arrivals and departures is simply not matching what is appearing in Asia and other parts of the world. Between 1986 and 1990—the latest years for which figures could be made available—the average annual percentage change in combined arrivals and departures at Jakarta in Indonesia was 11.3 per cent. For comparison, in those years, Melbourne's growth was 7.8 per cent and Sydney's was only 6.8 per cent. We can see from those figures that there was an increase in departures and arrivals at the airport at Jakarta in the Asian area. The percentage change during that period at Tokyo was 17.7 per cent; at Changi in Singapore, 12.8 per cent; and at Bangkok, a massive 16.9 per cent. I say `massive' because Thailand's arrivals and departures at its international airports totalled almost 11 million persons, which is more than Australia's six busiest airports could manage in the year 1990.

We must not discourage visitors such as backpackers—who spent on average almost $3,800 each in 1992 compared with $1,760 for other visitors—by excessive taxation measures like the departure tax that is proposed in this bill. I agree with the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) that the backpacker market is a very important aspect of the tourist operation in Australia. As he so quite rightly says, the backpackers of today are the tourists of tomorrow. The backpacking operation is certainly a growth market. Backpackers spend their dollars in the local areas, wherever they might be touring around Australia. I know that backpackers certainly congregate in the Cairns area of Queensland. Their injection into that economy is quite massive. I hope that the government will encourage the backpacker operation. I support the whole view that backpackers will be the tourists of tomorrow and that they do help local economies. Australia provides opportunities for visitors to have low cost holidays and, as a result, backpackers will spread some goodwill about all the good tourist destinations that are here in Australia.

If every tax charge and fee that these price and quality conscious visitors faced increased overnight by about 25 per cent as this tax proposes to do, we would see more than the five per cent drop in backpacker numbers that occurred between 1990 and 1992. We might be drawing a long bow by saying that it was the departure tax that caused the drop-off. Obviously, there were a number of other factors, but backpackers look at every dollar very carefully and it is those considerable overheads that cause them to make decisions about whether they might come to Australia or whether they might go to other Asian nations with lower overhead costings. So this government should not be complacent about the role of tourism in the national economy. Everything that the government and members of the opposition can do to encourage tourism to Australia and develop over the longer term the facilities, the image and the way in which we promote tourism is very important to industry as we come up to the year 2000.

As in industrial relations, as in the business of government and as in social policy, the comparisons Australia makes in tourism cannot be how we as a nation performed two, three or 20 years ago. We should make those comparisons of how Australia is performing in this whole tourist market with other nations around the world. How are we competing and comparing with the Asian market and its rates of growth? How are we comparing with the USA market, which provided a boom some three or four years ago here in Australia? How are we comparing with the European market in tourist growth?

There is no doubt in my mind that the tourist potential of Australia is enormous. We have this uncluttered land mass of pristine wilderness. We have some tourist attractions that cannot be matched in Asia or Europe. If we can provide the facilities, infrastructure and right attitude within the tourist industry, I am sure we will attract these tourists from overseas destinations.

I hope that the government will not increase the departure tax to any greater degree than is competitive on the world market. Whilst a $5 increase does not seem much, it all adds to the overheads. When people overseas put together a package the departure tax becomes part of the package deal. If it becomes too excessive, we will not get the tourists that we have been anticipating.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Departure Tax Amendment Bill. The departure tax increase proposed in the bill is designed to ensure the growth and prosperity of our tourism industry through additional resources that the budget for 1993 had allocated. We see a recognition in this proposal that some additional impost in the way of a departure tax will be used productively by the government in the development of the tourism industry—particularly tourism promotion around the world—and will enable a wide range of initiatives to be undertaken over the next four years. The additional funding will help to ensure and underpin the growth of our tourism industry for the rest of this century.

PARA.TAB: In listening to the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), one could be excused for thinking the tourism industry has not continued to move, grow and prosper in the last few years. With the greatest respect to the honourable member, that is a very inaccurate reflection of the way the tourism industry has grown in Australia in the last decade. It is an industry that, traditionally, until the Labor government came to power, was not really recognised as a proper industry as it is today. It was not recognised that the Commonwealth government had a role to play in the industry. A body such as the Australian Tourist Commission, with its potential to harness the development of the tourism industry, was not seen as an important item on the agenda. Indeed, in elections since that time, opposition members have often gone to the polls advocating the abolition of the Australian Tourist Commission. Such is the priority they place on the coordination and development of our tourism infrastructure and industry. Such is the prominence they think an industry such as tourism should have in marketing around the world. They think the Commonwealth government should just opt out of it and leave it to the piecemeal adhockery that was a feature of tourism development in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —J.J. Brown.

—The Assistant Treasurer rightly identifies the role that the government in 1983 took in tourism. My predecessor in the seat of Parramatta, the Hon. John Brown, was certainly an activist in developing the Hogan campaigns and so on that really started the growth of a new industry for Australia. Today, we see the benefits of the impetus that was undertaken at that time with the launch of those Hogan campaigns around the world, particularly in the United States.

PARA.TAB: We have also seen the growth of our tourism impetus in the Asia-Pacific region more generally. The figures suggest very strongly that, notwithstanding the recession that has occurred here and in parts of the region—indeed, in Europe as well—the interest in Australia as a tourism destination has continued to grow. The desirability of Australia as a safe and stimulating tourist destination has continued to be a priority of people all over the world.

It is interesting to note how prominently tourists from Europe view Australia. I was in Germany recently. We have just on 100,000 tourists coming from Germany now. Of all the tourists who come here, they are the ones who stay longer and, indeed, per capita spend more than any other tourist who visits Australia. That suggests we need to be conscious of the importance of price, but I suspect that when tourists from countries such as Germany come here—they number 100,000 a year and hopefully more as time goes on—the diversity of attractions that exist in Australia is the reason why they choose to come such a long distance to Australia for a holiday when they could be going elsewhere.

In recent discussions about safety of holidays to the United States and so on, it was clear that people in Germany and other countries in Europe are increasingly looking to Australia and seeing the opportunities that exist here for outback holidays and for a diverse range of activities. Also, the prominence that the Sydney Olympic bid has given to tourism opportunities has helped to enhance interest around the world in Australia as a desirable tourist destination.

So rather than the negative approach of asking whether this additional $5 departure tax will undermine tourism, we should be recognising the fairly major achievements over recent times of the Australian Tourist Commission, with its campaigns and its coordination with state tourist commissions to try to develop a more strategic approach among the states, the Commonwealth and the industry. As the honourable member for Corangamite mentioned, when the departure tax came into place in the past, all the money went to aviation development. That was shown to be one of the deficiencies in the approach adopted; not enough Commonwealth energy was going into promoting and marketing Australia abroad. The changes that have taken place over the last few years in the way we harness our effort, and the growth in tourism marketing, are fundamental to creating a greater awareness of Australia around the world.

We have to appreciate that it is a very competitive industry. There are a lot of holiday options for people from Asia or Europe. Unless we keep getting our message across about the attractiveness of our product, we will lose out to those who are prepared to market. We need to spell out the virtues of, and opportunities in, Australia. It is not just aviation or roads infrastructure that we need or other facilities such as hotels and tourism resorts; we also need to market the product in a fairly precise and coordinated fashion.

In part, that is what departure tax funds have been used for over the last few years. As is clearly spelled out in the budget papers, part of the reason for the increase in the departure tax from the beginning of 1994 is to enhance the effort that has been added to in the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and in a variety of initiatives taken since that time, to provide more impetus to that growth. We had a big growth in tourism throughout the 1980s. Some people said that growth would be hard to sustain as time went on and that it would be hard to keep it going.

Most of us who have had a keen interest in the industry know that, with concerted effort, Australia can continue to help the industry grow in a very major fashion through this decade and beyond. The increasing mobility, flexibility and convenience of travel provide that opportunity. Price competitiveness is very important. Very few people would travel from Australia to Europe or Japan, then look at the price equation of travelling from Europe or Japan to Australia, and not say that our pricing structures generally for hotels, fares, packages and all the rest are very competitive.

In Japan, even with its recession, people have continued to take a very strong interest in coming to Australia, in large measure because of our price competitiveness and the desirability of the product—the tourism industry has developed products suitable to that market. Many in Japan claim that such things are not always readily available if they go to the United States and other places.

We should not rest on our laurels. It is important to maintain the price competitiveness in everything we do. We have to develop an advantage in price because of the distance people have to travel to get here, compared with going to other regions. But I do not believe we can sustain an argument that the increase in departure tax will be a pivotal factor. In looking at it from the reverse perspective, that is, of how much extra benefit we will get from greater promotion and awareness of Australia overseas, I am very confident that the equation has been developed in the right way, with the package of the departure tax and the increased expenditure on tourism.

It is worth mentioning a few facts. Exports in the tourism industry have represented 10 per cent of our export earnings over the last year. That is substantial. The level of employment at the moment is near the 500,000 figure—and that is a very substantial growth compared with a decade or more ago when the industry was not even identified in statistics as a real industry. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have a good understanding of this industry, being from a part of New South Wales which is very much involved and interested in tourism and has developed it dramatically in the last decade. I note, from recent reports, that there are increasing moves to expand the flexibility of the infrastructure with charter flights and other important things in places such as Coffs Harbour.

Tourism has developed in other places along the coast. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who is in the chamber, can relate to this matter as well. In the various inquiries we have conducted in the past into customs and other matters, similar sorts of issues have been raised of allowing government policy to have flexibility. That is important. At the same time, there is a recognition that there will be costs as far as immigration, customs and other services are concerned. They should be developed in a way that is commensurate with the accrued economic benefit and the need to have flexible travel into Australia by charter, and so on.

All those things have been implemented. The House should acknowledge some of the achievements made in tourism and the way the tourism industry has developed its professionalism. It has moved dramatically from where it was a few years ago. Sydney is still a very popular destination for visitors to Australia—first arrivals like to come to Sydney. I am sure that with the successful bid for the Olympic Games over the next few years many more will be doing so, as part of a broader visit to Australia.

Part of selling has been the coordination between regions around New South Wales and the packaging of North Queensland, Sydney and some of the other desirable places to which a large number of tourists go. We can do that in a comprehensive way only if we are prepared to spend some of the funds that have been identified and which the Tourist Commission has used in its strategic marketing campaigns around the world; integrating that with other government and private sector initiatives in those regions.

There is a campaign in Japan called Celebrate Australia. When I was there recently I was very pleased to see just how many cities in Japan have taken an interest in this. Funds and resources have been provided through the embassy and a large number of private sector firms. An expenditure of around $40 million is being outlaid in Japan this month on Celebrate Australia. Of that, the direct contribution from the public sector amounts—in various facets—to some $4 million.

It was certainly the view of people I spoke to in Japan that the reason others had the interest and impetus to get involved in this campaign was that the embassy, through the resources it developed, had a serious interest in the issue. If there had not been some commitment from the Commonwealth—from us as a nation—to this initiative, it would have been much harder to get private sector firms, and Japanese tourism industry firms, to say, `We want to sign up and make a contribution to that campaign.'

Part of the role for the funds we provide through the Tourist Commission is to be a catalyst and facilitator in getting others to take an active part in these sorts of campaigns. Some 32 cities across Japan are involved very actively in Celebrate Australia. There has been tremendous interest from chambers of commerce and travel associations across cities such as Osaka, Nagoya and so on. Most of the people who are experts and operators in the field say Australia could not have hoped to get that attention had not the initial drive come from us in the first place.

That is why we need a tourist commission and that is why it needs to be adequately funded, so that we can get the drive that those sorts of things bring and get the private sector interest and sponsorship that binds the whole process together strongly. To maintain that momentum some adjustment—I admit we must get the balance right—and increase in the departure tax is entirely justifiable.

The expenditure on air time, promotion, and the literature that is being produced in Japan about Celebrate Australia has to be the most cost effective that we could possibly hope for at a national level. Notwithstanding the recession in Japan, the number of Japanese tourists coming to Australia has kept growing. At a time when the overall movement of Japanese tourists abroad has not shown substantial growth, tourism to Australia has maintained a healthy trend. Keeping that trend going will be a challenge for us all.

I pay tribute to all Australians who are involved in the Celebrate Australia campaign, including the government agencies and the people associated with the embassies. It is interesting to note that a number of Australians resident in Japan have volunteered to be part of this exercise. They are very dedicated and committed people who have volunteered hours and hours of their time. The embassy staff has put a tremendous effort into this campaign, as have the various consulate offices around Japan, believing fundamentally that Australia is a great place to promote because it has a product that is worth promoting.

Just as importantly, there is an audience in Japan which genuinely believes we have a great product. The Japanese love to come to Australia. This does not happen by accident. Similar sorts of exercises have been undertaken in other parts of Asia, and we will need to keep doing this. Part of the reason why there is so much enthusiasm across the Japanese tourism industry is that it believes that, as a nation, we are serious about tourism and promoting our product. The Japanese believe tourists who come to Australia get value for money. They believe Australia provides cost effective holidays when compared with the costs of hotels and so on in Europe.

I saw a newspaper article a couple of days ago which compared the cost of hotel accommodation in Sydney with that of hotel accommodation in 10 other generally comparable cities around the world. It showed that the cost of a four- or five-star hotel in Sydney averaged about a third or less of the cost of hotels in most cities around Europe. Members of parliament who have had the opportunity to travel overseas would realise that the cost of hotel accommodation in Europe, in particular, is very high compared with Australia.

We need to be competitive with the Asian market. There are more and more people from Asian countries who are mobile and who are keen to undertake travel abroad. Increasingly, we get the impression that they want to come to Australia because they regard Australia as offering very diverse attractions. Many parts of rural and regional Australia are interesting. We have many historical landmarks, as well as great cities such as Sydney and all that it has to offer, including the Blue Mountains.

We can promote all of those things because the dynamics of our tourism industry are built upon the government impetus provided through the Tourism Advisory Council and the active cooperation of tourism bodies across the nation. Furthermore, through the measures provided in part by the additional funding in this year's budget, we now have the impetus to develop regional and localised tourism packages that can fit in nicely with our national objective.

I think that is a very positive step. We need to recognise the importance of that competitive mix in regional Australia and give these areas the opportunity to coordinate their resources. Many of us have probably been members of tourism associations, doing our own thing without necessarily being concerned about the adjacent regions. The regional tourism strategy contained in this budget—which has been allocated funding as a result of this departure tax arrangement—allows for more coordination of those arrangements and for more strategic planning in regional tourism.

I can certainly identify the capacity for that to occur in my own region of western Sydney. There are many attractions to promote in that area—from the Blue Mountains to areas such as Parramatta, which is the second oldest city in Australia. The Olympic Games will provide a much greater development impetus than we have seen in the past.

Honourable members should be coming into this House giving positive support to our tourism industry, commending the initiatives that have been undertaken, and recognising that its active promotion overseas is part and parcel of a competitive tourism industry. That is what the departure tax increase is designed to achieve, and I have pleasure in supporting the bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this wide ranging debate on the Departure Tax Amendment Bill. While this bill deals only with the departure tax, we have had a general debate about the tourist industry. Over the last couple of months, we have been restricted in debating matters of public importance in this House. But I believe this matter is as important as any we could debate because it has far reaching ramifications right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), certainly alerted the House to the benefits of tourism as they exist in Australia today. I must pay a compliment to the shadow minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who is in the chamber today. In his own way, he has spear-headed an approach to tourism unequalled in this parliament for many years. People complain that it has been only in the last 10 years that tourism has really been given its head; but that is not quite true. Until the Fraser government gave its commitment to internationalise the Cairns airport—with all the benefits that that has brought to North Queensland—tourism was going nowhere; particularly in the north. We have to be fair in looking at the past, even as we look to the future. I pay tribute to the honourable member for Fadden for the work he has done within the tourism portfolio.

The bill before us increases the departure tax from $20 to $25—a $5 increase. Initially it was $10 in 1978 under the Fraser government. The budgeted revenue is estimated to be an additional $11 million for 1993-94; $28 million for 1994-95; $30 million for 1995-96; and $32 million for 1996-97. Once we stabilise the rate, the figures indicate a three or four per cent increase in tourism in the remaining three of those four years. That is a fair figure, considering that, according to the estimates, growth in Australia will be limited to less than three per cent. It also recognises that the rest of the world regards Australia as a safe destination for tourists, with many world acclaimed destinations.

We should never forget that. When I come back to our shores from overseas—and I speak particularly about the Barrier Reef—there is nothing in the world that equals the sun, sand and surf of the Queensland beaches or Queensland itself. People can go to the Bahamas, the Mediterranean, or anywhere in the world but they will not find anything like we have in Australia.

The beauty is that, at this stage, Australia is relatively untouched. There are certainly areas in Australia that I believe have been overcommitted and overcommercialised to the point where they are now just concrete jungles. But most of Australia is there awaiting the proper development of resources. In looking at the figures, our real fear should be whether Australia will be in a position to cope with the additional number of tourists and provide the additional services and facilities that the world will be demanding. That is a problem we will have to look at.

I also refer to the effect that the Olympic Games will have on Australian tourism through the number of overseas visitors to our shores. Taking the year 2000 as a benchmark, the games will provide the impetus for an increase in foreign visitors to Australia. Events such as the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane in 1982 and Expo in 1988 had a tremendous influence on the increased tourist intake into Australia. The figures certainly indicate that Queensland is leading this tourist push, but that is not to deny that the other states are doing their share.

I am very happy to be able to report that the additional revenue from the bill will be used for the promotion of tourism right across Australia. The Australian Tourist Commission at this stage has a budget of $103 million, which includes an amount of $25 million from the industry itself. That is creditable because we need a partnership if we are going to develop tourism to its full potential.

I agree with my colleague the honourable member for Fadden that for too long tourism facilities and programs have regarded each other as being in opposition instead of in competition with each other and their attitude has been `If we do not get it within our particular region we do not want it at all'. I do not believe that is the right attitude. I make the point that it is a grave pity, when we realise how much Queensland contributes towards that tourist dollar, that there is no Queenslander appointed to the Australian Tourist Commission. It is all right to say that we have to balance the whole thing up and look right across Australia but when there are eight commissioners I believe one from Queensland should have been appointed.

I understand there are new programs being provided by the Australian Tourist Commission that will enhance that competition but I hope that we do not have the fiasco that we heard of earlier this week of the latest advertising of Qantas being filmed offshore. I think this is another Australian cringe. Australian business and Australians themselves do not believe they are good enough or have the expertise to do this type of advertising publication themselves. If there is a lesson to be learnt from that fiasco it is that the government, Australian instrumentalities and Australian business would do well to look at the expertise in Australia before they go outside looking for the big names, because bigger is not always best. We have had that cringe in Australia of not being able to recognise Australian talent and Australian content.

The figures in connection with the departures of overseas tourists from Australia over the years show again an increase in the number from Queensland. I believe it is a favoured destination and the statistics prove it. In 1987, Queensland was second only to New South Wales, with 13 per cent of the foreign overseas departures. In 1992, while it was still second to New South Wales, that figure was 26 per cent. That 26 per cent figure seems to be holding firm with the quartiles that have come through since.

Those figures also show that we have almost as many Australians departing for overseas destinations as we have foreign visitors coming to visit us. I know we have to take out of that the business equation but I do not think this reflects well on Australia. In 1992 we had 2.5 million foreign visitors departing Australia and yet in the same year we had 2.3 million Australians going overseas. That leads me to the conclusion that unfortunately foreigners know more about Australia than we do ourselves. I will read from an article in the Australian Financial Review of 25 May headed `Foreign visitors know most about best isles'. Basically, foreigners know more about the destinations here than we do ourselves. The article states:
Germans consider Australia adventurous, Italians view it as glamorous, exotic, quaint, unusual and warm, and Swedish travellers look forward to seeing the natural wonders.
And North Queensland certainly offers a range of world-class attractions and facilities for both domestic and international visitors.
The Great Barrier Reef is just one of the unique attractions that is supported by world-class tourism facilities.
Yet it is often overlooked by Australians who seek what they consider to be the more exotic destinations of islands off Fiji and Vanuatu.

SPEECH.PARA: The comment is also made that many of these resorts are of world class standard. I think there is a lesson to be learnt. It is all very well and good to be doing this promotion overseas but again I add the qualification that I think there is a need for us to be able to promote Australia—though not with Qantas advertising filmed in Hawaii—so that more of our own people will travel within our own shores.

PARA.TAB: Departure tax applies to both overseas visitors returning and Australians going overseas, but I believe it would be better for the Australian economy if the Australians did not pay that departure tax but visited within their own shores instead. The industry expects that the increase of $5 per departure will be absorbed in other travel costs and will not be a great influence.

I want to mention two things when talking about the attractiveness of Australia and the ability of people to come to our shores. I mention a case that was told to me in the last fortnight. Some very good friends of ours, Ray and Eve Foreman, recently won on handicap the Brisbane-South Pacific yacht race. During the race they mixed with yachties from all over the world. The comment was made that the yachties do not favour Australia as a destination, just to call in and hook up, because of the costs involved in the AQIS inspections that are not part and parcel of many other destinations.

Australia is apparently one of about three other island nations that make a charge for AQIS type services. I am not talking about departure tax. The Americans have said they are not going to come onshore and pay $100 or $200 for a part of an hour—it is only 15 minutes work—just to have their boat looked at every time they hook into a marina. That comment was made to the Foremans by Americans and also by many other visitors in the South Pacific. So there are tourists who could be accommodated in Australia but who are not being accommodated because of those charges. It is not a great amount but people are price sensitive to those little things. When the Foremans came back as proud winners of the race they were forced to pay an extra $100 to get their boat inspected by AQIS.

The other thing I want to mention concerns never overlooking the internal tourist, the Australian domestic traveller. I know that the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) was castigated here and was called a racist because he brought to the attention of the House an incident where a person from his electorate had gone up to Cairns and found that if he did not pay with yen at certain destinations he could not shop or get the services there. That was his experience. I know of a very similar experience of somebody who travelled up to Ayr, got onto one of the boats, went over to Green Island—I believe that is run by Daikyo now; I am not sure—and all he wanted to do, having paid for his trip in Australian dollars, was to go onshore to buy a soft drink. He could not buy a soft drink unless he exchanged his Australian currency for island currency. The alternative was to go without a drink, which he did.

I think those little things count a lot for the Australian tourist. I would hate to think that we are developing a culture within our tourist industry and at certain destinations where favour is given to international tourists and the domestic tourist is overlooked. I think Australia is for Australians and I believe that, while we should offer good services and good destinations, there is no real reason or good excuse for an Australian visiting his own country to have to convert his Australian currency. I understood that in Australia Australian currency has to be accepted as legal tender. I often wonder how destinations such as that can get away with insisting on only yen. Something needs to be done domestically in that regard.

Having said that, the Australian market is a very lucrative market and one that should be expanded. For quite a while in Mackay we have complained about other difficulties. I believe we are getting our share of the tourist dollar. The thing that I am happy about in my region is that we have not gone overboard and stuck up huge concrete monuments that would despoil the country and which would mean that we probably would not get the visitors that we seek. That is the case in other parts of Australia. But, as my friend the yachtie said, the marinas and berthing facilities could be improved to encourage greater travel along our coast. After all, those people who use the Whitsunday Islands must realise that that is a yachties' paradise. Anyone who visits the place gets hooked on it.

Obviously, Cairns is an established destination, and I would like to repeat something that I said in the past: anyone who charges that the conservatives in government did not think that the tourist industry was important should note that it was the Fraser government that offered $30 million to upgrade the Cairns airport to international standard. Just as importantly, it was the Cairns Port Authority that took over the challenge and spent twice that amount in developing the airport facilities. I understand that Cairns airport is presently getting 60 international flights in and out every week. Of course, the facilities at this airport can tap into the Pacific islands, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and all those Asian markets. Those people who have a yen for travel—and the yen to spend on it—will inject very attractive tourist dollars into the economy if we can keep attracting them with such facilities.

Money would be well spent if, when attracting foreign visitors to a particular destination, domestic aircraft offered packages to ensure that our foreign visitors could spread out to the available attractions. Unless they are American, tourists cannot see Australia in one visit. We must ensure that they have more destinations to see than the one at which they arrive. I believe that the new Qantas-Australian Airlines set-up will lead to a greater diversity of destinations for overseas tourists.

As noted in the Australian Financial Review of 31 August 1993, Cairns is expected to be our second biggest international gateway after Sydney by the year 2000. The director of marketing up there said that, by the year 2000, it is expected that 23 per cent of visitors to Australia will be clearing customs through Cairns compared with about 44 per cent for Sydney. When one realises that Queensland already processes 26 per cent of those visitors, 23 per cent is a great effort from that one airport. So if we can catch the mood and spread those visitors, it will be better to accommodate them right throughout the state and Australia with fly-ons and packages that will benefit the tourists and Australians.

With this mass attack on our major international airports, there must be a policy for back-to-back charters that will allow into other airports the types of aircraft now involved in international travel. I do not specifically mean 747s but many of the aircraft now being used on the Asian and New Zealand routes should be able to land at airports in places such as Hamilton Island, Proserpine and Mackay. I believe that it is very important that we go that way.

I also want to recognise in this debate some of the other great natural attractions to be found in the best electorate in Australia. There is the Great Barrier Reef, a prized destination. Anybody who has visited the Whitsundays and seen the off-shore facilities would also have to recognise Laguna Keys. Foreign currency is being used there to build up facilities on target and to develop a golf course which, it has been suggested by some, is one of the best international golf courses on which they have ever played. Unfortunately, we have yet to get the internationals on the golf course. However, Laguna Keys offers a great on-shore resort.

Then there is Club Med on Lindeman Island where the French have seen fit to spend $60 million to enhance that facility as a destination. Developments have been undertaken on quite a lot of the other islands—Hayman, Hamilton, Brampton, and all along the line. In fact, it thrills me to be able to go into the bills and papers office here and see a big glossy photograph of the Radisson development on Long Island which is right in the middle of the Whitsundays—right in the middle of my electorate. I might encourage other departments within Parliament House to cover other aspects of the Whitsundays. I would be quite happy to provide those photographs free of charge because over the course of this particular session we have lacked the opportunity to talk realistically about the good things that Australia offers.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having looked at the guillotine motion and the time limits for this debate on the Departure Tax Amendment Bill brought in by the government, I had calculated that I would not have the opportunity of making a contribution. However, I am very pleased to be able to speak briefly on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), said earlier, the opposition is not opposing this bill. However, I do have some concerns about increasing charges on an industry that has been singularly successful in helping this country to trade some of the way out of its present problems.

In the run-up to the 13 March election, the government indicated that it would not increase taxes. The travelling public must have been quite dismayed when it saw the departure tax increased in the budget. I hope that the pain that will be inflicted on the tourist industry will indeed be worth the relatively small amount of increased revenue which the government will reap as a result of the departure tax increase.

We should consider whether the departure tax imposed by this country is equitable when compared to departure taxes or other taxes imposed on travellers in other parts of the world. After all, while we on the Sunshine Coast in Queensland and in the area represented by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) have a lot to offer the travelling public, a lot to offer the tourist, we should remember that we are in a world market and that we should not at any time leave ourselves open to pricing ourselves out of the marketplace. Going to any travel agency, one finds that there are very many desirable places competing for the tourist dollar. At all times we must ensure that in Australia we do not put any unnecessary impediment in the way of people visiting us.

I am singularly fortunate to represent the most beautiful tourist destination on the coast of Australia, namely, the Sunshine Coast. It is one of the fastest growing areas in Australia. Indeed, my federal electorate of Fisher is the fastest growing electorate out of the 147 electorates in the House of Representatives. People are voting with their feet and they are moving to join us. They find that we have a very desirable lifestyle and that it is an excellent place to live. Increasingly, we notice that a lot of people also find us a very pleasant place to visit.

Tourism is an inexhaustible resource. I commend the honourable member for Fadden for his very strong support of the tourism industry over the years. It is unfortunate that we were not successful at the 13 March election because the opposition's tourism and aviation policies would have made substantial contributions to improving an industry which is already doing well. However, I am concerned that the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) has not seen fit to put a Queenslander on the Australian Tourist Commission because, after all, Queensland is a premier destination.

While on this occasion the opposition does not oppose the increase in the departure tax, I have some personal misgivings. We should be getting off the back of industry. We should be making it easier for the tourist industry to compete. We should ensure that we are able to attract an ever-increasing number of tourists. While some people might say that a relatively small increase in the departure tax will not deter people from visiting us—I certainly hope that is the case—one should be concerned by the fact that any increase in the departure tax is being imposed. The government stands condemned before the people of this nation for its broken promises in the election not to increase taxes.
In effect, the government conned the Australian people on 13 March. The government was deliberately economical with the truth in the run-up to the 13 March election.

I will not detain the House at length, except to say that I am concerned about the increase in the departure tax. I am worried that it will be one more impediment which will discourage people from taking advantage of the very many pleasant places to visit in Australia. I hope that in future the government will remove taxes from tourism to encourage tourism rather than bring in measures such as the one presently before the House. This measure may discourage some people from coming to this country and from contributing to the economic recovery which, unfortunately, to date has been all too thin.
