SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As change appears to be squarely on the government's agenda, it is an appropriate time to raise an issue which, unlike our constitution and flag, actually does require change. Unfortunately, there is no choice to vote or not to vote. It is time that we caught up with the rest of the world. Australia is the only English-speaking nation and the only Westminster democracy to enforce compulsory voting. While I steadfastly and very strongly support a person's right to vote, it is the antithesis of democracy to compel people to exercise their rights. People should have the right to vote or not to vote. Compulsory voting is a farce.

PARA.TAB: Introduced in 1924 for the upcoming federal elections, compulsory voting has, by default, become an accepted fact of Australian politics. There should be debate in all parties about the merits and disadvantages of this policy. In the early part of this century a drop in voter turnout at one election was assumed to be sufficient justification for the imposition of compulsory voting. It should be noted for the record that that particular election fell on the Saturday before Christmas, when voter turnout would naturally have been down. The private member's bill which ended voluntary voting for federal elections passed both Houses without a division after less than 2 1/2 hours debate—not very much consideration for such a measure. In the House the then honourable member for Boothby, Mr Duncan-Hughes, spoke against the proposal, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I regret the haste with which this bill has been introduced. Compulsory voting was not advocated by me when contesting the last election. There may be good reasons for the reduction in the number of persons who voted—
at the election in question—

but that falling off does not, of itself, justify this House in making such a radical alteration of the electoral laws of the Commonwealth as this bill proposes. It is said that a man cannot be made moral by an act of parliament. It is certain that a man cannot be compelled to take an interest in political affairs if he does not want to do so.

Under our current system Australians are forced to turn up at the polling booth. It has not been proven that this serves any good purpose. It simply increases the proportion of votes cast thoughtlessly.

PARA.TAB: Compulsory voting has undesirable effects on the quality of participation in political life. It helps to make political parties lazy between elections. It encourages last-minute saturation advertising campaigns and, as such, increases the likelihood of voters being misled by false promises. The mere mention of voluntary voting arouses suspicion, knee-jerk reactions and emotive rhetoric. There is, however, no evidence to indicate that voluntary voting would favour one side of politics in particular. It would simply be returning liberty to the individual. This is a matter which all parties should consider very seriously.

Voluntary voting has many benefits. Voting turnouts tend to be much higher in marginal electorates than in safe ones. Voluntary voting, therefore, appears to make it harder for incumbents to take their seats for granted. It promotes increased community involvement in politics and elections due to the fact that potential voters have to be encouraged to go out and cast their votes. Australians deserve the freedom to make their own choice about voting. This issue should and must be on the agenda. I hope that the government looks at it fairly and squarely. It certainly, at the very least, deserves open debate.

So often, when voluntary voting is mentioned, the American example is cited with predictions that voter turnout would decline so dramatically that governments would be decided by a minority. It is misleading to draw a comparison between the United States and Australia. For a start, electoral enrolment is optional in the USA. The rules of eligibility for enrolment vary widely from state to state. Voter fatigue is alive and well in the USA. On top of the range of elections for the three levels of government with which we are familiar, there are any number of contests for the position of judge, sheriff and so on.

Under these circumstances the ballot box will lose appeal. In any event, I believe that we should maintain compulsory enrolment, unlike the United States, but have voluntary voting. It is more appropriate to compare Australia with other countries that share our common law heritage and system of government. New Zealand averages a turnout rate of around 88 per cent without the imposition of compulsory voting. In the United Kingdom and Canada the turnout usually exceeds 75 per cent. I suggest that, while compulsory voting may be part of Australia's past since 1924, it should not be part of its future. I implore the government to look at this proposal. It is a positive reform measure, requiring proper consideration. It is a measure which involves the liberty of the individual and fairness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on the record that I completely and totally endorse compulsory voting. If we live in a country, we should have the responsibility to have some say in its government. The point that I would like to bring to the attention of the House is an 1837 report of a Select Committee on Aborigines in the British Settlements reported to the House of Commons. As recorded by the House, the report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the intercourse of Europeans in general without any exception in favour of the subjects of Great Britain, has been, unless when attended by missionary exertions, a source of many calamities to uncivilised nations. Too often, their territory has been usurped; their property seized; their numbers diminished; their character debased; the spread of civilisation impeded. European vices and diseases have been introduced amongst them, and they have been familiarised with the use of our most potent instruments for the subtle or the violent destruction of human life, viz. brandy and gunpowder . . . . It might be presumed that the native inhabitants of any land have an incontrovertible right to their own soil; a plain and sacred right, however, which seems not to have been understood. Europeans have entered their borders uninvited, and, when there, have not only acted as if they were undoubted lords of the soil, but have punished the natives as aggressors if they have evinced a disposition to live in their own country . . . . If they have been found upon their own property, they have been treated as thieves and robbers. They are driven back into the interior as if they were dogs or kangaroos. From very large tracts we have, it appears, succeeded in eradicating them; and though from some parts their ejection has not been so apparently violent as from others, it has been equally complete, through our taking possession of their hunting-grounds, whereby we have despoiled them of the means of existence'. The committee gave particular attention to the Aborigines in the Australian colonies and the weight of the evidence it obtained constituted one of the most condemning indictments of genocide in the nineteenth century.

I read that extract because I am concerned by the comments that have been made and the position that has been taken by the coalition parties. I ask them to look at history. I ask them to look at this 1837 report. When those opposite express their well-considered opinions, when they stand before this House and make their opinions known, when they have the legislation in front of them and make their position known, I ask them to look at the real history. I ask them to look at what has really happened to our indigenous Australians and to have some compassion, some foresight, to have the courage of their convictions and do the honourable thing, and that is to acknowledge what has taken place in the past.

PARA.TAB: Today, as individual Australians, we may not be directly responsible for what has happened in the past, but as a society and a civilisation we have a direct responsibility.I ask those opposite to take the 1837 Select Committee on Aborigines into account, to examine what changes have really taken place over the years, and to ask themselves why we should not now take a civilised and responsible attitude and make amends to these people who, although they were the original inhabitants and owners of this land, have been grossly and unfairly treated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a matter of discrimination against a disabled Western Australian by the Legal Aid Commission of Western Australia. Mr Terry Wigley is an $8,000 per year disability pensioner who has been ordered to pay his estranged wife $50 a week child maintenance. His wife is a nursing sister—a deputy director of nursing, in fact—earning $42,000 per year. She owns an $80,000 home. She was also granted legal aid.

PARA.TAB: Mr Wigley has a loving relationship with his 14-year-old son whom he willingly clothes, accommodates, feeds and entertains for 30 per cent of the year—all on an $8,000 single man's disability pension. He is currently in arrears of more than $1,000 with the Child Support Agency and faces arrest for non-compliance. He was in hiding until two weeks ago when he was hospitalised suffering bronchial pneumonia, severe and chronic diabetes, angina and low-grade quadriplegia. He is out now, back in hiding, but continues to suffer two serious angina attacks per week and faces the possibility of amputation of his feet due to the complications of his diabetes.

Mr Wigley's application for legal aid was refused, both initially and on reconsideration, on the basis of `the limited funding available to the Commission for the provision of legal aid, and because of the greater needs of other applicants'. Could a deputy director of nursing on $42,000 have greater needs than a physically and almost mentally wrecked man on $8,000 per year? She was granted legal aid. I am numbed by the sheer stupidity of that.

The commission has ignored a request for a meeting with Mr Wigley, his social worker and a member of my staff. Now, with the approval and endorsement of the commission, it has hit him with a bill for $7,871.38 for services rendered by various legal firms four to six years ago in a workers compensation matter.

It seems that the Western Australian Legal Aid Commission has little or no regard to Mr Wigley's life threatening health predicament. The undeclared war it has waged on a sick man—hounding him for money he does not have, and denying him representation—will almost certainly end up with him in the grave. Each time his social worker rings my office, I fear it is to tell me of his death. The attitude of the commission's review committee flabbergasts me. It would only need to take one look at the man to see that he desperately needs help. What does the committee say when I ask it to look for some compassionate grounds? I am told, `The decision of the review committee is final. I am not in a position to reassess Mr Wigley's application to appeal against the magistrate's decision'.

Then the commission proceeded to place a mortgage on Mr Wigley's home, of which he only owns a small portion. Mr Wigley's health problems are directly related to the stress caused by this tragic case, which should not have arisen in the first place. The immense and unjustifiable hardship caused to this man by this group of faceless, inhuman robots is unforgivable and, may I say, totally un-Australian. In the light of his encounters with the commission, the lack of assistance, the possible victimisation and the undeniable deficiency in compassion, it could be legitimately argued that Mr Wigley is being seriously disadvantaged and discriminated against by members of the Western Australian Legal Aid Commission under sections 40 and 42(i) of the Disability Discrimination Act.

With the hope that justice and equity prevail in this nation, I ask the Western Australian Legal Aid Commission to look positively at the merits of Mr Wigley's case and, in particular, at his impoverished health and dire financial situation. I ask them to determine that the costs against him be set aside. Such a decision would be in keeping with the principles set down by the Western Australian State Disability Services Act 1992 and the Commonwealth Discrimination Act 1992. It would also be in keeping with the Australian principle of a fair go. I ask the commission to demonstrate that it is prepared to take an active role in maintaining the rights of people with disabilities, such as Mr Wigley, who are often disadvantaged both financially and physically, and who are consequently placed in positions of double jeopardy.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Returned and Services League of Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday evening I had the pleasure of attending a diggers' night in the small town of Dungog in the Hunter Valley. It is an annual event where the local branch of the RSL hosts a dinner for all veterans in the area. It is not an elaborate occasion—the catering is done by wives, daughters and other volunteers—but it is a night where these people enjoy good fellowship and remember their comrades. These veterans, who were prepared to make the ultimate sacrifice so long ago, are still supporting the community in which they live—as they are doing in towns like Dungog all over Australia.

PARA.TAB: During the evening I mentioned that I had served in the 11th National Service Training Battalion as a national service trainee, whereupon I was advised that I was eligible to join a sub-branch of the RSL. I guess that there are many other `nashos' who are unaware of this. In fact, approximately 220,000 young men served their country in that way in that unique chapter in Australia's defence history.

We knew exactly what it was like to serve in the forces—the short-arm parades, the latrine duty, the compulsory injections every Friday night for every known disease and some that were unknown, the bromide in our tea that did not work, and, of course, the first weekend's leave after eight weeks. The attitudes to our peacekeeping role have changed since then, but in March 1951 national service was introduced in an atmosphere of fear about the growth of communist influences throughout the world and the Menzies government's belief that large-scale deployment of troops could still be a prime factor in many contingencies.

The ALP conference voted by a small majority in favour of the scheme. So all young men aged 18 years were required to register and, if fit, undertake training for 176 days in one of the military services. A review of the scheme in 1953 produced certain changes. Army training was reduced to 140 days and navy and air force training to 154 days. Trainees had free choice of a branch of the service, but volunteered to serve overseas as required if in the navy or air force. National service training continued to operate in this form until April 1957 when the government came to the conclusion that the maintenance of a large reservoir of partially trained young men was no longer essential to Australia's military defence needs. The Regular Army was reorganised and increased its intake and the national service intake fell from an average of about 33,000 to one of 12,000.

National service training for the navy and air force was discontinued. Trainees were then determined by a ballot system based on birth dates. Actually, I am sure this appealed to the Australian gambling streak. So if 18 December, for example, came up, as it did for me, one reported to the nearest army headquarters and then went off to Wacol, Ingleburn, Puckapunyal or wherever, and underwent basic military training with the officers of the Regular Army. The government finally suspended the scheme completely in 1959.

I wish to bring to the attention of the House this evening the fact that former national service trainees of that unique period in Australia's history are not only eligible to join the RSL, that great organisation of volunteers, but they would be welcomed for their input of fresh ideas and youth. Whether or not we believe in the political attitudes of the RSL, there is no doubt that the organisation is of enormous value to many people in our community. Unfortunately, it is an ageing organisation. I make this speech to reach many of those `nashos' so that they, too, can serve the community in which they live. I am sure the RSL will reflect this in its continuing spirit of commitment to all communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the acknowledgment by the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) of national servicemen. Having lived through that period, although not being a national serviceman, I understand some of the issues to which he referred and I dip my lid to them.

PARA.TAB: I want to say a few words tonight about our Aboriginal communities and my association with them. I come from a small rural community. I suppose my first memory in this regard is of the integrated school that I attended, playing football and other sport and enjoying the friendship and comradeship. As I got a little older I moved around the country, to the eastern seaboard, and I ended up in the Northern Territory, working with Aboriginal people on cattle stations and in the various occupations that I had as a young man.

In another stage of my life, that of political candidate, I have been required to be a little more circumspect and address myself more to the deeper issues affecting our society. In the last 12 months or two years I have experienced the despair and the ecstasy, if you like. They might not be the most appropriate words, but they are the best that come to mind. I remember one Aboriginal community in the far north where I observed petrol sniffing for the first time. It had an overwhelming impact. I remember at Christmas time last year being with a group of Aboriginals in Port Augusta at a national evangelical gathering. There was much excellent fellowship, a wonderful sense of comradeship and a very strong force for a positive future.

Another aspect of my association with the Aboriginal community has occurred during my work as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I have really valued that work during my short time in parliament because it has given me an opportunity to listen to all points of view across all parties. I pay tribute to all members of that committee as we endeavour to come to terms with the issues that confront us.

In recent days I have had the good fortune to share with my daughter her memories of her work experience at a little settlement, Kalkarindji, in the Northern Territory. She worked there as a nurse with Aboriginal people and Aboriginal health workers. She came back full of absolute appreciation for the opportunity to work there and she would love to go back.

One aspect of Australian people of which I am immensely proud is that of fairness. There will always be in Australia that sense of justice and fairness which will strive to overcome. It will never be adequate; some of the Aboriginal issues that we face are huge. The issues of health and accommodation have been talked about by many people in this place, no doubt for many decades.

One cannot talk about Aboriginal people without mentioning football and their sense of humour and love of the game. While I was a candidate I travelled to the Pitjantjatjara lands. I was absolutely staggered when the young chairman of the Aboriginal council came up to me and said, `Are you related to those fellows who play for Port Adelaide?'. This fellow in the Pitjantjatjara lands, thousands of kilometres away from Port Adelaide, was asking me whether some of my relatives happened to play for Port Adelaide. It was quite remarkable.

I think it is time to recognise the progress that we as a society have made. I am proud of the country in which I live. I am confident we are going to come to terms with the issues that confront us. I conclude by remembering once again, as I did in my first speech, Benno Murray, the Aboriginal Gallipoli veteran and veteran of two wars. I think he exemplifies the Australian spirit and that of Aboriginal and European Australians together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw the attention of the House to a very disturbing comment that appeared in the Herald-Sun newspaper of 22 October by the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht. Senator Schacht, as honourable members will know, has not endeared himself to scientists in Australia. They have already come to the conclusion that his interest in this area is purely to gain a name for himself by making major decisions regardless of whether or not those decisions are seen as being sensible by the science community. We had a proposal to merge ANSTO with the CSIRO and to break up the CSIRO divisions that are concerned with marine science.

PARA.TAB: The comment that was reported in the Herald-Sun this week adds a new dimension to the problems which Australian science is now facing. The minister confessed to a visiting group of science students that he was sick and tired of going to meetings of scientists. He said to the students that he found the scientists were all grey-haired men in cardigans and that he found these meetings boring. He said it was a bit boring to have to go along to these meetings of elderly scientists in cardigans and he was sick and tired of it.

The attack on Australian scientists is absolutely intolerable. The minister quite rightly was rebuked by the government's own former chief scientist, Professor Ralph Slatyer, who made a stinging comment on these remarks when he pointed out that, to the extent that there was an increasing number of older people undertaking scientific research in Australia's universities and in the CSIRO, this was largely a result of the cutbacks that have occurred in science funding.

In particular, of course, as all involved in Australian science would know, by taking funding out of the universities through these cutbacks and putting it into the Australian Research Council, the universities have been deprived of funds vital to bringing on younger graduates and giving them a chance to cut their teeth on research within the universities. These are people who would not be eligible and would not be able to obtain competitive research grants from the ARC but who, in the past, were brought into Australian science through funds that were available to the universities and which have now been removed from them.

So, to the extent that this greying of Australian science is a reality, it is entirely a function of the government's policies on science. The government has allowed the problem to degenerate to the extent that the CSIRO now believes that half of its research staff will have reached retirement age by the year 2000. Not only is the age distribution in the nation's research institutions skewed towards older research staff, but these institutions have insufficient funds to recruit young people and, as a result, the attractiveness of careers in areas such as science, engineering and technology has declined relative to other professions.

What Australian science needs is a minister with vision and, above all, a minister with an interest in science. We know that this minister is interested in the leadership of the Australian Labor Party because he was the numbers man for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). We know that he is interested in the upheaval of Australia's constitution because it was he who moved the resolution at the ALP conference in Hobart that Australia should become a republic. But what still needs to be demonstrated is that the person responsible for the government science policy has an interest in science. He should be prepared to talk to and consult with scientists. He should stop abusing and demoralising them. He should also stop disabusing young people of the view that there is a decent career for them in science, because there will not be as long as this present approach to Australian science continues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: The Asiatic black bear is listed under Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) which restricts the trade of endangered species. Australia and China are both signatories to CITES.

Accordingly the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, as the Australian CITES management authority, bans the import of Asiatic black bear products into Australia. The import of medicines (and other products) is subject to regulation under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 if they contain parts, products or derivatives of animals or plants protected by CITES. The import of such medicines is not permitted for private or commercial purposes and these products are subject to seizure on arrival in Australia. These and other regulations relating to the import into Australia of products are enforced by the Australian Customs Service.
Our Embassy in Beijing has made representations to the Chinese authorities expressing our concern about reports of the maltreatment of Asiatic black bears in China and trade in the protected species.
